title: Sims v. Hall
description: In this legal malpractice action, the court reviews the federal law of disclaimer relating to estates in the context of legal malpractice precedent.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Alice C. Sims, Jr., Individually And In Her Capacity as Personal Representative 
        of the Estates of Alice C. Sims, Sr., and Georgia Sheridan Sims,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Ronald R. Hall,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Olin D. Burgdorf, Master In Equity

Opinion No. 3703
Submitted November 3, 2003 â€“ Filed December 
  8, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Ronald R. Hall, of West Columbia, Pro Se.
John G. Felder, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:  Alice Sims, Jr., initiated 
  this legal malpractice action against Ronald R. Hall alleging he was negligent 
  in failing to provide competent advice regarding the administration of her deceased 
  motherâ€™s estate.Â  The trial court found Hall was negligent and awarded Sims 
  $191,543 in actual damages.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
 Alice Sims, Jr.â€™s sister, Georgia Sims, 
  died intestate on January 14, 1997.Â  Their mother, Alice Sims, Sr., died later 
  that year on September 1, 1997.Â  As personal representative of both estates, 
  Alice Sims, Jr., retained Hall to advise her as she concluded her motherâ€™s and 
  sisterâ€™s affairs.
Georgia Sims died without a valid will.Â  
  Her estate passed to Alice Sims, Sr., under South Carolinaâ€™s intestate succession 
  statute.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-2-103(2) (Supp. 2002) (providing if 
  there is no surviving spouse or surviving issue, the entire estate passes to 
  the intestateâ€™s parents).Â  As a result, when Alice Sims, Sr.â€™s estate was settled 
  in 1998, it was subject to substantially higher tax liability because Georgia 
  Simsâ€™ property had become part of Alice Sims, Sr.â€™s estate.Â  
The taxing of Georgia 
  Simsâ€™ property as part of her motherâ€™s estate could have been avoided if Alice 
  Sims, Sr. (during the last few months of her life) or Alice Sims, Jr. (as personal 
  representative of Alice Sims, Sr.â€™s estate after her death) had executed a â€œqualified 
  disclaimerâ€ under section 2518 of the Internal Revenue Code.Â  See 26 
  U.S.C.A. Â§ 2518 (2003).Â  South Carolina adopted the Internal Revenue Codeâ€™s 
  disclaimer requirements for its estate tax laws.Â  Section 12-16-1910 (1976) 
  of the South Carolina Code provides that â€œif a person as defined in Section 
  62-2-801 makes a disclaimer as provided in Internal Revenue Code Section 2518 
  with respect to any interest in property, this chapter applies as if the interest 
  had never been transferred to the person.â€ 
By exercising the right of disclaimer, a person relinquishes 
  all rights to, or â€œdisclaims,â€ property received by gift, will, or intestate 
  succession.Â  This is done almost exclusively to garner favorable tax consequences.Â  
  In this case, if a valid disclaimer of Georgia Simsâ€™ property had been made 
  by Alice Sims, Sr., or on behalf of her estate by Alice Sims, Jr., the property 
  of Georgia Sims would have been treated for tax purposes as though it had never 
  passed to Alice Sims, Sr.
The right of disclaimer cannot, however, 
  be exercised at any time.Â  A party wishing to disclaim her interest in property 
  received must do so within the statutorily prescribed time limit.Â  The time 
  period is enunciated in section 2518, which provides, in pertinent part, that 
  the written disclaimer must be â€œreceived by the transferor of the interest, 
  his legal representative, or the holder of the legal title to the property to 
  which the interest relates not later than the date which is 9 months after . 
  . . the day on which the transfer creating the interest in such person is made.â€Â  
  26 U.S.C.A. Â§ 2518(b)(2)(A).Â  For the purposes of the present appeal, the unappealed 
  rulings of the trial court establish as the law of this case that the date of 
  â€œtransferâ€ under section 2518 was the date of Georgia Simsâ€™ death. [2]  Â 
Alice Sims, Jr., served as the personal representative 
  of Georgia Simsâ€™ estate and Alice Sims, Sr.â€™s estate during this nine-month 
  time period for disclaimer following Georgia Simsâ€™ death.Â  It is undisputed 
  that Hall, as Alice Sims, Jr.â€™s attorney during this time, never advised her 
  of the benefits of disclaiming Alice Sims, Sr.â€™s interest in Georgia Simsâ€™ estate.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

Alice Sims, Jr., instituted this action against 
  Hall, claiming he was professionally negligent in failing to advise her of the 
  right to disclaim Georgia Simsâ€™ estate.Â  The case was tried without a jury before 
  the Master-in-Equity of Orangeburg County.Â  The trial court found Hallâ€™s failure 
  to discuss the option of executing a disclaimer fell below the standard of care 
  owed to Sims. Â The court ruled that Alice Sims, Jr., was legally entitled 
  to exercise the right of disclaimer on behalf of her motherâ€™s estate and she 
  would have disclaimed had she been informed of the option by Hall.Â  As to damages, 
  the court found that the failure to execute a disclaimer resulted in additional 
  tax liability of $191,543.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In an action at law tried without a jury, 
  an appellate courtâ€™s scope of review extends only to the correction of errors 
  of law.Â  Crary v. Djebelli, 329 S.C. 385, 388, 496 S.E.2d 21, 23 (1998) 
  (citing Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 
  86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976)); Campbell v. Marion County Hosp. Dist., 
  354 S.C. 274, 280, 580 S.E.2d 163, 165-66 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Thus, the factual 
  findings of the trial judge will not be disturbed on appeal unless a review 
  of the record discloses that there is no evidence which reasonably supports 
  the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Harkins v. Greenville County, 340 S.C. 
  606, 621, 533 S.E.2d 886, 893 (2000); Townes, 266 S.C. at 86, 
  221 S.E.2d at 775; Scott v. Greenville Hous. Auth., 353 S.C. 639, 
  645, 579 S.E.2d 151, 154 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Hall appeals the trial courtâ€™s judgment, 
  arguing: (A) Respondent did not properly establish that he owed a duty to inform 
  her of the disclaimer rights or that he breached this duty, and (B) Respondent 
  failed to present sufficient evidence supporting the trial courtâ€™s finding he 
  proximately caused the damages. [3] 
  Â  In an action for legal malpractice, the claimant must prove four elements: 
  (1) the existence of an attorney-client relationship; (2) breach of a duty by 
  the attorney; (3) damage to the client; and (4) proximate causation of the client's 
  damages by the breach.Â  Smith v. Haynsworth, Marion, McKay & Geurard, 
  322 S.C. 433, 435 n.2, 472 S.E.2d 612, 613 n.2 (1996); McNair v. Rainsford, 
  330 S.C. 332, 342, 499 S.E.2d 488, 493 (Ct. App. 1998). Â 
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Standard of Care and Breach
Generally, a plaintiff in a legal malpractice case 
  must establish the standard of care by expert testimony, unless the subject 
  matter is of common knowledge to laypersons.Â  Smith v. Haynsworth, Marion, 
  McKay & Geurard, 322 S.C. 433, 435, 472 S.E.2d 612, 613 (1996); Hall 
  v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 174, 561 S.E.2d 654, 657 (Ct. App. 2002); Henkel 
  v. Winn, 346 S.C. 14, 18, 550 S.E.2d 577, 579 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  However, 
  this court held in Mali v. Odom that expert testimony is not required 
  where the defendant admits the standard of care that was owed to the plaintiff.Â  
  295 S.C. 78, 81, 367 S.E.2d 166, 168 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  The same result is warranted 
  in the present case.
In Mali, the plaintiffs brought 
  a legal malpractice action against their attorney alleging negligent misrepresentation 
  at a real estate closing.Â  Id. at 79, 367 S.E.2d at 168.Â  The court found 
  the plaintiffs were not required to establish by expert testimony the applicable 
  standard of care because the defendant attorney conceded in written responses 
  to the plaintiffsâ€™ interrogatories that he had a duty to disclose restrictions 
  on the subject property and explain the legal impact of those restrictions to 
  his clients.Â  Id. at 81, 367 S.E.2d at 168.
In the present case, Hall admitted in his Memorandum 
  in Support of Summary Judgment filed with the circuit court that, during the 
  nine-month time period of the disclaimer right, Alice Sims, Jr.â€™s â€œcounsel of 
  recordâ€ had a duty to advise her regarding the option to execute a disclaimer.Â Â  
  In his motion for summary judgment and supporting memorandum, however, the lynchpin 
  of Hallâ€™s argument was that he was not the â€œcounsel of recordâ€ during the nine-month 
  disclaimer period. [4] Â  Therefore, 
  in addressing the duty to advise Sims of her right to disclaim, Hall states 
  in the memorandum:

As Defendant was not Plaintiffâ€™s attorney at the time of 
  the transfer, nor had any knowledge or dealings with either Estate, the Defendant 
  could not have advised Plaintiff regarding her option to file a Disclaimer.Â  
  It follows then that the Defendant owed no duty to Plaintiff to advise her regarding 
  her option to file a Disclaimer.Â  That duty lay with her then counsel of record.

At trial, Hall abandoned the argument that he was 
  not Simsâ€™ attorney after his motion for summary judgment was denied.Â  He now 
  concedes that he was Simsâ€™ attorney during the disclaimer period. 
Hall argues that his statement in his summary judgment 
  memorandum does not constitute an admission of the standard of care because 
  he made the statement while arguing that someone else was Simsâ€™ 
  counsel of record during the disclaimer period.Â  We disagree.
The admission of the standard of care need not 
  be an admission of wrongdoing by the defendant.Â  To the contrary, the purpose 
  of establishing the appropriate standard of care is simply to arm the finder 
  of fact with the appropriate criteria by which to judge the defendantâ€™s conduct.Â  
  Cianbro Corp. v. Jeffcoat & Martin, 804 F. Supp. 784, 791 (D.S.C. 
  1992).Â  In Mali, the defendant admitted his duty to disclose the restrictions 
  on the subject property, but he did not admit he breached that duty.Â  See 
  also Stallings v. Ratliff, 292 S.C. 349, 356 S.E.2d 414 (Ct. App. 
  1987) (finding testimony of defendant physicianâ€™s own expert and defendant himself 
  established the applicable standard of care, even though defendant denied he 
  breached that standard).Â  Thus, Hallâ€™s argument that his statement in his summary 
  judgment memorandum does not constitute an admission establishing the standard 
  of care because it was not made in connection with an admission of wrongdoing 
  is in error.
We hold Hall established the appropriate standard 
  of care by his own admission and expert testimony was not required in this case.
Despite his admission, Hall contends he did not 
  breach his duty to advise Alice Sims, Jr., of her rights to execute a disclaimer 
  because he did not have knowledge of the size of Alice Sims, Sr.â€™s estate during 
  the time he was the attorney for the estate.Â  Because he did not know the amount 
  of the estate, Hall claims he had no way to determine if there would be possible 
  tax consequences.
This argument is meritless.Â  Hall acknowledged that he was 
  familiar with the concept of disclaimer.Â  Moreover, he has admitted that he 
  had a duty to inform Sims of the right of disclaimer.Â  As an attorney familiar 
  with the concept, Hallâ€™s duty to advise his client whether disclaimer would 
  be to her advantage cannot be abrogated by mere ignorance of his clientâ€™s affairs.Â  
  Hallâ€™s duty to inform Sims of the right of disclaimer compelled him to ascertain 
  if executing a disclaimer was in his clientâ€™s interest or, at a minimum, advise 
  her of the existence or significance of a disclaimer.
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Proximate Cause
Hall next asserts that he did not proximately 
  cause Alice Sims, Sr.â€™s estate to be subject to additional tax liability because 
  Alice Sims, Sr. (1) took possession and, therefore, â€œacceptedâ€ Georgia Simsâ€™ 
  property, and (2) â€œdirectedâ€ its disposition to Alice Sims, Jr.â€”actions Hall 
  claims contravene the right of disclaimer under section 2518.Â  We address these 
  claims seriatim.
Proximate cause requires proof of causation in 
  fact and legal cause.Â  Oliver v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. 
  Transp., 309 S.C. 313, 316, 422 S.E.2d 128, 130 (1992); Hurd v. Williamsburg 
  County, 353 S.C. 596, 611, 579 S.E.2d 136, 144 (Ct. App. 2003); Trivelas 
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 348 S.C. 125, 135, 558 S.E.2d 271, 276 
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Causation in fact is proved by establishing the plaintiffâ€™s 
  injury would not have occurred â€œbut forâ€ the defendantâ€™s negligence.Â  Oliver, 
  309 S.C. at 316, 422 S.E.2d at 130; Small v. Pioneer Mach., Inc., 329 
  S.C. 448, 463, 494 S.E.2d 835, 842 (Ct. App. 1997); Vinson v. Hartley, 
  324 S.C. 389, 400, 477 S.E.2d 715, 721 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Legal cause is proved 
  by establishing foreseeability.Â  Bray v. Marathon Corp., Op. No. 25733 
  (S.C. Sup.Ct. filed October 13, 2003) (Shearouse Search Term Begin Search 
  Term End Adv. Sh. No. 37 at 36). Â For an act to be a proximate cause of the 
  injury, the injury must be a foreseeable consequence of the act.Â  Young v. 
  Tide Craft, Inc., 270 S.C. 453, 475, 242 S.E.2d 671, 681 (1978); Small, 
  329 S.C. at 463, 494 S.E.2d at 842-43.Â  Although foreseeability of some injury 
  from an act or omission is a prerequisite to establishing proximate cause, the 
  plaintiff need not prove that the actor should have contemplated the particular 
  event which occurred.Â  Whitlaw v. Kroger Co., 306 S.C. 51, 54, 410 S.E.2d 
  251, 253 (1991); Bramlette v. Charter-Med.-Columbia, 302 S.C. 68, 74, 
  393 S.E.2d 914, 916 (1990).
The defendant may be held liable for anything which appears 
  to have been a natural and probable consequence of his negligence.Â  Greenville 
  Memâ€™l Auditorium v. Martin, 301 S.C. 242, 245, 391 S.E.2d 546, 548 (1990); 
  Childers v. Gas Lines, Inc., 248 S.C. 316, 325, 149 S.E.2d 761, 765 (1966).Â  
  Proximate cause does not mean the sole cause.Â  Bishop v. South Carolina Depâ€™t 
  of Mental Health, 331 S.C. 79, 89, 502 S.E.2d 78, 83 (1998); Hurd, 
  353 S.C. at 613, 579 S.E.2d at 145.Â  The defendantâ€™s conduct can be a proximate 
  cause if it was at least one of the direct, concurring causes of the injury.Â  
  Hughes v. Childrenâ€™s Clinic, P.A., 269 S.C. 389, 398, 237 S.E.2d 753, 
  757 (1977); Small, 329 S.C. at 464, 494 S.E.2d at 843.
 1.                
Alice Sims, Sr., did not â€œacceptâ€ Georgia Simsâ€™ estate. 
   
 Under section 2518, a person may validly 
  execute a disclaimer only if â€œsuch person has not accepted the interest or any 
  of its benefits.â€Â  Hall claims Alice Sims, Sr., took constructive possession 
  of Georgia Simsâ€™ property and thereby â€œacceptedâ€ it.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note this issue is not preserved 
  for appellate review.Â  Though Hall pled this defense in his answer to plaintiffâ€™s 
  complaint, the trial court did not rule upon the question of whether Alice Sims, 
  Sr., accepted Georgia Simsâ€™ property, and Hall did not raise the issue in his 
  post-trial Motion to Modify or Amend Judgment and Motion for a New Trial.Â  Post-trial 
  motions to amend or modify judgment are necessary to preserve issues that have 
  been raised to the trial court but not ruled upon.Â  Bailey v. Segars, 
  346 S.C. 359, 365, 550 S.E.2d 910, 913 (Ct. App. 2001); see also 
  Creech v. South Carolina Marine Wildlife Res. Depâ€™t, 328 S.C. 24, 34, 
  491 S.E.2d 571, 576 (1997) (holding that appellate court cannot address an issue 
  unless the issue was raised to and ruled upon by the trial court).Â  Accordingly, 
  the issue is not properly before this court.Â  Even if we were to reach the merits 
  of Hallâ€™s argument, however, we would still affirm the trial courtâ€™s judgment.
We find no evidence in the record before us sufficient 
  to warrant finding Alice Sims, Sr., accepted Georgia Simsâ€™ property.Â  In defining 
  the parameters of â€œacceptanceâ€ under section 2518, the applicable treasury regulation 
  provides:

A qualified disclaimer cannot be made with respect to an 
  interest in property if the disclaimant has accepted the interest or any of 
  its benefits, expressly or impliedly, prior to making the disclaimer. Acceptance 
  is manifested by an affirmative act which is consistent with ownership of the 
  interest in property. Acts indicative of acceptance include using the property 
  or the interest in property; accepting dividends, interest, or rents from the 
  property; and directing others to act with respect to the property or interest 
  in property. However, merely taking delivery of an instrument of title, without 
  more, does not constitute acceptance.

26 C.F.R. Â§ 25.2518-2(d)(1) (2003).Â  When determining whether 
  a disclaimant has accepted the property, we do not look to a single act or declaration, 
  but rather the court must examine the disclaimantâ€™s conduct in toto.Â  See 
  80 Am. Jur. 2d Wills Â§ 1364 (2002) (noting â€œacceptance of a devise or 
  bequest need not be express but may be shown by the acts or conduct of the beneficiaryâ€ 
  and â€œacceptance . . . occurs if the party with the expectancy interest exercises 
  dominion and control over the property in the capacity of a beneficiaryâ€).Â  
  A beneficiary of property in an estate will not be deemed to have accepted the 
  property as long she â€œleaves the disputed property in the possession of the 
  estate and does not unreasonably disrupt the orderly and timely distribution 
  of the estate assets.â€Â  In re Estate of Watkins, 572 So. 2d 1014, 1015 
  (Fla. App. 1991); see also Jordan v. Trower, 208 Ga. App. 
  552, 553, 431 S.E.2d 160, 162 (1993) (finding that a will beneficiaryâ€™s acceptance 
  of approximately $460 from an estate prior to filing of a will for probate, 
  for beneficiaryâ€™s use in purchasing clothing for funeral and other expenses, 
  did not constitute type of acceptance or possession of property of estate that 
  would preclude her from timely renouncing her interest; beneficiary did not 
  obtain, nor even seek, possession of property of estate as a whole and undertook 
  no actions that would indicate an intention to assert an ownership interest 
  in the property of the estate); Niklason v. Ramsey, 233 Va. 161, 164, 
  353 S.E.2d 783, 784 (1987) (holding that a beneficiaryâ€™s contract to divide 
  his motherâ€™s estate prior to execution of disclaimer operated as dominion and 
  control over the estate, thereby precluding disclaimer).
In this case, Hall points to his testimony that Alice Sims, 
  Sr., had â€œtaken possessionâ€ of Georgia Simsâ€™ house after her death because she 
  â€œhad the house cleaned upâ€ and she â€œsold the furniture out of the house.â€ Â Â Without 
  more, this conduct does not evidence such dominion and control as to have precluded 
  Alice Sims, Sr., or the personal representative of her estate from making a 
  valid disclaimer.
Important to this determination is the fact that 
  both Alice Sims, Sr., prior to her death, and Alice Sims, Jr., served as personal 
  representatives of Georgia Simsâ€™ estate, qualifying them as fiduciaries of the 
  estate.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-703(a) (1987).Â  As fiduciaries, the 
  Treasury Regulation defining acceptance under section 2518 provides that their 
  actions â€œto preserve or maintain the disclaimed property shall not be treated 
  as an acceptance of such property or any of its benefits.Â  Under this rule, 
  for example, an executor who is also a beneficiary may direct the harvesting 
  of a crop or the general maintenance of a home.â€Â  
  26 C.F.R. Â§ 25.2518-2(d)(2) (emphasis added).Â  Alice Sims, Sr., therefore, did 
  not prejudice her right to execute a qualified disclaimer by acting to preserve 
  her late daughterâ€™s estate.
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Alice Sims, Sr., did not direct the 
  disposition of Georgia Simsâ€™ estate.
Under 26 U.S.C.A. Â§ 2518(b)(4), a disclaimer 
  is valid only if the interest being refused â€œpasses without any direction on 
  the part of the person making the disclaimer.â€Â  Hall claims that prior to her 
  death, Alice Sims, Sr. â€œplanned and directedâ€ Georgia Simsâ€™ estate go directly 
  to Alice Sims, Jr., thereby precluding her from effecting a valid disclaimer.Â  
  We disagree.
As a threshold matter, this question is 
  not preserved for appellate review because the trial court did not rule upon 
  this issue and Hall did not raise the issue in his post-trial Motion to Modify 
  or Amend Order.Â  For the same reasons cited regarding preservation of the prior 
  issue, this question is not properly before this court.Â  Again, however, even 
  if we reach the merits, we would affirm the trial courtâ€™s judgment. 
The applicable Treasury Regulation has interpreted the requirement 
  that the interest pass without direction by the disclaimant as meaning: â€œIf 
  there is an express or implied agreement that the disclaimed interest in property 
  is to be given or bequeathed to a person specified by the disclaimant, the disclaimant 
  shall be treated as directing the transfer of the property interest.â€Â  26 C.F.R. 
  Â§ 25.2518-2(e)(1).
As evidence that Alice Sims, Sr., had such an agreement 
  prior to disclaimer to dispose of Georgia Simsâ€™ estate, Hall cites the trial 
  testimony of Alice Sims, Jr.: 

[W]e [Alice Sims, Sr., and Alice Sims, Jr.] both felt that 
  Georgiaâ€™s estate should come directly to me. At the time I had been told by 
  Mr. Hall that I was co-heir with my . . . mother.Â  And I said, well, then I 
  want, we want mamaâ€™s portion, mamaâ€™s half to come directly to me.

This statement does not evidence an agreement between 
  Alice Sims Jr., and her mother to â€œdirectâ€ the transfer of Georgia Simsâ€™ property 
  as contemplated under section 2518.Â  To the contrary, this testimony reveals 
  nothing more than Alice Sims, Jr., and Alice Sims, Sr., simply inquiring with 
  their attorney about the possibility of disclaimer.Â  Hall asks this court to 
  find that Alice Sims, Sr.â€”by saying that she wanted to disclaim her interestâ€”is 
  barred from making such a disclaimer because she directed the transfer of the 
  property.Â  This argument strains credulity.Â  If this procedure was followed, 
  lawyers advising clients on matters of estate administration would be unable 
  to engage their clients in meaningful conversations about their wishes for the 
  distribution of property for fear of foregoing disclaimer and other similar 
  options.Â  We decline to adopt this approach.
CONCLUSION
The trial court did not err in ruling 
  Respondent had established the proper standard of care in this case and Hall 
  breached that duty, proximately resulting in substantial, additional taxable 
  assets accruing to Alice Sims, Sr.â€™s estate.Â  Concomitantly, the judgment of 
  the Master is
 AFFIRMED.
BEATTY, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
    [1]    We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
     
    [2] Â Â  Prior to trial, there was a dispute among the parties concerning 
    the date on which a â€œtransferâ€ occurs under section 2518.Â  Hall contended 
    the â€œtransferâ€ of Georgia Simsâ€™ property to Alice Sims, Sr., did not occur 
    until the date the deed of distribution transferred title.Â  Alice Sims, Jr., 
    claimed the transfer occurred on the date Georgia Sims died.Â  In ruling on 
    Hallâ€™s motion for summary judgment, the circuit court found that the date 
    of transfer, for the purposes of transfer by intestacy, was the date of Georgia 
    Simsâ€™ death.Â  
  Hall did not appeal the courtâ€™s summary judgment order and later conceded at 
    trial that, to be effective, disclaimer of Georgia Simsâ€™ property must have 
    occurred within nine months after her death.Â  Unappealed rulings become the 
    law of the case and should not be reconsidered by this court.Â  ML-Lee Acquisition 
    Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 241, 489 S.E.2d 470, 
    472 (1997); Toyota of Florence, Inc., v. Lynch, 314 S.C. 257, 266, 
    442 S.E.2d 611, 616 (1994).Â  Accordingly, this Court will not rule on the 
    legal question as to the date on which the transfer occurred under section 
    2518.Â  In the present appeal, the date of transfer will be the date of Georgia 
    Simsâ€™ death.

 
   
     
    [3]    In the Appellantâ€™s â€œStatement of Issues on Appeal,â€ he lists as an 
    issue whether â€œthe trial court err[ed] in finding the Respondent had proven 
    damages in the amount of $191,453.00.â€Â  In the body of the brief, however, 
    this issue is not discussed.Â  Our stateâ€™s appellate courts have consistently 
    held that issues raised on appeal but not argued in the brief will not be 
    considered by the court.Â  See, e.g, Jinks v. Richland County, 
    355 S.C. 341, ___, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 (2003) (holding the court will not 
    consider issues raised on appeal but not argued in the body of the brief); 
    Fields v. Melrose Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 312 S.C. 102, 106, 439 S.E.2d 283, 285 
    (Ct. App. 1993) (finding that â€œ[a]lthough the [appellants] raise this alternative 
    holding in their statement of the issues on appeal, they fail to argue it 
    in their brief.Â  An issue raised on appeal but not argued in the brief is 
    deemed abandoned and will not be considered by the appellate court.â€).

 
   
     
    [4]    See supra fn. 2 (explaining Hallâ€™s earlier motion for 
    summary judgment and the trial courtâ€™s disposition).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Edward D. Sloan, Jr., individually, and as a Citizen, Resident, Taxpayer 
        and Registered Elector of Greenville County, and on behalf of all others 
        similarly situated,        Appellant/Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Greenville County, a Political Subdivision of the State of South Carolina, 
        Dozier Brooks, Scott Case, C. Wade Cleveland, Bob Cook, Joseph Dill, Lottie 
        Gibson, Allen â€œBunkâ€ Johnson, Mark C. Kingsbury, Xanthene Norris, Stephen 
        Selby, and Dana Sullivan, Paul B. Wickensimer in their official capacity 
        as Greenville County Council Members,       
Respondents/Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3704
Heard November 5, 2003 â€“ Filed December 
  8, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jennifer J. Miller and James G. Carpenter, of Greenville, for Appellant-Respondent.
Boyd B. Nicholson, Jr. and Thomas H. Coker, Jr., of Greenville, for Respondents-Appellants.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Edward D. Sloan, Jr., individually, 
  and as a citizen, resident, taxpayer and registered elector of Greenville County, 
  and on behalf of all others similarly situated, brought this action against 
  Greenville County alleging it failed to comply with county ordinances governing 
  the procurement of construction services when it awarded contracts for the completion 
  of three public works projects.Â  The trial court ruled the procurement processes 
  met the statutory standard with respect to two of these projects, while the 
  third project did not.Â  Both Sloan and the County appeal.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The Greenville County Code (â€œG.C.C.â€ or 
  â€œthe Codeâ€) prescribes the methods the County may use to award contracts for 
  construction services.Â  As a general rule, the code requires that all contracts 
  must be awarded by the â€œcompetitive sealed biddingâ€ method.Â  G.C.C. Â§ 7-212.Â  
  This method of source selection proceeds in multiple stages.Â  The County must 
  first hire an architect or other design professional to prepare the initial 
  plans and specifications for the new construction project.Â  After the County 
  has approved these initial plans, the design professional will typically draft 
  a detailed set of construction drawings and specifications that will become 
  part of a â€œbid package.â€Â  The County will then use the bid package to publicly 
  solicit bids from contractors to perform the work.Â  The lowest responsible, 
  responsive bidder is awarded the project.
Under the Code, the County must use the 
  competitive sealed bidding method to procure construction services over $15,000 
  unless one of several specific exceptions applies.Â  See G.C.C. Â§Â§ 7-212 
  â€“ 7-242.5.Â  One of these exceptionsâ€”the focal point of this caseâ€”is known as 
  the â€œdesign-buildâ€ procurement method. 
  [1] Â  See Â§ 7-242.5. 
The design-build method differs from traditional 
  competitive sealed bidding in two important ways.Â  First, under the design-build 
  method, the County enters into a single contract for design and construction 
  of the project.Â  This arrangement condenses the two-step process of competitive 
  sealed bidding in which the County procures design services and then contracts 
  separately for the actual construction.Â  Design-buildâ€™s single source procurement 
  also enables design and construction to proceed concurrently, thereby shortening 
  project duration.Â  Once a design â€œfootprintâ€ for a structure has been prepared, 
  a contractor may begin work such as grading and excavating a site, while a designer 
  continues to design the structure.
Second, the design-build method allows comparative 
  subjective evaluations to be made when determining acceptable proposals for 
  negotiation and award of the contract.Â  Price need not be the sole or primary 
  criterion for evaluating competing proposalsâ€”it may be only one of several factors 
  considered.Â  The County may select the design-build team based on other factors 
  such as experience, project team members, and expertise.
It is design-buildâ€™s lack of objective, bright-line 
  criteria that raises concerns about its use.Â  Critics espouse that design-build 
  vests too much discretion with the governing body regarding when and to whom 
  public contracts are awarded.Â  Because price is not a controlling factor in 
  design-build source selection, the public entity may not always receive the 
  lowest, most competitive price possible.Â  See e.g., Sloan v. 
  Sch. Dist. of Greenville County, 342 S.C. 515, 521, 537 S.E.2d 299, 302 
  (Ct. App. 2000) (opining that â€œ[t]his court has long maintained that â€˜[m]unicipal 
  competitive bidding laws are enacted to guard against such evils as favoritism, 
  fraud or corruption in the award of contracts, to secure the best product at 
  the lowest priceâ€™â€).Â  Without proper guidelines and oversight, design-build 
  may foster the impression that the government is somehow less accountable for 
  its decisions as to how it spends taxpayer money.
For these reasons, the use of design-build is limited 
  under the Code to those situations in which it is properly justified.Â  Greenville 
  Countyâ€™s design-build ordinance sets out when it may be used:

The county administrator or his designee shall have the discretion to use construction 
  management services, design-build services, or turnkey management services as 
  alternatives for construction contracting administration.Â  In exercising such 
  discretion, the county administrator or his designee shall consider the method 
  which is the most advantageous to the county and will result in the most timely, 
  economical, and successful completion of the construction project.Â  The determination 
  for the method of source selection utilized shall be stated in writing and included 
  as part of the contract file.

G.C.C. Â§ 7-242.5(a). Â The Countyâ€™s discretion 
  to use design-build instead of competitive sealed bidding source selection is 
  therefore limited to those occasions when it is in the best interests of the 
  Countyâ€”a determination that must be in writing and available for public consumption 
  in the contract file.
At issue before us is whether Greenville 
  County properly justified its decision to use the design-build method to award 
  three multi-million dollar construction contracts.Â  Specifically, we must decide 
  whether the written determinations were sufficient under section 7-242.5 of 
  the Code.
The Construction Projects
The contracts 
  for the three construction projects were awarded in 1999 and 2000.Â  Construction 
  services for all three were obtained using the design-build method. 
Two of these contracts were for road-building projects 
  that were part of a special infrastructure improvement program called the â€œPrescription 
  for Progressâ€ plan.Â  This plan, approved by Greenville County Council in 1997, 
  called for the expenditure of eighteen million dollars for the repair and resurfacing 
  of approximately 148 lane miles on more than 400 county roads through the year 
  2010.Â  The two projects at issue are Prescription for Progress road improvement 
  programs for years 2000 and 2001 (hereinafter referred to as the â€œRoads 2000â€ 
  and â€œRoads 2001â€ projects).Â  For the Roads 2000 project, the County procured 
  $6,759,100 of road construction services. Â In the Roads 2001 project, 
  the County obtained $12 million in road construction services.
The third construction contract was for the renovation 
  of the criminal forensics lab at the Countyâ€™s law enforcement center in 1999.Â  
  The County procured $290,000 in construction services to complete this project.
This Action
After each of these contracts was awarded, 
  Sloan brought suit seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, contending the 
  procurements violated the Code.Â  The primary issueâ€”common to all three casesâ€”was 
  the validity of the Countyâ€™s determination to use design-build source selection 
  rather than competitive sealed bidding in awarding the contracts.Â  As additional 
  causes of action, Sloan asserted the County did not obtain sufficient performance 
  and payment bonds for the Roads 2000 project, and he claimed the Forensics Lab 
  contract did not properly define the responsibilities and rights of the parties, 
  both in violation of the Greenville County Code.Â  In answering Sloanâ€™s charges, 
  the County asserted the cases were not justiciable because Sloan did not have 
  standing to challenge the Countyâ€™s actions and the questions presented were 
  moot, preventing the court from awarding any effective relief. 
The trial court consolidated the three cases for 
  trial. Â The court decided these actions were properly justiciableâ€”ruling that 
  Sloan had standing to bring suit and the case was not subject to dismissal for 
  mootness.Â  With respect to the validity of the written determinations to use 
  design-build source selection, the court deemed the determinations for the Roads 
  2000 and Roads 2001 projects were sufficient under the Code.Â  It pronounced, 
  however, the written determination for the Forensics Lab project did not satisfy 
  the Codeâ€™s requirements.Â  As to the other claims asserted: The court adjudged 
  the County had failed to obtain sufficient bonds for the Roads 2000 project.Â  
  It found the Forensics Lab contract sufficiently defined the rights and duties 
  of the parties.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The County contends this court should apply an â€œany 
  evidenceâ€ standard of review rather than a â€œpreponderance of the evidenceâ€ standard.Â  
  We disagree.
In actions at law, on appeal of a case tried without 
  a jury, the lower court must be affirmed where there is any evidence which reasonably 
  supports the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Strickland v. Prudential Ins. Co. of Am., 
  278 S.C. 82, 85, 292 S.E.2d 301, 303 (1982); Townes Assocs., LTD. v. City 
  of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976); Campbell 
  v. Marion County Hosp. Dist., 354 S.C. 274, 280, 580 S.E.2d 163, 165 (Ct. 
  App. 2003).Â  In an action in equity, however, the appellate court may â€œfind 
  facts in accordance with its views of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Townes 
  Assocs., 266 S.C. at 86, 221 S.E.2d at 775; Kiriakides v. Atlas Food 
  Sys. & Serv., 338 S.C. 572, 581, 527 S.E.2d 371, 376 (Ct. App. 2000).
â€œA suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal 
  nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.â€Â  Doe 
  v. South Carolina Med. Malpractice Liab. Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n, 347 S.C. 
  642, 645, 557 S.E.2d 670, 672 (2001); Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 
  354, 355, 400 S.E.2d 781, 781 (1991); Travelers Indem. Co. v. Auto World 
  of Orangeburg, 334 S.C. 137, 140, 511 S.E.2d 692, 694 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
  The fact that Sloan seeks equitable relief does not, however, require the case 
  be treated as an equitable action in toto.Â  Rather, we must look to the â€œmain 
  purposeâ€ of the suit to determine its characterization.Â  William v. Wilson, 
  349 S.C. 336, 340, 563 S.E.2d 320, 322 (2002); Ins. Fin. Servs., Inc. v. 
  South Carolina Ins. Co., 271 S.C. 289, 293, 247 S.E.2d 315, 318 (1978); 
  see also Floyd v. Floyd, 306 S.C. 376, 380, 412 S.E.2d 397, 399 
  (1991) (â€œAs we interpret the â€˜main purposeâ€™ rule, its primary function is to 
  administratively categorize an action in which parties seek both equitable relief 
  and legal redress.â€); Alford v. Martin, 176 S.C. 207, 212, 180 S.E. 13, 
  15 (1935) (â€œThe character of an action is determined by the complaint in its 
  main purpose and broad outlines and not merely by allegations that are merely 
  incidental.â€).Â  The main purpose of the action is generally discerned from the 
  body of the complaint.Â  Ins. Fin. Servs., at 293, 247 S.E.2d at 318; 
  see also Natâ€™l Bank of South Carolina v. Daniels, 283 S.C. 438, 
  440, 322 S.E.2d 689, 690 (Ct. App. 1984) (noting that whether an action is legal 
  or equitable â€œmust be determined from the character of the action as framed 
  in the complaintâ€).Â  â€œHowever, if necessary, resort may be had to the prayer 
  for relief and any other facts and circumstances which throw light upon the 
  main purpose of the action.â€ Id.; see also Doe v. South Carolina 
  Med. Malpractice Liab. Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n, 347 S.C. 642, 645, 557 
  S.E.2d 670, 672 (2001) (finding the main purpose of an action was equitable 
  in nature where both injunctive relief and money damages were sought, but plaintiff 
  offered no proof of damages at trial and no damages were awarded by the court); 
  Bramlett v. Young, 229 S.C. 519, 534-35, 93 S.E.2d 873, 881 (1956) (examining 
  the substance of the pleadings throughout the case and the evidence introduced 
  at trial in its determination whether the action sounded in law or equity).
Although the County asserts the main purpose of 
  this action is to construe a written contract, it seems clear that Sloanâ€™s main 
  concern is to enjoin the County from awarding contracts in a manner he claims 
  is ultra vires under the Countyâ€™s procurement code.Â  Sloan brought 
  this action as a citizen and taxpayer of Greenville County, not as a private 
  individual seeking redress under the terms of a particular contract.Â  In his 
  complaint, Sloan only requested a declaration that the contracts were illegal 
  and should be set aside.Â  At trial, the testimony introduced concerned only 
  the sufficiency of the Countyâ€™s determination that design-build was the proper 
  method of source selection for the construction projects.Â  Sloan did not pray 
  for damages in his pleadings, and the court awarded none.Â  Indeed, by the time 
  the case reached trial, the projects at issue had already been completed.Â  The 
  gravamen of the action, therefore, is merely to prevent the County from awarding 
  future public works contracts in the manner employed in the present case.
A case with legal and equitable issues presents 
  a divided scope of review.Â  Perry v. Heirs at Law & Distributees of Gadsden, 
  313 S.C. 296, 437 S.E.2d 174 (Ct. App. 1993), affâ€™d as modified, 316 
  S.C. 224, 449 S.E.2d 250 (1994).Â  When legal and equitable actions are maintained 
  in one suit, each retains its own identity as legal or equitable for purposes 
  of the applicable standard of review on appeal.Â  Corley v. Ott, 326 S.C. 
  89, 485 S.E.2d 97 (1997); Future Group, II v. Nationsbank, 324 S.C. 89, 
  478 S.E.2d 45 (1996); Kuznik v. Bees Ferry Assocs., 342 S.C. 579, 538 
  S.E.2d 15 (Ct. App. 2000), cert. granted July 3, 2001.Â  A legal question 
  in an equity case receives review as in law.Â  Gunter v. Fallaw, 78 S.C. 
  457, 59 S.E. 70 (1907); Garvin v. Garvin, 55 S.C. 360, 33 S.E. 458 (1899).Â Â  
  Even if a case is tried in equity if it is actually a law case, the appellate 
  court will apply the scope of review in law cases.Â  Brooks v. Cent. Baptist 
  Church, 185 S.C. 200, 193 S.E. 326 (1937).
This action is appropriately characterized as equitable 
  and should be reviewed under the â€œpreponderance of the evidenceâ€ standard.Â  
  Our broad scope of review, however, does not require this court to disregard 
  the findings of the trial judge who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a 
  better position to judge their credibility.Â  See Pinckney v. Warren, 
  344 S.C. 382, 544 S.E.2d 620 (2001); Ingram v. Kaseyâ€™s Assocs., 340 S.C. 
  98, 105, 531 S.E.2d 287, 291 (2000); Greer v. Spartanburg Technical Coll., 
  338 S.C. 76, 79, 524 S.E.2d 856, 858 (Ct. App. 1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Justiciability of Sloanâ€™s Claims
 We first examine whether Sloanâ€™s causes of action 
  were properly justiciable.Â  The County challenges Sloanâ€™s standing to bring 
  suit and asserts the issues raised present no actual controversy and are therefore 
  moot.Â  We address each seriatim.
Before any action can be maintained, a justiciable controversy 
  must be present.Â  Byrd v. Irmo High School, 321 S.C. 426, 430, 468 S.E.2d 
  861, 864 (1996).Â  A justiciable controversy is a real and substantial controversy 
  appropriate for judicial determination, as opposed to a dispute or difference 
  of a contingent, hypothetical or abstract character.Â  Waters v. South Carolina 
  Land Res. Conservation Commâ€™n, 321 S.C. 219, 227, 467 S.E.2d 913, 917-18 
  (1996); S. Bank & Trust Co. v. Harrison Sales Co., Inc., 285 S.C. 
  50, 51, 328 S.E.2d 66, 67 (1985); Charleston County Sch. Dist. v. Thomas, 
  277 S.C. 145, 146, 283 S.E.2d 441, 442 (1981); see also Graham v. 
  State Farm Mut. Auto Ins. Co., 319 S.C. 69, 71, 459 S.E.2d 844, 845 (1995) 
  (â€œA justiciable controversy exists when a concrete issue is present, there is 
  a definite assertion of legal rights and a positive legal duty which is denied 
  by the adverse party.â€).Â  The concept of justiciability encompasses the doctrines 
  of ripeness, mootness, and standing.Â  Holden v. Cribb, 349 S.C. 132, 
  137, 561 S.E.2d 634, 637 (Ct. App. 2002).

A.Â Â Â Â Â  Standing

The County argues the trial court erred in holding 
  Sloan had standing to challenge the Countyâ€™s award of the contracts.Â  We disagree.
A plaintiff must have standing to institute 
  an action.Â  Joytime Distribs. & Amusement Co., Inc. v. State, 338 
  S.C. 634, 639, 528 S.E.2d 647, 649 (1999).Â  â€œTo have standing, one must have 
  a personal stake in the subject matter of the lawsuit.â€ Sea Pines Assâ€™n for 
  the Prot. of Wildlife, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Res., 345 
  S.C. 594, 600, 550 S.E.2d 287, 291 (2001); Evins v. Richland County Historic 
  Pres. Commâ€™n, 341 S.C. 15, 21, 532 S.E.2d 876, 879 (2000); Newman v. 
  Richland County Historic Pres. Commâ€™n, 325 S.C. 79, ___, 480 S.E.2d 72, 
  74 (1997).Â  â€œTo have standing . . . one must be a real party in interest.Â  A 
  real party in interest is one who has a real, material, or substantial interest 
  in the subject matter of the action, as opposed to one who has only a nominal 
  or technical interest in the action.â€Â  Charleston County Sch. Dist. v. Charleston 
  County Election Commâ€™n, 336 S.C. 174, 181, 519 S.E.2d 567, 571 (1999) (quoting 
  Anchor Point, Inc. v. Shoals Sewer Co., 308 S.C. 422, 428, 418 S.E.2d 
  546, 549 (1992)); see also Henry v. Horry County, 334 S.C. 461, 
  463 n.1, 514 S.E.2d 122, 123 n.1 (1999) (â€œTo have standing, one must be a real 
  party in interest.â€); Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 530, 
  229 S.E.2d 718, 718 (1999).Â  Our supreme court has consistently held: 

A private individual may not 
  invoke the judicial power to determine the validity of an executive or legislative 
  act unless the private individual can show that, as a result of that action, 
  a direct injury has been sustained, or that there is immediate danger a direct 
  injury will be sustained.

Joytime Distribs., 338 S.C. at 639, 528 S.E.2d 
  at 649-50; see also Evins, 341 S.C. at 21, 532 S.E.2d at 879; 
  Citizens for Lee County, Inc. v. Lee County, 308 S.C. 23, 29, 416 S.E.2d 
  641, 645 (1992); Blandon v. Coleman, 285 S.C. 472, 475, 330 S.E.2d 298, 
  299 (1985); Florence Morning News v. Bldg. Commâ€™n, 265 S.C. 389, 398, 
  218 S.E.2d 881, 884-85 (1975); Carolina Alliance for Fair Employment v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation, 337 S.C. 476, 486, 
  523 S.E.2d 795, 800 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œMoreover, the injury must be of a personal 
  nature to the party bringing the action, not merely of a general nature which 
  is common to all members of the public.â€Â  Joytime Distribs., 338 S.C. 
  at 639-40, 528 S.E.2d at 650; see also Quality Towing, Inc. v. City 
  of Myrtle Beach, 340 S.C. 29, 34, 530 S.E.2d 369, 371 (2000); Baird, 
  333 S.C. at 530, 511 S.E.2d at 75.
â€œ[T]he rule [of standing] is not an inflexible 
  one.â€Â  Thompson v. South Carolina Commâ€™n on Alcohol & Drug Abuse, 
  267 S.C. 463, 467, 229 S.E.2d 718, 719 (1976).Â  Standing may be conferred upon 
  a party â€œwhen an issue is of such public importance as to require its resolution 
  for future guidance.â€Â  Baird, 333 S.C. at 531, 511 S.E.2d at 75; Carolina 
  Alliance, 337 S.C. at 488, 523 S.E.2d at 801; see also Charleston 
  County Parents for Pub. Sch., Inc. v. Moseley, 343 S.C. 509, 513, 541 S.E.2d 
  533, 535 (2001) (noting that an action to determine whether a school district 
  could impose a tax levy was an issue of public importance sufficient to confer 
  standing); Thompson v. South Carolina Commâ€™n on Alcohol & Drug Abuse, 
  267 S.C. 463, 467, 229 S.E.2d 718, 719 (1976) (holding the plaintiffs had 
  standing because the questions involved were of such wide concern, both to law 
  enforcement personnel and to the public); Berry v. Zahler, 220 S.C. 86, 
  89, 66 S.E.2d 459, 461 (1951) (holding the question of public interest originally 
  encompassed in an action should be decided for future guidance).

The general rule is that a taxpayer may not maintain 
  a suit to enjoin the action of State officers when he has no special interest 
  and his only standing is the exceedingly small interest of a general taxpayer.Â  
  This doctrine is founded upon the salutary public policy of limiting the judicial 
  process to real controversies between the parties to the proceeding.Â  The mere 
  fact that the issue is one of public importance does not confer upon any citizen 
  or taxpayer the right to invoke per se a judicial determination of the issue.

Crews v. Beattie, 197 S.C. 32, 49, 14 S.E.2d 
  351, 357-58 (1941).Â  For a plaintiff to have taxpayer standing, the party must 
  â€œdemonstrate some overriding public purpose or concern to confer standing to 
  sue on behalf of her fellow taxpayers.â€Â  Beaufort County v. Trask, 349 
  S.C. 522, 529, 563 S.E.2d 660, 664 (Ct. App. 2002).
A party seeking to establish standing 
  must prove the â€œirreducible constitutional minimum of standing,â€ which consists 
  of three elements:Â  (1) the plaintiff must have suffered an injury in fact; 
  (2) the injury and the conduct complained of must be causally connected; and 
  (3) it must be likely, rather than merely speculative, that the injury will 
  be redressed by a favorable decision.Â  Sea Pines Assâ€™n, 345 S.C. at 601, 
  550 S.E.2d at 291 (quoting Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 
  112 S.Ct. 2130, 119 L.Ed.2d 351 (1992)); see also Beaufort Realty 
  Co., Inc. v. Beaufort County, 346 S.C. 298, 551 S.E.2d 588 (Ct. App. 2001) 
  (â€œThe United States Supreme Court has established the following requirements 
  to show standing: (1) the plaintiff must suffer an "injury in fact" 
  that is (a) concrete and particularized and (b) actual or imminent, not conjectural 
  or hypothetical; (2) the injury is fairly traceable to the challenged action 
  of the defendant; and (3) it is likely, as opposed to merely speculative, that 
  the injury will be redressed by a favorable decision.â€).
The present case is analogous to this 
  courtâ€™s decision in Sloan v. School District of Greenville County, 342 
  S.C. 515, 537 S.E.2d 299 (Ct. App. 2000), in which the court examined taxpayer 
  standing on largely similar facts.Â  In Sloan, the plaintiff brought an 
  action against the school district seeking a declaratory judgment that the district 
  violated its procurement regulations by entering into construction contracts 
  without following the prescribed competitive sealed bidding procedure.Â  Id. 
  at 517-18, 537 S.E.2d at 300.Â  The contracts at issue had been awarded under 
  an exception which allowed the district to award contracts without competitive 
  sealed bidding when there was an emergency need for the procurement of construction 
  and other services.Â  Id. at 517, 537 S.E.2d at 300.Â  The plaintiff challenged 
  the districtâ€™s determination that the procurement without competitive sealed 
  bidding was justified under this exception.Â  Id. at 518, 537 S.E.2d at 
  300.Â  As in the case sub judice, the plaintiff had no private interest 
  in the contracts and had not submitted a bid for the construction work.Â  Id.
The court first held the plaintiff had 
  standing to sue as an individual taxpayer, finding the plaintiff, as a taxpaying 
  citizen of Greenville County, had â€œa direct interest in the proper use and allocation 
  of tax receipts by the District.â€ Id. at 522, 537 S.E.2d at 303.Â  The 
  court grounded its reasoning on the rationale articulated by our supreme court 
  in Mauldin v. City Council of Greenville, 33 S.C. 1, 11 S.E. 434 (1890), 
  a case challenging the governmentâ€™s expenditure of public funds.Â  There, the 
  court held: 

The injury charged as the result 
  of the acts complained of is a private injury, in which the tax-payers of the 
  county . . . are the individual sufferers, rather than the public.Â  The people 
  out of the county bear no part of the burden; nor do the people within the county, 
  except the tax-payers, bear any part of it.Â  It is therefore an injury peculiar

B.Â Â Â Â Â  Mootness

  533, 291 S.E.2d 195 (1982)); see also Charleston County Sch. Dist.

  344, 346, 195 S.E.2d 713, 715 (1973)).Â  â€œThe function of appellate courts is

  â€œ[w]hen a construction contract is awarded in excess of twenty-five thousand 
  dollars ($25,000.00)â€ a â€œperformance bondâ€ and a â€œpayment bondâ€ â€œshall be delivered 
  to the county and shall become binding on the parties upon the execution of 
  the contract.â€Â  Each of these bonds â€œshall be in an amount equal to one hundred 
  (100) percent of the price specified in the contract.â€Â  G.C.C. Â§ 7-238.
The total amount of compensation agreed 
  upon under the contract for the Roads 2000 project was $6,759,100.Â  The County, 
  however, obtained a bond for only $4,666,000, the amount listed as the â€œtotal 
  construction budgetâ€ in an exhibit attached to the contract. Â The additional 
  $2,093,100 covered the costs for engineering ($816,900), â€œquality assuranceâ€ 
  ($201,200), and â€œprogram managementâ€ ($1,075,000).
The County asserts the â€œprice specified 
  in the contractâ€ under section 7-238 need not include items in the contract 
  other than the actual, direct costs of construction.Â  We find this argument 
  is in error.
We look first to the language of the Code 
  provision.Â  The words of a statute or regulation â€œmust be given their plain 
  and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit 
  or expand its operation.â€ Â Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 
  S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992); accord Durham v. United 
  Cos. Fin. Corp., 331 S.C. 600, 604, 503 S.E.2d 465, 468 (1998); Adkins 
  v. Comcar Indus., Inc., 323 S.C. 409, 411, 475 S.E.2d 762, 763 (1996).Â  
  â€œThe language must also be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject 
  matter and accords with its general purpose.â€Â  Hitachi Data Sys., 309 
  S.C. at 178, 420 S.E.2d at 846 (citations omitted). Â A statute should be given 
  a reasonable and practical construction consistent with the purpose and policy 
  expressed in the statute.Â  Davis v. NationsCredit Fin. Servs. Corp., 
  326 S.C. 83, 484 S.E.2d 471 (1997); Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, Inc. v. 
  County of Aiken, 354 S.C. 18, 22, 579 S.E.2d 334, 336 (Ct. App. 2003); Stephen 
  v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  If a 
  statuteâ€™s language is plain, unambiguous, and conveys a clear meaning â€œthe rules 
  of statutory interpretation are not needed and the court has no right to impose 
  another meaning.â€Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 
  581 (2000); Paschal v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 454 S.E.2d 
  890 (1995); Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, 354 S.C. at 24, 579 S.E.2d at 
  337.Â  
By its plain meaning, section 7-238 affords 
  the County no discretion to deliver payment and performance bonds for any amount 
  less than the amount specified in the contract.Â  There is no limiting language 
  which would indicate the provision was intended to apply only to the portion 
  of the contract price specifically related to the cost of construction.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The Countyâ€™s procurement code is remedial in nature, 
  and its provisions should be construed liberally to carry out its purposes.Â  
  See South Carolina Depâ€™t of Mental Health v. Hanna, 270 S.C. 210, 
  213, 241 S.E.2d 563, 564 (1978) (â€œA remedial statute should be liberally construed 
  in order to effectuate its purpose.â€); Spencer v. Barnwell County Hosp., 
  314 S.C. 405, 408, 444 S.E.2d 538, 540 (Ct. App. 1994) (â€œIn considering a remedial 
  act designed to protect a class of persons or the public at large, the courts 
  liberally construe the act to carry out its purposes.â€).Â  Because the express 
  purpose of the procurement code is to ensure the â€œefficient and economical use 
  of revenuesâ€ provided by the taxpayers (Â§ 7-192), the bonding requirements of 
  section 7-238 should be read to afford the greatest protection to the citizens 
  of Greenville County.
We are bolstered in our reading of section 
  7-238 by evidence presented at trial regarding the general industry practice 
  concerning the delivery of performance and payment bonds.Â  Included in the record 
  before the court is an industry publication, Design-Build RFQ/RFP Guide for 
  Public Sector Projects.Â  Under the heading â€œContract Bond Must Include Design,â€ 
  this guide instructs the government procurer to:

Indicate to the proposers that 
  the contract bond (performance and payment bond) must cover the entire contract 
  between the owner and the design-builder, including any and all necessary professional 
  architectural and engineering services.Â  The bond must not be limited to construction 
  value and associated risks.

Expert testimony was also presented which confirms 
  that the general practice in the field of public procurement is to obtain bonds 
  for the full amount of the contract price, inclusive of design and other non-construction 
  cost items.
We conclude the language of section 
  7-238, supported by evidence regarding industry practice, clearly requires the 
  delivery of performance and payment bonds for the full amount of the contract 
  price, not simply the contract costs for construction alone.Â  The trial court, 
  therefore, correctly ruled the Roads 2000 project was not properly bonded. 
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Sufficiency of Forensics Lab Contract
Sloan argues the Forensics Lab contract fails to 
  comply with section 7-240(a) of the County Code because the County failed to 
  append the contract with a project scope, payment schedule, or project schedule.Â  
  We disagree.
Section 7-240 provides: â€œAll contracts for . . 
  . construction shall include provisions necessary to define the responsibilities 
  and rights of the parties to the contract.â€Â  Based on our review of the contract, 
  we find this standard was met.Â  Although no additional documents were attached 
  to the original contract further defining the project scope, payment schedule, 
  or project schedule, the contract was sufficiently definite to â€œdefine the responsibilities 
  and rights of the parties to the contract.â€
With respect to the project scope, construction 
  drawings were developed for the project, reflecting in substantial detail the 
  project scope contemplated by the design-build team.Â  The contract also incorporated 
  by reference the Request for Proposal criteria used to solicit design-build 
  team proposals, providing a further indication of the planned project scope.
The contract also contains sufficient details regarding 
  compensation and terms of payment.Â  Article 3.1 provides that the price of the 
  contract shall not exceed $290,000.Â  Additionally, Article 4.1 addresses the 
  terms of paymentâ€”outlining in substantial detail when the contractor is required 
  to submit payments each month and the timeframe in which the County must make 
  payments.
Finally, while the contract does not provide a 
  comprehensive project schedule, it does contain a 120-day completion schedule. 
  Â We conclude, therefore, that the contract is sufficiently definite to 
  â€œdefine the responsibilities and rights of the parties.â€ 
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court 
  ruled correctly with respect to all of the issues presented:Â  The case was properly 
  justiciable.Â  The written determinations to use design-build source selection 
  for the Roads 2000 and Roads 2001 projects were sufficient under the Code, while 
  the determination prepared for the Forensics Lab project was not.Â  The trial 
  court did not err by admitting witness testimony regarding the written determinations.Â  
  The County did not obtain sufficient performance and payment bonds for the Roads 
  2000 project.Â  Finally, the trial court correctly found the Forensics Lab contract 
  was sufficient under the Code.Â  Accordingly, the rulings of the trial court 
  are
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and CONNOR, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Professionals in the field of public procurement variously refer 
    to this method of source selection as â€œdesign-build,â€ â€œcompetitive sealed 
    proposal,â€ or â€œrequest for proposal.â€Â  Though these terms are generally interchangeable, 
    for ease of reference, we will refer exclusively to â€œdesign-buildâ€ when discussing 
    this alternative to traditional competitive sealed bidding procurement.

description: In this condemnation action, SCDOT appeals the trial court's ruling that the landowner was entitled to litigation expenses as the prevailing party.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Transportation,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jan R. Thompson, f/k/a Jan R. Hardee,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3705
Submitted October 6, 2003 â€“ Filed December 
  8, 2003 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
B. Michael Brackett, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Howell V. Bellamy, Jr. and Robert S. Shelton, both of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Jan R. Thompson brought this 
  action seeking compensation for property condemned by the South Carolina Department 
  of Transportation (SCDOT).Â  Thompson received a jury award of $38,000.Â  The 
  trial court awarded Thompson attorneyâ€™s fees and costs pursuant to S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 28-2-510(B) (1991), finding she was the prevailing party as required 
  by the statute.Â  SCDOT appeals.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
SCDOT condemned a portion of Thompsonâ€™s 
  property in Horry County in order to construct the Conway Bypass.Â  Prior to 
  the condemnation, Thompson owned 10.04 acres.Â  As a result of the condemnation 
  of 3.35 acres, Thompsonâ€™s land was split into two tracts totaling 6.69 acres.Â  

At trial, SCDOT presented testimony that 
  the value of the condemned land was only $6,821.Â  That value was much less than 
  the value given by Thompsonâ€™s appraiser, who testified the property was worth 
  $33,500.Â  Thompson testified that she believed the property was worth $8,000 
  per acre and that the remaining 6.69 acres were damaged by either 50 or 60 per 
  cent.Â  The highest resulting compensation would therefore be $58,912. 
  [2] Â  
During cross-examination, SCDOTâ€™s counsel 
  asked Thompson about a statement in her deposition regarding the value of the 
  property.Â  Thompson admitted that during her deposition testimony she had stated 
  the property was worth $15,000 to $20,000 per acre, instead of the $8,000 she 
  testified to at trial.Â  This would have produced a high valuation of $147,280, 
  using $20,000 per acre and additionally assuming the damage to the remainder 
  of the land was 60 per cent.
At trial, however, Thompson asserted that 
  the value was only $8,000 per acre.Â  She explained, â€œItâ€™s Eight Thousand, because 
  at that time I was really upset . . . about the taking of my land, and the way 
  it was left, and Iâ€™ve had time to think about it, and Iâ€™ve gone back down and 
  looked at it a lot more, and I think, to be fair and reasonable, Eight Thousand 
  is better.â€Â  
After the jury returned a verdict for 
  Thompson for $38,000 in total compensation, the trial court found she was the 
  prevailing party and awarded her litigation expenses of $13,159.36.Â  The court 
  reasoned the verdict was closer to Thompsonâ€™s value attested to at trial of 
  $8,000 per acre (plus the damage to the remainder at 50 to 60 per cent) than 
  SCDOTâ€™s highest valuation of $6,821 in total compensation.Â  Moreover, the court 
  found Thompson had expressly disavowed the value she had placed on the property 
  in her deposition testimony; therefore, it was not the highest value attested 
  to at trial by Thompson.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Value in Deposition Testimony
SCDOT contends the trial court erred in 
  finding Thompson was entitled to litigation expenses as the prevailing party.Â  
  Specifically, SCDOT maintains the highest value attested to by Thompson was 
  the amount stated in her deposition, $15,000 to $20,000 per acre, which would 
  have given a high valuation of $147,280, thus making SCDOTâ€™s valuation of $6,821 
  closer to the actual jury verdict of $38,000. [3] Â  We disagree.
 After a condemnation action is concluded, 
  the landowner may petition for litigation expenses pursuant to section 28-2-510(B)(1), 
  which provides:Â  â€œA landowner who prevails in the trial of a condemnation action, 
  in addition to his compensation for the property, may recover his reasonable 
  litigation expenses . . . .â€ [4] Â  
The statute defines â€œprevailsâ€ as follows:

For the purpose of this section, â€œprevailsâ€ means that the 
  compensation awarded (other than by settlement) for the property, exclusive 
  of interest, is at least as close to the highest valuation of the property that 
  is attested to at trial on behalf of the landowner as it is to the highest 
  valuation of the property that is attested to at trial on behalf of the 
  condemnor. [5] 

The South Carolina Supreme Court has further defined 
  the meaning of â€œprevailsâ€ in the case of City of Folly Beach v. Atlantic 
  House Properties, Ltd., stating â€œa landowner â€˜prevailsâ€™ if the difference 
  between the value he offers at trial and the compensation awarded him is less 
  than or equal to the difference between the value the condemnor offers at trial 
  and the compensation awarded landowner.â€ [6] 
The central issue in this case turns on 
  whether the value placed on the property in Thompsonâ€™s deposition was ever â€œattested 
  to at trialâ€ by Thompson.Â  We conclude the higher value of $15,000 to $20,000 
  per acre was not â€œattested to at trialâ€ on behalf of the landowner as required 
  by the statute.
SCDOT offered the testimony regarding 
  the $15,000 to $20,000 per acre valuation in an attempt to discredit the testimony 
  of Thompson.Â  Thompson did not offer the deposition testimony as a reasonable 
  value for compensation for the condemned property.Â  Thompson unequivocally and 
  expressly testified that the value she was utilizing at trial was $8,000 per 
  acre and that the value she testified to in her deposition was not accurate 
  and was the result of her emotions.Â  Based upon the wording of the statute, 
  we hold Thompson only attested to the $8,000 per acre value at trial and that 
  is the amount to be used in determining whether she was the prevailing party 
  so as to entitle her to litigation expenses. 
II.Â  Reference to Value in Closing 
  Argument
SCDOT further contends that Thompsonâ€™s attorney 
  used the higher valuation in his closing argument and therefore it should be 
  used in determining whether Thompson was the prevailing party. 
  [7] Â  We disagree.
Arguments made by counsel are not evidence. 
  [8] Â  Additionally, the statements clearly do not constitute an attestation 
  at trial as required by the statute.Â  Thus, this issue provides no basis for 
  reversing the award of litigation expenses to Thompson. 
  [9] 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2] Â  This sum is calculated as follows:Â  (3.35 condemned acres x $8,000 
    per acre) + (6.69 remaining acres x 60 per cent damage x $8,000 per acre).

 
   
    [3] Â  In the order awarding Thompson litigation expenses as the prevailing 
    party, the trial court incorrectly stated the highest value attested to at 
    trial by Thompson was $48,192 instead of $58,912.Â  Even when the correct figure 
    is used, however, the juryâ€™s verdict was closer to the value testified to 
    by Thompson than the value asserted by SCDOT. 

 
   [4] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 28-2-510(B)(1) (1991).

 
   
    [5] Â  Id. Â§ 28-2-510(B)(2) (emphasis added).Â  

 
   [6] Â  321 S.C. 241, 243, 467 S.E.2d 928, 929 (1996).

 
   
    [7] Â  In closing argument, SCDOTâ€™s counsel specifically brought up Thompsonâ€™s 
    prior deposition testimony in an attempt to discredit her property valuation 
    at trial.Â  In response to this argument, Thompsonâ€™s attorney again asserted 
    that Thompson was not asking for that amount, but argued if the jury wanted 
    to send a message to SCDOT about fairness, they could give her what opposing 
    counsel was stating.Â  

 
   
    [8] Â  McManus v. Bank of Greenwood, 171 S.C. 84, 89, 171 S.E. 473, 
    475 (1933) (â€œThis court has repeatedly held that statements of fact appearing 
    only in argument of counsel will not be considered.â€); see also Sessions 
    v. Withers, 327 S.C. 409, 488 S.E.2d 888 (Ct. App. 1997); Gilmore v. 
    Ivey, 290 S.C. 53, 348 S.E.2d 180 (Ct. App. 1986).

 
   
    [9] Â  Cf. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp. v. Richardson, 
    335 S.C. 278, 516 S.E.2d 3 (Ct. App. 1999) (rejecting a partyâ€™s assertion 
    that his own attorneyâ€™s statements to the court and to the jury constituted 
    the value attested to at trial for purposes of section 28-2-510(B)).
