THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
James C. Thornton, M.D.,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Trident Medical Center, L.L.C., d/b/a Trident Medical Center,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3706
Heard November 4, 2003 â€“ Filed December 
  8, 2003

REVERSED


  
    
      
Allan Shackelford, of Greensboro; and James L. Gale, 
  of Raleigh, for Appellant.
G. Dana Sinkler, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Trident Medical Center (Trident) appeals the circuit 
  courtâ€™s finding that the agreement between Trident and James C. Thornton does 
  not involve interstate commerce and, therefore, is not subject to the Federal 
  Arbitration Act, 9 U.S.C. Â§ 2 (1999).Â  We reverse.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In 1999, Trident was suffering from a shortage of qualified physicians in its 
  cardiovascular surgery group, South Carolina Cardiovascular Associates (â€œSCCAâ€).Â  
  To alleviate this shortage, Trident began an effort to recruit physicians from 
  other parts of the country to join SCCA.Â  To entice physicians to move to Charleston, 
  Trident offered substantial financial incentives that would not only cover the 
  expenses of relocation but would provide bonuses and a guaranteed income stream 
  for a period of time after their arrival.
Dr. James Thornton (Thornton) was one of the physicians Trident was able to 
  attract to Charleston.Â  In May 1999, Thornton and Trident entered into a â€œrecruiting 
  agreementâ€ in which Thornton agreed to relocate his medical practice as a cardiovascular 
  surgeon from Grand Rapids, Michigan to Charleston.Â  In addition to the principal 
  agreement under which Thornton agreed to relocate to Charleston and maintain 
  his practice there for at least four years, the recruiting agreement contained 
  four addenda: (1) a net collectable revenue guarantee which provided Thornton 
  with a guaranteed income for twenty-four months; (2) a signing bonus; (3) a 
  relocation agreement for payment of moving expenses; and (4) an agreement providing 
  that Thornton was being recruited into the existing practice of SCCA.
Payment of all the financial incentives to Thornton under this agreement was 
  contingent upon Thornton maintaining his practice in Charleston for at least 
  four years.Â  If he failed to do so, the payments made to Thornton under the 
  agreement had to be repaid to Trident.Â  Further, the agreement read: â€œIn the 
  event any dispute shall arise concerning any aspect of this Agreement, such 
  dispute shall be submitted to final and binding arbitration in accordance with 
  rules established by the American Arbitration Association.â€
Thornton moved to Charleston and joined SCCA in August 1999.Â  However, he left 
  the practice and relocated to Pennsylvania before the end of his four-year commitment.Â  
  Thornton claimed he was excused from his obligations under the recruiting agreement 
  and refused to repay any of the financial incentives he had received from Trident.
Thornton brought the present declaratory judgment action seeking a determination 
  that the arbitration provision contained in the recruiting agreement was unenforceable.Â  
  The trial court found the provision (1) did not satisfy the requirements set 
  out in Â§ 15-48-10 of the South Carolina Uniform Arbitration Act, and (2) was 
  not enforceable under Â§ 2 of the Federal Arbitration Act (â€œFAAâ€), because the 
  transaction between the parties did not involve interstate commerce.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Determinations of arbitrability are subject to de novo review.Â  Stokes v. 
  Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 351 S.C. 606, 571 S.E.2d 711 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
  Nevertheless, a circuit courtâ€™s factual findings will not be reversed on appeal 
  if there is any evidence reasonably supporting the findings.Â  McMillan v. 
  Gold Kist, Inc., 353 S.C. 353, 577 S.E.2d 482 (Ct. App. 2003); Evans 
  v. Accent Manufactured Homes, Inc., 352 S.C. 544, 575 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 
  2003); Liberty Builders, Inc. v. Horton, 336 S.C. 658, 521 S.E.2d 749 
  (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The question of the arbitrability of a claim is an issue for 
  judicial determination, unless the parties provide otherwise.Â  Zabinski v. 
  Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 553 S.E.2d 110 (2001); Evans, 
  352 S.C. at 549, 575 S.E.2d at 76; see also Vestry and Church Wardens 
  v. Orkin Exterminating Co., Op. No. 3679 (S.C. Ct. App. filed September 
  22, 2003) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 35 at 53) (whether claim is subject to arbitration 
  is issue for judicial determination, unless parties have agreed otherwise).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The parties do not dispute the trial courtâ€™s finding that the arbitration clause 
  contained in the recruiting agreement is unenforceable under the South Carolina 
  Uniform Arbitration Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-48-10 to -240 (Supp. 2002).Â  If, 
  however, the agreement involves interstate commerce, the FAA applies and trumps 
  the state arbitration laws.Â  See Doctorâ€™s Assocs., Inc. v. Casarotto, 
  517 U.S. 681 (1996); Soil Remediation Co. v. Nu-Way Envtl., Inc., 323 
  S.C. 454, 476 S.E.2d 149 (1996).
The FAA provides: â€œA written provision in any maritime transaction or a contract 
  evidencing a transaction involving commerce to settle by arbitration a controversy 
  thereafter arising out of such contract . . . shall be valid, irrevocable, and 
  enforceable, save upon such grounds as exist at law or in equity for the revocation 
  of any contract.â€Â  9 U.S.C. Â§ 2.Â  The words â€œinvolving commerceâ€ have been interpreted 
  by the United States Supreme Court as being the functional equivalent of â€œaffecting 
  commerceâ€â€”words signaling â€œan intent to exercise Congressâ€™ commerce power to 
  the full.â€Â  Allied-Bruce Terminix Cos. v. Dobson, 513 U.S. 265, 277 (1995); 
  see also Citizens Bank v. Alafabco, Inc., 123 S. Ct. 2037, 2040 
  (2003) (â€œWe have interpreted the term â€˜involving commerceâ€™ in the FAA as the 
  functional equivalent of the more familiar term â€˜affecting commerceâ€™â€”words of 
  art that ordinarily signal the broadest permissible exercise of Congressâ€™ Commerce 
  Clause power.â€); Blanton v. Stathos, 351 S.C. 534, 540, 570 S.E.2d 565, 
  568 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œThe United States Supreme Court has held that the phrase 
  â€˜involving commerceâ€™ is the same as â€˜affecting commerce,â€™ which has been broadly 
  interpreted to mean Congress intended to utilize its powers to regulate interstate 
  commerce to its full extent.â€).Â  â€œBecause the statute provides for the enforcement 
  of arbitration agreements within the full reach of the Commerce Clause, it is 
  perfectly clear that the FAA encompasses a wider range of transactions than 
  those actually in commerceâ€”that is, within the flow of interstate commerce.â€Â  
  Citizens Bank, 123 S. Ct. at 2040 (internal quotation marks and citations 
  omitted).
Thornton claims the recruiting agreement does not evidence interstate commerce 
  and, consequently, the FAA does not apply.Â  We disagree.
In all cases, determination of whether a transaction involves interstate commerce 
  depends on the facts of the case.Â  Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 
  346 S.C. 580, 594, 553 S.E.2d 110, 117 (2001) (â€œTo ascertain whether a transaction 
  involves commerce within the meaning of the FAA, the court must examine the 
  agreement, the complaint, and the surrounding facts.â€).Â  Thornton argues the 
  recruiting agreement did not involve interstate commerce because it only concerned 
  the performance of his duties as a physician providing medical services within 
  South Carolina.
Thornton is correct in urging this Court to focus upon what the terms of the 
  contract specifically require for performance in determining whether interstate 
  commerce is involved.Â  Our courts consistently look to the essential character 
  of the contract when applying the FAA.
In Mathews v. Fluor Corp., our Supreme Court found interstate commerce 
  was not involved in a contract for the sale of land in South Carolina to out-of-state 
  partiesâ€”even though, incident to the sale, the parties obtained the services 
  of a North Carolina engineer and financing from a Pennsylvania lender.Â  Mathews 
  v. Fluor Corp., 312 S.C. 404, 440 S.E.2d 880 (1994), overruled by 
  Munoz v. Green Tree Fin. Corp., 343 S.C. 531, 542 S.E.2d 360 (2001) (overruling 
  Mathews â€œto the extent it considered whether the parties contemplated 
  interstate commerce as a factor in determining if the FAA applied.â€).Â  The Court 
  held the transaction was outside the scope of the FAA because it was â€œunable 
  to discern from the evidence presented whether the contract required 
  respondent to administer anything related to interstate commerce.â€Â  Mathews, 
  312 S.C. at 407, 440 S.E.2d at 882 (emphasis in original).Â  See also 
  Munoz v. Green Tree Fin. Corp., 343 S.C. 531, 542 S.E.2d 360 (2001) (finding 
  interstate commerce involved in a construction contract where builder was domiciled 
  in South Carolina, but, under the contract, assigned rights to a Delaware creditor); 
  Soil Remediation Co. v. Nu-Way Envtl., Inc., 323 S.C. 454, 476 S.E.2d 
  149 (1996) (holding interstate commerce involved in contract requiring removal 
  of water and sludge from property in South Carolina to a facility in North Carolina); 
  Timms v. Greene, 310 S.C. 469, 427 S.E.2d 642 (1993) (stating that a 
  contract between a nursing home and patient did not involve interstate commerce, 
  despite the fact that the nursing home was a division of a Delaware partnership, 
  marketed its services to persons residing outside of the state, and purchased 
  the majority of its supplies and equipment from out-of-state; the Court reasoned 
  that the performance of the contractâ€”the provision of patient-resident services 
  in South Carolinaâ€”did not require any activities in interstate commerce); Episcopal 
  Hous. Corp. v. Federal Ins. Co., 269 S.C. 631, 640, 239 S.E.2d 647, 652 
  (1977) (concluding performance required under a contract for the construction 
  of an eighteen-story building involved interstate commerce because â€œ[i]t would 
  be virtually impossible to constructâ€ such a building â€œwith materials, equipment 
  and supplies all produced and manufactured solely within the State of South 
  Carolina.â€); Blanton v. Stathos, 351 S.C. 534, 541, 570 S.E.2d 565, 569 
  (Ct. App. 2002) (determining that a contract for design and architectural services 
  in the construction of a restaurant in South Carolina involved interstate commerce 
  because â€œâ€˜the contract not only contemplated the use of materials manufactured 
  outside the state of South Carolina, but realistically the project could not 
  be constructed without the use of materials in interstate commerce.â€™â€).
In the present case, performance of the recruiting agreement requires activity 
  involving interstate commerce.Â  Contrary to Thorntonâ€™s assertions, the subject 
  matter of the contract clearly extends beyond Thorntonâ€™s obligation to provide 
  medical services in South Carolina.Â  Thornton was recruited and agreed to move 
  from one state to another.Â  An essential requirement for performance under the 
  agreement was Thorntonâ€™s relocation from Michigan to South Carolina within a 
  fixed period of time.Â  Thornton was a resident of Michigan at the time the contract 
  was entered.Â  The contract recites that Thornton will be compensated for expenses 
  incurred in moving his personal effects and household furnishings to South Carolina.Â  
  Thornton accepted money to defray the cost of the move and agreed to repay these 
  relocation expenses if he failed to maintain his practice in Charleston for 
  four years.Â  The contract terms provided for Tridentâ€™s payment of money to induce 
  the relocation and Thorntonâ€™s promise to repay the money should he fail to perform 
  fully under the contract.Â  By the terms of the recruiting agreement, Thornton 
  was obligated to relocate his practice from Michigan to South Carolina.Â  Trident, 
  in turn, was obligated to reimburse Thornton for expenses incurred in the transfer 
  of his practice across state lines.Â  After Thorntonâ€™s relocation to South Carolina, 
  he was then bound by the terms of the agreement to remain in the state as a 
  practicing physician for at least four years, effectively preventing him from 
  working in any other state during that time.Â  The contract was denominated as 
  and was intended as a recruiting agreement to induce Thorntonâ€™s move across 
  state lines.Â  The express purpose of the recruiting agreement was to provide 
  a monetary incentive, consisting of multiple related promises, to induce Thornton 
  to relocate his professional medical services practice from Michigan to South 
  Carolina.
Thornton contends the present case is analogous to and controlled by the United 
  States Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in Bernhardt v. Polygraphic Co., 350 
  U.S. 198 (1956).Â  We disagree.Â  First, we note that Bernhardt was decided 
  over forty-five years ago.Â  The law of arbitrability was nascent in 1956 and 
  has evolved and maturated extant.Â  Moreover, Bernhardt differs factually 
  from the instant case.Â  In Bernhardt, plaintiff sought to invoke the 
  arbitration act with respect to an employment contract entered into in New York, 
  but which was to be performed in Vermont.Â  Id. at 199.Â  The Court held 
  that the FAA did not apply because the contract did not evidence â€œâ€˜a transaction 
  involving commerce.â€™â€Â  Id. at 200.Â  The Courtâ€™s finding was based upon 
  the absence of any proof demonstrating that plaintiff â€œwhile performing his 
  duties under the employment contract was working â€˜inâ€™ commerce, was producing 
  goods for commerce, or was engaging in activity that affected commerce.â€Â  Id. 
  at 201.
Unlike the recruiting agreement 
  in the case sub judice, the agreement in Bernhardt did 
  not contemplate any actions affecting commerce outside of Vermont.Â  Performance 
  under the contract in Bernhardt wasâ€”by its termsâ€”confined to a single 
  state.
The case of Selma 
  Med. Ctr., Inc. v. Fontenot, 824 So. 2d 668 (Ala. 2001), is instructive.Â  
  The contract at issue in Selma (1) required two physicians to relocate 
  their medical practices from one state to another; (2) provided guaranteed gross 
  receipts or income for a certain period of time after relocation, with the stipulation 
  that if the net collectible revenue exceeded $500,000 during that period, the 
  physicians would repay the hospital the difference; (3) provided for payment 
  of certain sums to assist in relocation expenses and start-up costs; and (4) 
  contained a provision requiring arbitration in accordance with the rules of 
  the American Arbitration Association.Â  The similitude of the contract in Selma 
  and the contract in the present case is striking.
A dispute arose when 
  the hospital claimed, but the physicians disputed, that the physicians owed 
  the hospital excess revenue collected during the guarantee period.Â  Concordant 
  with Thornton, the Alabama physicians challenged the arbitration agreement and 
  attempted to have the court disregard the clear interstate aspect of the agreement 
  and concentrate solely on medical services to be provided in-state.Â  South Carolina 
  and Alabama each have a statute that places certain requirements on arbitration 
  agreements if they are to be enforced.Â  Thus, like the case at bar, if the FAA 
  applied, Alabamaâ€™s statutory requirement for arbitration agreements would be 
  preempted.
In determining that the arbitration 
  provisions contained within the physician recruitment agreements were governed 
  by the FAA, the Selma court cited the three categories of activity that 
  Congress can regulate pursuant to the Commerce Clause, namely: â€œ(1) the use 
  of the channels of interstate commerce; (2) the instrumentalities of interstate 
  commerce or persons or things in interstate commerce; and (3) those activities 
  having a substantial effect on interstate commerce.â€Â  Id. at 674 (emphasis 
  in original).Â  The court concluded that, in the context of the physician recruitment 
  agreement at issue in Selma, interstate commerce was involved because 
  â€œthe actual persons and things involved are themselves within the flow of commerce.â€Â  
  Id. at 674 (internal quotations omitted).Â  The court explained:

The Physicians entered the flow of interstate commerce when they moved from 
  South Carolina to Alabama.Â  In fact, the sole purpose of the Agreements was 
  to place the Physicians within the current of commerce and to move them to Alabama 
  . . . . Accordingly, when the Physicians moved across state lines, they became 
  â€œpersons . . . in interstate commerce.â€Â  As part of the flow of commerce, then, 
  the Physicians were properly subject to congressional regulation.
The flow of commerce begins before, and ends after, the actual movement across 
  State lines, in order to fulfill the purpose of the overall transaction. . . 
  . .
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
The Agreements required the Physicians to move themselves and their medical 
  practices from South Carolina to Selma, Alabama, to provide anesthesia services 
  to patients in the Selma community.Â  Thus, the agreements were themselves an 
  integral part of the Physiciansâ€™ movement in the flow of commerce, subjecting 
  their personal-service contracts to the jurisdiction of the FAA.

Id. at 675 (citations omitted).
Having determined the 
  physicians were part of the flow of interstate commerce, the Selma court 
  did not need to decide whether the physician recruitment agreements substantially 
  affected commerce.Â  â€œWhen a case involves allegations of the use of the instrumentalities 
  of interstate commerce, or persons or things in interstate commerce, a court 
  need not reach the question whether the underlying transaction â€˜substantially 
  affectsâ€™ interstate commerce, because such persons and things, by definition, 
  substantially affectâ€”because they are components ofâ€”interstate commerce.â€Â  Id. 
  at 674 (internal quotations omitted).
The Selma courtâ€™s 
  logic and analysis apply equally here and are in full accord with South Carolina 
  case law.Â  Irrefutably, there is a substantial impact on interstate commerce: 
  (1) money was paid and is now owed as a result of recruiting across state lines; 
  (2) factually, the record is replete with movement across state lines; and (3) 
  negotiation, bargaining, and completion of an agreement was within the rubric 
  of interstate commerce.Â  The reach of the FAA, as explicated by the Commerce 
  Clause, encapsulates the Trident-Thornton contract.
CONCLUSION
We conclude the recruiting agreement entered into 
  between Thornton and Trident involved interstate commerce.Â  Concomitantly, the 
  FAA governs the agreement in this case and compels arbitration.Â  Accordingly, 
  the order of the trial court is
 REVERSED.
GOOLSBY and CONNOR, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Williamsburg Rural Water and Sewer Company, Inc.,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Williamsburg County Water and Sewer Authority, a Body Politic, County 
        of Williamsburg, A Body Politic, and Town of Kingstree, a Body Politic,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3707
Heard June 11, 2003 â€“ Filed December 
  8, 2003Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Larry G. Reddeck, of Lake City; for Appellant.
Ernest J. Jarrett, W.E. Jenkinson, 
  III, and Jennifer R. Kellahan, all of Kingstree; for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  The central issue 
  in this case is whether a countyâ€™s constructive approval of a water and sewer 
  service proposal submitted by a non-profit corporation under former S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 33-35-90 grants the non-profit corporation exclusive service rights such 
  that the county may not give franchise rights to competing providers within 
  the same service areas designated in the proposal.Â  Williamsburg Rural Water 
  and Sewer Company, Inc. (Williamsburg Water) commenced this action against Williamsburg 
  County, Williamsburg County Water and Sewer Authority, and the Town of Kingstree 
  (collectively, the County) [1]  
  seeking: (1) a determination that Williamsburg Water possessed an exclusive 
  right to provide water and sewer service within designated unincorporated areas 
  in Williamsburg County, (2) damages in tort based on the Countyâ€™s interference 
  with that right, and (3) injunctive relief.Â  The circuit court granted summary 
  judgment to the County, finding that Williamsburg Water did not possess an exclusive 
  service right and that Williamsburg Waterâ€™s cause of action in tort was barred 
  by the South Carolina Tort Claims Act and the statute of limitations.Â  Williamsburg 
  Water appeals. We affirm.
FACTS/ PROCEDURAL HISTORY
The relevant facts of this 
  case are largely undisputed and are gathered from a timeline of events to which 
  the parties stipulated.Â  On January 16, 1995, W.N. Kellahan, an organizer of 
  Williamsburg Water, sent a letter to Elwood Gerald, the Countyâ€™s director of 
  rural and community development, notifying the County of Williamsburg Waterâ€™s 
  intention to provide service to certain unincorporated areas of Williamsburg 
  County pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-35-90 (1990).  
  [2]  Â Â Section 33-35-90 sets forth the statutory mechanism for a non-profit 
  corporation to provide water and sewer services within the geographical areas 
  designated in its articles of incorporation, provided the corporation notifies 
  the county of the nature of the services to be provided and receives the countyâ€™s 
  consent.
In March and again in April of 1995, Kellahan appeared 
  before the Williamsburg County Council on behalf of Williamsburg Water to reiterate 
  Williamsburg Waterâ€™s intent to provide services to the designated areas.Â  Kellahan 
  sent a copy of Williamsburg Waterâ€™s master plan to the council and to Gerald.Â  
  In May of 1995, Williamsburg Water filed its articles of incorporation with 
  the Secretary of State.Â  Shortly thereafter, Williamsburg Water began applying 
  for loans and federal grants to fund its operation.
During this same time period, the county council began 
  considering enacting an ordinance that would allow the County to expand its 
  own water and sewer services into the same unincorporated areas that Williamsburg 
  Water intended to service.Â  The proposed ordinance allowed the County to grant 
  franchises to organizations that submitted applications to the County seeking 
  permission to provide service within these same areas.
The first of three public readings of 
  the proposed franchise ordinance was held on March 6, 1995.Â  On August 7 of 
  that year, the ordinance was adopted.Â  In May of 1998, the County applied for 
  federal funding to construct its water system.Â  On November 3, 1998, the County 
  solicited bids for water and sewer services to the Industrial Park area, which 
  is located within the service area designated in Williamsburg Waterâ€™s proposal.Â  
  The County awarded the bid to Tom Brigman Contractorâ€™s, Inc., of Newberry, on 
  November 9, 1998. 
In response, Williamsburg Water commenced 
  this action against the County on December 4, 1998, claiming that Williamsburg 
  Water possessed an exclusive right to provide services to the unincorporated 
  areas specified in its proposal, including the area where the Industrial Park 
  was located. In essence, Williamsburg Water claimed that its proposal was approved 
  by the County by virtue of the Countyâ€™s failure to notify Williamsburg Water 
  to the contrary in accordance with section 33-35-90. Williamsburg Water further 
  claimed the County intentionally interfered with and/or threatened to interfere 
  with Williamsburg Waterâ€™s ability to obtain federal funding and to provide service 
  within the designated areas.Â  The complaint alleged that as a result of the 
  Countyâ€™s grossly negligent actions, Williamsburg Water suffered injury and damages.Â  
  Finally, Williamsburg Water sought a declaration that it was exempt from the 
  Countyâ€™s franchise ordinance and that it possessed an exclusive right to service 
  the unincorporated areas designated in its proposal. 
Â Williamsburg Water and the County filed cross 
  motions for summary judgment.Â  The circuit court granted summary judgment to 
  the County on Williamsburg Waterâ€™s first cause of action, ruling that Williamsburg 
  Water had the right, but not the exclusive right, to provide water and sewer 
  service to the designated areas.Â  The circuit court also granted summary judgment 
  to the County on Williamsburg Waterâ€™s action in tort, finding the County was 
  immune from liability under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act and that the 
  statute of limitations had run.Â  However, the circuit court found there was 
  a genuine issue of material fact as to whether Williamsburg Water was exempt 
  from the Countyâ€™s franchise ordinance.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate 
  court applies the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 
  56(c), SCRCP.â€Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567, S.E.2d 857, 
  860 (2002).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, 
  answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, 
  if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that 
  the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), 
  SCRCP.Â  Once the party moving for summary judgment meets the initial burden 
  of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the non-moving 
  party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue 
  for trial.Â  Id.; SSI Med. Servs., Inc. v. Cox, 301 S.C. 493, 497, 
  392 S.E.2d 789, 792 (1990).Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issue of fact 
  exists, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom 
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Worsley 
  Cos.Â  v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 339 S.C. 51, 55, 528 S.E.2d 657, 659 (2000).Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Exclusive Service 
  Rights
The circuit court found that the notices contained in Williamsburg 
  Waterâ€™s proposal dated January 16, 1995, were both proper and adequate to comply 
  with section 33-35-90.Â  Moreover, the circuit court held Williamsburg Water 
  possessed the right, but not the exclusive right, to provide service within 
  the disputed area.Â  The County did not appeal either of these findings; therefore, 
  it is the law of this case that Williamsburg Water possesses a right to provide 
  water and sewer services in Williamsburg County.Â  See Bakala v. Bakala, 
  352 S.C. 612, 576 S.E.2d 156 (2003); Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing 
  Corp., 338 S.E. 171, 525 S.E.2d 869 (2000) (stating an unappealed ruling 
  is the law of the case). The question before this court is whether that right 
  is an exclusive service right, such that the County is prohibited from awarding 
  franchises within the areas identified in Williamsburg Waterâ€™s proposal.Â  
The circuit courtâ€™s order does not indicate the basis for 
  its finding that Williamsburg Water possesses a right to provide service in 
  the county.Â  We presume the circuit court found this right to be the product 
  of the Countyâ€™s failure to comply with the mandatory notice provisions of section 
  33-35-90, for there is no other explanation in the order for the creation of 
  this right.Â  It is the law of this case that Williamsburg Water possesses a 
  right of some degree; thus, determining the source of that right is not necessary 
  to its existence.Â  However, we believe it is necessary for a complete understanding 
  of the controversy in this case to briefly set forth our view regarding the 
  Countyâ€™s failure to comply with section 33-35-90, which must be the foundation 
  for the circuit courtâ€™s ruling.
Section 33-35-90 (1990) stated in relevant part:

[P]rior to providing any of the services authorized in this 
  section, nonprofit corporations or groups intending to organize such corporations 
  shall first notify the governing body, of the county or municipality in which 
  the services are to be provided, of their intentions and the nature of such 
  services.Â  The governing body shall, from the date of such notification, 
  have a period of ninety days in which to approve the request to provide such 
  services or inform the persons requesting permission to provide such services 
  that the governing body intends to provide for such matters as a public function 
  of government.Â  Any such notification of intent by the governing body shall 
  include a detailed description of the area to be served, the services to be 
  provided and the time schedule under which such services will be available from 
  the county or municipality.

(Emphasis added).
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain 
  and effectuate the legislative intent whenever possible.â€ Strother v. Lexington 
  County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 62, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  
  â€œUnless there is something in a statute requiring a different interpretation, 
  the words used in the statute must be given their ordinary meaning.â€Â  Mullinax 
  v. J.M. Brown Amusement Co., 326 S.C. 453, 458, 485 S.E.2d 103, 106 (Ct. 
  App. 1997).Â  â€œThe language must also be read in a sense which harmonizes with 
  its subject matter and accords with its general purpose.â€Â  Hitachi Data Sys. 
  Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â  â€œStatutes, 
  as a whole, must receive practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation, consonant 
  with the purpose, design, and policy of lawmakers.â€Â  TNS Mills, Inc. v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 624, 503 S.E.2d 471, 478 (1998).Â  

Section 33-35-90 unambiguously required the County to respond 
  to Williamsburg Waterâ€™s proposal within ninety days of its receipt.Â  The statute 
  further required the County to inform Williamsburg Water of its intention to 
  provide such services and to give a detailed description of any area it wished 
  to serve, as well as a time schedule for the availability of such services.Â  
  Although the first reading of the proposed ordinance occurred within ninety 
  days of Williamsburg Waterâ€™s application, there is no evidence the reading of 
  the ordinance notified Williamsburg Water that the County had rejected its proposal 
  or that it described with detail the area it wished to service, the nature of 
  services to be provided, and the time schedule for the availability of such 
  services.Â  Section 33-35-90 mandates that â€œanyâ€ such notification by the County 
  â€œshallâ€ include such information. It is irrelevant that representatives of Williamsburg 
  Water attended the reading of the proposed ordinance because the reading did 
  not satisfy the requirements of the statute.Â  The County, therefore, failed 
  to comply with section 33-35-90.Â  
Unlike current section 33-36-270, 
  [3]  the former statute does not specifically state that a governing bodyâ€™s 
  failure to respond to a non-profit corporationâ€™s proposal serves as an acceptance 
  of the corporationâ€™s proposal.Â  However, we believe the use of affirmative language 
  stating that the County â€œshall . . . have a period of ninety daysâ€ in 
  which to respond imposes an obligation upon the County to take action in accordance 
  with the statute.Â  See Horry County v. City of Myrtle Beach, 288 
  S.C. 412, 419, 343 S.E.2d 36, 39 (Ct. App. 1986) (stating the words â€œshallâ€ 
  and â€œmustâ€ are generally regarded as making a provision mandatory).Â  Considering 
  its overall purpose and the mandatory terms chosen by the legislature, we believe 
  the only logical construction of section 33-35-90 is that the Countyâ€™s failure 
  to respond within the ninety-day time limit constitutes approval of Williamsburg 
  Waterâ€™s proposal. [4] Â  
We turn now to address the extent of the service rights acquired 
  by Williamsburg Water as a result of the Countyâ€™s implicit approval of the proposal.Â  
  Williamsburg Water argues its right to provide water and sewer services is exclusive; 
  therefore, the County was prohibited from awarding franchises within the proposed 
  service area.Â  The County disagrees, contending that Section 15 of Article VIII 
  of the South Carolina Constitution safeguards the Countyâ€™s right to choose whomever 
  it desires to provide such services to its citizens.Â  
Section 15 of Article VIII states in pertinent part:

 [N]or shall any law be passed by the 
  General Assembly granting the right to construct and operate in a public 
  street or on public property a street or other railway, or to erect waterworks 
  for public use, or to lay water or sewer mains for any purpose, or to use the 
  streets for any facility other than telephone, telegraph, gas, and electric, 
  without first obtaining the consent of the governing body of the county 
  . . . . 

(Emphasis added).
Section 15 of Article VIII of the South Carolina 
  Constitution prohibits the legislature from passing a law which grants the right 
  to lay water or sewer mains without first obtaining a countyâ€™s consent.Â  See 
  City of Aiken v. Aiken Elec. Co-op., Inc., 305 S.C. 466, 468, 409 S.E.2d 
  403, 404 (1991).Â  However, section 15 conveys only a veto power; it is not a 
  franchising mechanism.Â  See City of Abbeville v. Aiken Elec. Co-op., 
  Inc., 287 S.C. 361, 368, 338 S.E.2d 831, 835 (1985) (â€œThe consent provision 
  of Â§ 15 is not an affirmative grant of franchise power, but is a restriction 
  on legislative authority.â€) (Emphasis in original). Therefore, prior to receiving 
  the Countyâ€™s consent, Williamsburg Water was prohibited from entering into any 
  area of the county because Section 15 of Article VIII acted as a shield barring 
  any such intrusion without the Countyâ€™s approval.Â  In this case, the Countyâ€™s 
  constructive consent simply removed this constitutional shield; it did not, 
  however, convert a previously non-existent right into a right that is exclusive 
  against all others, including the County.Â  Nothing in section 33-35-90 or case 
  law of this state suggests such an extensive interpretation.Â  
The cases in South Carolina that have addressed conflicts 
  between rural service providers and governmental bodies give little guidance 
  under the facts of this case.Â  Both parties directed this courtâ€™s attention 
  to the line of cases involving annexation, including City of Aiken and 
  City of Abbeville, as well as City of Rock Hill v. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n 
  of S.C., 308 S.C. 175, 417 S.E.2d 562 (1992), South Carolina Electric 
  & Gas Co. v. Berkeley Elec. Co-op., Inc., 306 S.C. 228, 411 S.E.2d 218 
  (1991), Berkeley Elec. Co-op., Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 304 S.C. 
  15, 402 S.E.2d 674 (1991), and Blue Ridge Elec. Co-op., Inc. v. City of Seneca, 
  297 S.C. 283, 376 S.E.2d 514 (1989).
In this line of cases, the common facts involved a 
  municipalityâ€™s annexation of land which was within an area that the Public Service 
  Commission had assigned to a rural service provider. An irreconcilable conflict 
  developed between the alleged right of the rural service provider to expand 
  its services within its assigned area and the municipalityâ€™s right to determine 
  who would provide services within the newly incorporated area.Â  Cf., 
  City of Rock Hill, 308 S.C. at 178, 417 S.E.2d at 564.Â  If the rural 
  service provider possessed an exclusive right to service the area, the municipality

Article VIII, section 15 requires consent of the county at the time 
  a water or sewer system is first constructed or when it is expanded.Â  See 
  City of Cayce v. AT&T Communications, 326 S.C. 237, 486 S.E.2d 92 
  (1997); City of Abbeville v. Aiken Elec. Coop., Inc., 287 S.C. 361, 338 
  S.E.2d 831 (1985).Â  The consent requirement of Article VIII, section 15 permits 
  counties to impose conditions on the grant of their consent to allow utilities 
  to build and operate water and electric systems.Â  City of Cayce, 326 
  S.C. at 241-42, 486 S.E.2d at 94.Â  Counties have the right to grant public utility 
  franchises and to determine who may or may not serve county residents.Â  South 
  Carolina Elec. & Gas Co. v. Berkeley Elec. Coop., Inc., 306 S.C. 228, 
  411 S.E.2d 218 (1991); City of Cayce, 326 S.C. at 241-42, 486 S.E.2d 
  at 94.Â  The Countyâ€™s constitutional authority includes the power to grant or 
  deny franchises, as well as the power to deny expansion of existing franchisees 
  or utility providers.Â  City of Aiken, 305 S.C. at 468, 409 S.E.2d at 
  404.
In Berkeley Elec. Coop., Inc. v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 
  304 S.C. 15, 402 S.E.2d 674 (1991), our Supreme Court explained:

We reject Co-opâ€™s claim that, while a municipality may, itself, provide 
  electric service within corporate limits, it may not designate a supplier through 
  a franchise agreement.Â  Our holdings in City of Abbeville v. Aiken Elec. 
  Co-op., Inc. and Blue Ridge Elec. Co-op v. City of Seneca are dispositive 
  of this issue.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In Abbeville, we rejected a municipalityâ€™s claim that it had 
  the right to oust an existing electric supplier upon annexation.Â  We stated:

  
[A] franchisee possessing a valid PSC territorial assignment to serve an area 
  which is subsequently annexed:
1.Â  Is permitted to continue service in that area to those premises being served 
  at the time of annexation;
2.Â  Is prohibited, without prior consent of the municipality, from extending 
  or expanding service in that area by the use of any streets, alleys, public 
  property or ways after the date of annexation.
  
287 S.C. at 370-371, 338 S.E.2d at 836.
In Blue Ridge, we addressed an assigned supplierâ€™s challenge to a municipal 
  utility which provided electricity in a newly annexed area.Â  There, we held 
  that â€œa municipality may either consent to expanded service by the assigned 
  supplier or itself serve new premises and customers within the assigned, annexed 
  area.â€Â  297 S.C. at 289, 376 S.E.2d at 517.
The basic premise upon which Abbeville and Blue Ridge 
  rest is a municipalityâ€™s right of consent under S.C. Const. Art. VIII, Â§ 15.Â  
  In Blue Ridge, we declined to interpret the Territorial Assignments Act, 
  as amended by Act 431 of 1984, in a way violative of this right.Â  We stated:
  
Absent the option of municipal service to new premises and customers in assigned, 
  annexed areas, the assigned supplier would possess, for all practical purposes, 
  an exclusive territorial service right.Â  Municipalities could not realistically 
  deny consent to expanded service by these assigned suppliers; denying consent 
  would be tantamount to denying property owners in the annexed area any electric 
  service at all.
  
297 S.C. at 289, 376 S.E.2d at 517-518.
Here, Co-opâ€™s contention that a municipally-franchised utility should 
  be distinguished from a municipally-owned utility effectually denies Summervilleâ€™s 
  right of consent, leaving Summerville with the sole alternative of permitting 
  Co-op to provide the service.Â  This would clearly violate Abbeville and 
  Blue Ridge, supra.
Summerville has granted SCE & G its consent 
  to serve the annexed area by virtue of the franchise agreement.Â  Accordingly, 
  Circuit Court correctly held that SCE & G may continue providing electric 
  service to Hardeeâ€™s.

Berkeley Elec. Coop., Inc., 304 S.C. at 18-20, 402 S.E.2d at 676-77 
  (footnotes and emphasis omitted).
The Court addressed the efficacy of Article VIII, section 15 of the 
  South Carolina Constitution in City of Aiken v. Aiken Elec. Coop., Inc., 
  305 S.C. 466, 409 S.E.2d 403 (1991):

Article VIII, Section 15, of the South Carolina 
  Constitution prohibits the General Assembly from enacting laws which grant the 
  right to construct or operate upon the streets or property of a municipality 
  without first obtaining the consent of such municipality.
This Court has affirmed the right of municipalities to authorize expansion 
  of existing service or to provide alternative service.Â  See Berkeley 
  Elec. Co-Op v. S.C. Public Service Commâ€™n, [304 S.C. 15,] 402 S.E.2d 674 
  (S.C. Sup. Ct. 1991) (citing Blue Ridge Elec. Co-Op v. City of Seneca, 
  297 S.C. 283, 376 S.E.2d 514 (1989)); City of Abbeville v. Aiken Elec. Co-Op, 
  287 S.C. 361, 338 S.E.2d 831 (1985).Â  When service to a new area is not provided 
  by the municipality, the municipally assigned supplier possesses exclusive rights.Â  
  Our holding in Berkeley makes no distinction between a municipally owned 
  supplier and a municipally franchised supplier.Â  Hence, service by a franchised 
  supplier is considered municipal service.
We find that the City was within its constitutional 
  authority to designate an electric service supplier for new customers in the 
  annexed area and to enact ordinances affecting other suppliers of electricity.Â  
  S.C. Const. Art. VIII, Â§ 15.

City of Aiken, 305 S.C. at 468, 409 S.E.2d at 404.

Article VIII, section 15 was further discussed in City of Rock Hill v. Public 
  Serv. Commâ€™n, 308 S.C. 175, 417 S.E.2d 562 (1992):
  
Article VIII, Â§ 15 of the South Carolina Constitution provides:
No law shall be passed by the General Assembly granting the right to construct 
  and operate in a public street or on public property a street or other railway, 
  telegraph, telephone or electric plant, or to erect water, sewer or gas works 
  for public use, or to lay mains for any purpose, or to use the streets for any 
  other such facility, without first obtaining the consent of the governing body 
  of the municipality in control of the streets or public places proposed to be 
  occupied for any such or like purpose.
  
We have interpreted this provision in several cases.Â  In City of Abbeville 
  v. Aiken Elec. Co-op., Inc., 287 S.C. 361, 338 S.E.2d 831 (1985), we held 
  that a municipality did not have the right to oust an existing electric supplier 
  when the assigned area was subsequently annexed.Â  However, we also determined 
  that expansion by the use of any city street or public property by the supplier 
  within the annexed area without the municipalityâ€™s consent was prohibited.Â  
  Id.Â  In Blue Ridge Electric v. City of Seneca, 297 S.C. 283, 376 
  S.E.2d 514 (1989), the issue presented was whether a municipality could service 
  new customers in an area assigned to another electrical supplier once the area 
  was annexed into the city.Â  We held that denying the municipalities the right 
  to serve in the annexed areas would be tantamount to leaving the assigned supplier 
  with an exclusive territorial right since the municipality would be faced with 
  the choice of denying the property owners power or consenting to the assigned 
  supplierâ€™s use of the streets and public ways for expansion of their service.Â  
  As this would create an irreconcilable conflict between the Act 431 and municipalityâ€™s 
  rights under Article VIII Â§ 15, we determined a municipality could not be enjoined 
  from serving new customers within the annexed property.
In subsequent cases, this Court held the cityâ€™s right to consent included 
  the power to designate another supplier other than the municipal utility or 
  the assigned supplier.Â  Berkeley Electric Co-op. v. South Carolina Public 
  Service Commission, 304 S.C. 15, 402 S.E.2d 674 (1991); City of Aiken 
  v. Aiken Elec. Co-op., 305 S.C. 466, 409 S.E.2d 403 (1991); South Carolina 
  Electric & Gas v. Berkeley Electric Cooperative, Inc., 306 S.C. 228, 
  411 S.E.2d 218 (1991).Â  In these cases, we have implicitly acknowledged that 
  without the ability to provide service or authorize another utility to provide 
  service, the constitutional right to grant or withhold consent would be meaningless.

City of Rock Hill, 308 S.C. at 177-78, 417 S.E.2d at 563-64.
Section 4-9-30(11) of the South Carolina Code authorizes counties â€œto grant 
  franchises and make charges in areas outside the corporate limits of municipalities 
  within the county in the manner provided by law for municipalities and subject 
  to the same limitations, to provide for the orderly control of services and 
  utilities affected with the public interest.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 4-9-30(11) (Supp. 
  2002).Â  The Williamsburg County Council passed a franchise ordinance regulating 
  the water franchises to various entities in Williamsburg County which became 
  effective on August 7, 1995.Â  In Glendale Water Corp. v. City of Florence, 
  274 S.C. 472, 265 S.E.2d 41 (1980), our Supreme Court approved of cities extending 
  their water lines if they had a valid franchise from the County.
The issue of exclusivity of a franchise is vested 
  in the governmental entity pursuant to Article VIII, sections 15 and 16 of the 
  South Carolina Constitution.Â  The General Assembly may enact legislation placing 
  responsibility upon a governmental entity to act upon a request by a non-governmental 
  entity to provide water and sewer services by denying or granting such a request 
  under certain conditions and time parameters.Â  Section 33-35-90 is the paradigm 
  of a legislative act involving procedural responses mandated by a governmental 
  entity to either provide water and sewer services or to allow a non-governmental 
  entity to engage in these activities.Â  This section was efficacious at the time 
  of the filing of the application by Williamsburg Water.Â  Because the County 
  is bound by the â€œlaw of the caseâ€ doctrine in regard to the issue of consent, 
  my analysis is limited to the facts of this case.
CONCLUSION
I find that the issue of governmental consent by the 
  County is controlled by the ruling of the circuit judge.Â  His conclusion that 
  Williamsburg Water gave proper and adequate notice under Â§ 33-35-90 became the 
  law of the case.
Based on the constitutional provisions and the evolving precedent 
  extant in this field, I hold that Williamsburg Water is entitled to a non-exclusive 
  right to provide water and sewer service to the areas designated in 
  its proposal made pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-35-90.Â  I rule the County 
  has a non-exclusive right to provide water and sewer service in 
  the areas designated in the proposal.
Accordingly, I VOTE to AFFIRM the order of the circuit court.
STILWELL, J.Â  (concurring 
  in result only):Â  Although I agree with the result of this case, I write 
  separately to explain my reasoning, which differs from both the majority opinion 
  and Judge Andersonâ€™s opinion concurring in result only.
The critical issue is whether Williamsburg Waterâ€™s 
  notice to the county and the countyâ€™s action or inaction thereafter vested Williamsburg 
  Water with the exclusive right to provide water service in the subject area 
  or a non-exclusive right to provide such service.Â  The trial courtâ€™s order holding 
  Williamsburg Waterâ€™s authority to be non-exclusive came as a result of rather 
  generic mutual motions for summary judgment, neither of which focused on the 
  issue of whether the rights obtained were exclusive or non-exclusive.Â Â  There 
  may well be a genuine issue of material fact concerning whether the statute, 
  Williamsburg Waterâ€™s notice, and Williamsburg Countyâ€™s response or lack thereof 
  creates exclusive or non-exclusive rights.
However, the status of this appeal is such that 
  we are not able to address that issue.Â  The question presented on appeal is 
  whether the trial court erred in failing to find that Williamsburg Water had 
  exclusive right and authority to serve within the specified area and Williamsburg 
  Waterâ€™s arguments all focus on its contention that it is so entitled.Â  Thus, 
  the issue as presented is the functional equivalent of an appeal of the refusal 
  to grant summary judgment, an issue that is not appealable.Â  Ballenger v. 
  Bowen, 313 S.C. 476, 443 S.E.2d 379 (1994); Olson v. Faculty House of 
  Carolina, 354 S.C. 161, 580 S.E.2d 440 (2003).Â  
Nowhere in Williamsburg Waterâ€™s brief do I find 
  an assertion that the court erred in ruling that Williamsburg Waterâ€™s rights 
  were non-exclusive.Â  Because that finding was not appealed, it is the law of 
  the case and not subject to review by this court.Â  ML-Lee Acquisition Fund, 
  LP, v. Deloitte & Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 489 S.E.2d 470 (1997).Â  
For that reason alone, I would affirm the trial 
  courtâ€™s ruling.
CONNOR, J., concurs.

 
   
    [1]  Williamsburg Water named the Town of Hemingway and Barrineau Water 
    Company, Inc., as defendants in the case, but these defendants were later 
    dismissed as parties. 

 
   [2] Â  In October of 2000, section 33-35-90 was repealed 
    and replaced with section 33-36-270.

 
   [3]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-36-270 (2000) 
    includes the following language:Â  â€œFailure to notify the corporation within 
    ninety days of the governing bodyâ€™s approval or intent to serve is considered 
    approval.â€

 
   
     
    [4]    Because only the extent of the service right is in issue, and not 
    the existence thereof, we need not address Williamsburg Waterâ€™s argument that 
    section 33-36-270 applies retroactively to these facts.

 
   
    [5] Â Â  We recognize that the lack of existing facilities is likely the 
    result of Williamsburg Waterâ€™s inability to obtain funding due to the circumstances 
    surrounding the Countyâ€™s award of franchises for the same areas which Williamsburg 
    Water desired to service.Â  However, we cannot ignore the absence of facilities 
    in light of its significance in the annexation cases.

 
   [6] Â  During oral argument, counsel for Williamsburg 
    Water conceded that it is subject to certain aspects of the ordinance. 

 
  1 Williamsburg 
    Water named the Town of Hemingway and Barrineau Water Company, Inc. as defendants 
    in the case, but these defendants were later dismissed as parties.

 
  2 In 
    October of 2000, Â§ 33-35-90 was repealed and replaced with Â§ 33-36-270.

 
  3 In 
    October of 2000, Â§ 33-35-170 was repealed.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Brentley Allen Blalock,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Donald W. Beatty, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3708
Heard October 8, 2003 â€“ Filed December 
  8, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Brentley Blalock was tried 
  on two counts ofÂ  criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  Blalock was acquitted 
  on one count and convicted on the second count. Blalock appeals his conviction, 
  arguing the trial judge committed reversible error by allowing the state to 
  present extrinsic evidence in connection with a prior inconsistent statement 
  by his wife, Lee Blalock. We affirm, finding the trial court did not abuse its 
  discretion in admitting the evidence. [1] 
FACTS/BACKGROUND [2] 
On July 11, 2000, 14-year-old 
  Jane Smith [3]  and her family 
  visited the home of their neighbors, Brentley and Lee Blalock.Â  After passing 
  the afternoon with the Blalocks, the Smiths returned to their nearby home.Â  
  Jane, however, asked and was allowed to stay for a while longer.Â  Brentley Blalock, 
  Lee Blalock, one of their sons, and Jane continued watching television and â€œplaying 
  aroundâ€ in the living room.Â  After a while, Ms. Blalock left the room to take 
  care of some chores in the adjacent kitchen.Â  During this time, Jane claimed 
  Brentley Blalock committed a sexual battery upon her.
At the center of this appeal is a statement Ms. 
  Blalock provided to a police detective investigating the incident on the evening 
  of July 11, 2000.Â  In the statement, transcribed by the detective, Ms. Blalock 
  described what she saw that night.Â  In the critical portion of the narrative, 
  Ms. Blalock reportedly said that when she returned from the kitchen to the living 
  room she â€œsaw [Jane] laying on her stomach in front of the T.V.Â  Brentley [Blalock] 
  was sitting beside her.Â  I noticed he had his hand under her pants leg on her 
  backside.â€
At trial, the prosecution called Ms. Blalock as 
  a witness and examined her regarding what she saw on July 11, 2000 â€“ focusing 
  primarily on her statement to the police detective.Â  Initially, however, the 
  solicitor did not confront her with the exact words recorded in the statement.Â  
  Instead, the solicitor characterized Ms. Blalockâ€™s statement in different termsâ€”adding 
  and deleting key words and changing the order of the words.Â  
The solicitor first asked Ms. Blalock whether she 
  saw her â€œhusbandâ€™s hand under [Janeâ€™s] pants and on her bottom.â€Â  The solicitorâ€™s 
  substitution of the word â€œpantsâ€ for â€œpants legâ€ and â€œbottomâ€ for â€œbacksideâ€ 
  contributed to the confusion that would follow.Â  Ms. Blalock answered â€œnoâ€ and 
  attempted to explain: 

I did not see his hand on her 
  butt per se, just for lack of a better word.Â  When I walked in, they were fine, 
  looking at television. She had shorts on that were what would have been acceptable 
  for school. Her parents didnâ€™t allow her to wear teenybopper type clothes.Â  
  So, they were kind of long and I did see his hand underneath her shorts on her 
  leg.Â  

Ms. Blalock apparently then tried to correct the 
  solicitorâ€™s misquotation of her statement, explaining that â€œin my statement, 
  it says on her back side.â€Â  Before Ms. Blalock could continue, however, the 
  solicitor protested to the court that she was being â€œnon-responsiveâ€ and asked 
  for permission to â€œtake her as a hostile witness to impeach her under Rule 607,â€ 
  which was allowed.Â  
The solicitor then presented Ms. Blalock 
  with a copy of her statement and had her read aloud the sentences quoted above.Â  
  Again, when asked to confirm or deny the statement, Ms. Blalock instead tried 
  to explain: â€œIâ€™m saying that maybe some of the details are missing [from the 
  statement].Â  Just like you pointed out with Jane, a few minutes ago, all of 
  the details were not included.Â  When youâ€™re upset in a time like that, you donâ€™t 
  think to include everything.â€
After further questioning, the solicitor 
  returned to the statement a third time, but once again the solicitor changed 
  the actual wording, asking Ms. Blalock: â€œYou saw his hand on her back side under 
  her pants?â€Â  Ms. Blalock again attempted explanation, responding:

A.Â Â Â Â Â  [Ms. Blalock]Â  Her back 
  side of her leg.Â  Thatâ€™s another thing that was left out.
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  [Solicitor]Â  Okay.Â  
  And when did you come up with that? When did you realize that was missing?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  That was sometime after 
  the, all the reports were gone and I had time to think over things in my mind, 
  and when I was more clear headed so I could remember more of the details of 
  what went on.

After a break in the testimony, the solicitor revisited 
  the statement a final time.Â  

Q.Â Â Â Â Â  [Solicitor]Â  Mrs. Blalock, 
  I want to show you your statement again, if I may, so that thereâ€™s no misunderstanding. 
  Okay?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  [Ms. Blalock]Â  (Witness 
  nods affirmatively.)
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  Did you say Brentley 
  was sitting beside her, and I noticed he had his hand under her pants leg on 
  her back side?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  I said that portion, 
  and for whatever reason, the detail of, of her leg, the back side, was left 
  out.
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  All right.Â  So thatâ€™s 
  what you --?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  But that portion, yes.
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  Okay.Â  Did you ever 
  tell anybody back side of her leg until court today?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Well, I thought that 
  I did.
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  Okay.Â  Who would you 
  have told?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Detective Lindsey and 
  cops or whoever else --.
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  When would you have told 
  Detective Lindsey?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  -- that may have been 
  there.
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  I mean you are saying 
  it happened that night you told him after you signed it or the following week?Â  
  When did you do this?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  It would have been at 
  the time of the statement.
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  Okay.Â  So, again, when 
  you said that, on the back side, you, at that time, you would of told him of 
  her leg?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  I feel like I said that.Â  
  If I didnâ€™t, you know, I may have been unclear about it or he may of, you know, 
  been paraphrasing what I was saying.

Immediately following this colloquy, the solicitor 
  attempted to offer the statement into evidence but withdrew the offer after 
  defense counsel requested a bench conference.
The State next called William Lindsey, 
  the police investigator who took Ms. Blalockâ€™s statement.Â  When the State sought 
  to publish the statement through Detective Lindsey, defense counsel objected, 
  citing Rule 613(b), SCRE.Â  The trial court overruled the objection and Ms. Blalockâ€™s 
  prior inconsistent statement was published.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Our courts have consistently held that a trial 
  courtâ€™s decision to admit evidence of a witnessâ€™s prior inconsistent statement 
  will not be reversed absent a manifest abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Lynn, 
  277 S.C. 222, 225, 284 S.E.2d 786, 788 (1981);Â  State v. Sierra, 337 
  S.C. 368, 373, 523 S.E.2d 187, 189 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding appellant must show 
  both abuse of discretion and resulting prejudice).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Blalock argues the trial 
  court erred by admitting extrinsic evidence of his wifeâ€™s prior statement to 
  impeach her trial testimony.Â  The State claims this issue is not preserved for 
  appellate review.Â  We disagree on both counts.
In order to preserve an 
  error for appellate review, a defendant must make a contemporaneous objection 
  on a specific ground. Rule 103(a)(1), SCRE; Â State v. Hoffman, 
  312 S.C. 386, 393, 440 S.E.2d 869, 873 (1994); State v. Holliday, 333 
  S.C. 332, 338, 509 S.E.2d 280, 283 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œThe objection should be 
  sufficiently specific to bring into focus the precise nature of the alleged 
  error so that it can be reasonably understood by the trial judge.â€ McKissick 
  v. J.F. Cleckley & Co., 325 S.C. 327, 344, 479 S.E.2d 67, 75 
  (Ct. App. 1996).
Here, defense counsel promptly objected when the 
  State sought to introduce extrinsic evidence of Ms. Blalockâ€™s prior statement.Â  
  First, the court promptly replied by referencing Rule 613(b), and the state 
  withdrew the exhibit.Â  Next, when Detective Lindsey was asked to publish Ms. 
  Blalockâ€™s statement, defense counsel objected by reference to Rule 613(b).Â  
  We find this evidentiary objection properly preserved.Â  We have no difficulty 
  discerning the issue from the targeted references by the trial court and defense 
  counsel to Rule 613(b) and the context from which this issue arose.
Rule 613(b), SCRE, provides 
  in pertinent part:

Extrinsic evidence of a prior 
  inconsistent statement by a witness is not admissible unless the witness is 
  advised of the substance of the statement, the time and place it was allegedly 
  made, and the person to whom it was made, and is given the opportunity to explain 
  or deny the statement. If a witness does not admit that he has made the prior 
  inconsistent statement, extrinsic evidence of such statement is admissible.

The central question, 
  therefore, is whether Ms. Blalock admitted making an inconsistent statement 
  in her testimony.Â  As described above, however, Ms. Blalockâ€™s testimony affords 
  little in the way of a clear admission or denial.Â  At various points in her 
  testimony, she concedes that the material portions of the statement were in 
  fact her own words; but she is simultaneously eager to explain and amend her 
  words and intent.Â  Overall, Ms. Blalock appears to have reacted as would be 
  expected of anyone who realizes he or she has been called as the star witness 
  against his or her spouse: self-conscious, confused, and wary of how her testimony 
  will be perceived by the jury.
In determining whether 
  a witness has admitted making a prior inconsistent statement and thereby obviated 
  the need for extrinsic proof, the courts of our state and other jurisdictions 
  have held that the witness must admit making the prior statement unequivocally 
  and without qualification.Â  See State v. Bottoms, 260 S.C. 187, 
  194, 195 S.E.2d 116, 118 (1973) (when a witness â€œadmits unequivocallyâ€ that 
  a prior inconsistent statement has been made by him, he has thereby impeached 
  himself and further evidence is unnecessary and inadmissible); 98 C.J.S. Witnesses 
  Â§ 727 (2002) (stating admission must be â€œunequivocalâ€).Â  
Generally, where the witness 
  has responded with anything less than an unequivocal admission, trial courts 
  have been granted wide latitude to allow extrinsic evidence proving the statement.Â  
  For example, a witnessâ€™s failure to fully recall her prior statement has been 
  found to be a sufficient denial to allow extrinsic evidence.Â  State v. Brown, 
  296 S.C. 191, 193, 371 S.E.2d 523, 524 (1988); State v. Miller, 262 S.C. 
  369, 371, 204 S.E.2d 738, 738-39 (1974); 81 Am. Jur. 2d Witnesses Â§ 948 
  (2003) (stating that a â€œwitness may be impeached by proof of prior contradictory 
  statements, where he merely testifies that he does not remember, or has no recollection 
  of, making the statements referred toâ€).Â  Extrinsic evidence is also usually 
  admitted when the witness simply avoids any direct answer.Â  Confronted with 
  this situation in State v. Sullivan, our supreme court held:

If the witness neither directly 
  admit [sic] nor deny [sic] the act or declaration, as when he merely says that 
  he does not recollect, or, as it seems, gives any other indirect answer not 
  amounting to an admission, it is competent for the adversary to prove the affirmative, 
  for otherwise the witness might in every such case exclude evidence of what 
  he had done or said by answering that he did not remember.

43 S.C. 205, 211, 21 S.E 
  4, 7 (1895).
In this case, we find 
  Ms. Blalockâ€™s response, when confronted with her prior statement, does not meet 
  the standard of a clear and unequivocal admission that the precedent case law 
  demands.Â  We are mindful that, towards the end of the solicitorâ€™s examination 
  of Ms. Blalock regarding the statement, she does admit that she said the â€œportionâ€ 
  of the statement quoted.Â  She is adamant throughout her testimony, however, 
  that the statement as recorded by the detective was incomplete.Â  As demonstrated 
  in the excerpted testimony above, Ms. Blalock repeatedly insists that she did 
  not merely say she saw her husbandâ€™s hand on Janeâ€™s â€œbackside,â€ but that she 
  saw his hand on the â€œback side of her leg.â€Â  When the solicitor presses her 
  on when and to whom she said â€œback side of her leg,â€ Ms. Blalock testifies that 
  she â€œfeel[s] likeâ€ that is what she told Detective Lindsey at the time he took 
  her statement.Â  Ultimately, she equivocates as to whether the statement was 
  in fact her own words, testifying that she may have been â€œunclearâ€ or that Detective 
  Lindsey had â€œparaphrasedâ€ what she said.
Clearly, by repeatedly 
  insisting that she said or intended to say â€œback side of her legâ€ instead of 
  â€œbackside,â€ Ms. Blalock was attempting to dispel the implication that she actually 
  saw Brentley Blalockâ€™s hand on or near Janeâ€™s genital area.Â  This disparity, 
  therefore, goes to the essential meaning of what Detective Lindsey recorded 
  as Ms. Blalockâ€™s statement.Â  The entire probative value of Ms. Blalockâ€™s statement 
  and trial testimony hinges on where she saw her husbandâ€™s hand on Janeâ€™s body.Â  
  Considered in toto, Ms. Blalockâ€™s testimony regarding her statement shrouds 
  its meaning in doubt.Â  Admission of extrinsic evidence to prove Ms. Blalock 
  made the statement was therefore relevant to the juryâ€™s consideration of the 
  veracity of Ms. Blalock as a witness and the consequent weight her testimony 
  should be afforded.
We respectfully reject 
  Blalockâ€™s position that State v. Lynn compels a different result.Â  First, 
  we are confronted with a different factual presentation.Â  We do not believe 
  Ms. Blalockâ€™s varyingÂ  responses rise to the level of the unequivocal admission, 
  as was present in Lynn, necessary to foreclose resort to extrinsic evidence.Â Â  
  Second, as noted above, a significant feature in Lynn is the holding 
  that â€œthe cross-examination of a witness to test his credibility is largely 
  within the discretion of the trial judge, and his decision whether to allow 
  the contradictory testimony will not be disturbed on appeal except for manifest 
  abuse of discretion.â€ State v. Lynn 277 S.C. at 225, 284 S.E.2d at 788. 
  Considering we are governed by an abuse of discretion standard, we cannot say 
  under these facts that the trial judge erred in admitting extrinsic evidence 
  of Ms. Blalockâ€™s prior inconsistent statement.Â  Moreover, Detective Lindseyâ€™s 
  publication of the prior statement was cumulative to Ms. Blalockâ€™s previous, 
  unchallenged publication of the relevant portion of her statement.Â  
As a final observation, 
  we acknowledge Blalockâ€™s concern with the conduct of the solicitor and his role 
  in fostering the present controversy.Â  We are persuaded, however, that Ms. Blalockâ€™s 
  varying responses cannot be solely attributed to the solicitorâ€™s paraphrasing 
  of the prior statement.Â  
CONCLUSION
The trial court acted 
  within its discretion in admitting extrinsic evidence of Lee Blalockâ€™s prior 
  inconsistent statement.
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and HOWARD,Â  JJ., concur. 

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Blalockâ€™s appellate counsel did not represent Blalock at trial.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Our discussion is limited to the facts and circumstances in 
    connection with the charge resulting in a conviction. 

 
   
    [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  TheÂ  minorÂ  victim and her family are identified by a fictitious 
    name.

description: The Court of Appeals found that First Union did not give the Kirkmans an impliedly warrant the habitability when it sold a home to them, because it was acting primarily as a lender rather than a seller or developer.
