THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Theodore H. Kirkman and Karen K.
Kirkman,        Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Parex, Inc.; Francis Coaxum, d/b/a Coaxum 
        Stucco; R.E. Miller, Miller Housing, Inc., and Miller Development Group; 
        and First Union National Bank of South Carolina       
Defendants,
of Whom First Union National Bank of South 
        Carolina is,        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3709
Submitted October 6, 2003 â€“ Filed December 
  8, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John D. Kassel and William D. Robertson, III, both of Columbia, 
  for Appellants.
Thomas E. Lydon, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Pursuant to cross-motions 
  for summary judgment, the trial court determined that First Union, as a lender, 
  did not impliedly warrant the habitability of Ted and Karen Kirkmanâ€™s house.Â  
  Summary judgment was granted in favor of First Union and the Kirkmans appeal.Â  
  We affirm.
FACTS
In 1989, Miller Housing began the construction 
  of a house for speculative sale in Mt. Pleasant, South Carolina.Â  Miller Housing 
  financed the construction through South Carolina Federal, predecessor to First 
  Union. [1]  Notwithstanding financial 
  difficulties, Miller Housing substantially completed the house by early 1991.Â  
  The Kirkmans desired to purchase the property from Miller Housing in April 1991, 
  but the property was in foreclosure.Â  The Kirkmans agreed to a purchase price 
  of $232,900.Â  The foreclosure action determined that Miller Housingâ€™s indebtedness 
  to First Union amounted to approximately $205,000.
The Kirkmans, Miller Housing and First 
  Union initially agreed that First Union would not conclude the foreclosure.Â  
  Other liens, however, necessitated foreclosure, and, with the partiesâ€™ consent, 
  the property was deeded to First Union in May 1991.Â  It was further agreed that 
  Miller Housing would complete construction.Â  Miller Housing failed to do so.Â  
  First Union, in an effort to mitigate its losses, hired Building Services of 
  Charleston to complete construction, at a cost of $40,000 to $50,000.Â  Building 
  Services of Charlestonâ€™s work included, among other things, installation of 
  compressors and air handlers, but it did not include any aspect of the 
  artificial stucco siding which is the subject of this suit.Â  The artificial 
  stucco siding was installed during Miller Housingâ€™s involvement, well prior 
  to First Unionâ€™s involvement.Â  The house was completed and the Kirkmans took 
  possession of the property in July of 1991.
In 1999, the Kirkmans were pursuing the 
  sale of the property and discovered moisture damage in the stucco siding.Â  After 
  repairing the damage and selling the house, the Kirkmans filed suit against 
  Miller Housing, the installer of the stucco, the manufacturer of the stucco 
  and First Union.Â  All claims have been resolved through default or settlement 
  except the implied warranty of habitability against First Union.
STANDARDÂ  OFÂ  REVIEW
â€œSummary judgment is proper when there is no genuine 
  issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to a judgment 
  as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56, SCRCP; South Carolina Prop. & Cas. Guar. 
  Assâ€™n. v. Yensen, 345 S.C. 512, 518, 548 S.E.2d 880, 883 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
  Here, there are no material facts in dispute.Â  Thus, in light of the uncontested 
  factual record, the dispositive question before the courtÂ  is one ofÂ  law.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Kirkmans contend the trial court 
  erred in finding First Union was not liable under an implied warranty of habitability.Â  
  They maintain First Union was â€œsubstantially involvedâ€ in completingÂ  construction 
  on the house.Â  The Kirkmans also assert that it was not necessary for First 
  Union to have been involved in the installation of the stucco for it to be liable 
  under an implied warranty of habitability.Â  We find First Union was a mere lender 
  protecting its interest and should not be held responsible under an implied 
  warranty of habitability.
A warranty of habitability springs from the sale 
  of a home.Â  See Lane v. Trenholm Bldg. Co., 267 S.C. 497, 500, 
  229 S.E.2d 728, 729 (1976).Â  The warranty is grounded in the doctrine of caveat 
  venditor.Â  In Lane, the court found â€œ[t]he law should not orphan the 
  purchaser of a house, who has likely invested his life savings â€¦ by operation 
  of the doctrine of [c]aveat emptor.â€ Id. at 503, 229 S.E.2d at 731. It 
  further wrote that a sellerâ€™s â€œliability is not founded upon fault, but because 
  it has profited by receiving a fair price and, as between it and an innocent 
  purchaser, the innocent purchaser should be protected from latent defects.â€Â 
Id.
Our supreme court has established that 
  public policy disfavors imposing an implied warranty of habitability on a mere 
  lender.Â  See Kennedy v. Columbia Lumber & Mfg. Co., 299 S.C. 
  335, 340, 384 S.E.2d 730, 734 (1989).Â  The court concluded that imposition of 
  liability on mere lenders would be burdensome and would discourage lending in 
  the state.Â  Id.Â  Additionally, the court held:Â  â€œ[I]t is unduly punitive 
  to impose potential warranty liability on a lender that is searching for some 
  way to recover the losses it has suffered due to the default of the debtor.â€Â  
  Id.Â Â  This court, following the Kennedy precedent, noted that 
  â€œa construction lender is not responsible for the torts of the borrower unless 
  the lender is involved in, or exercises control over, construction to an extent 
  that exceeds the degree of involvement normally expected of a commercial lender.â€ 
  Whitfield Constr. Co. v. Bank of Tokyo Trust Co., 338 S.C. 207, 216, 
  525 S.E.2d 888, 893 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
In Roundtree Villas Assâ€™n, Inc. v. 
  4701 Kings Corporation, 282 S.C. 415, 321 S.E.2d 46 (1984), the court found 
  a lender was not liable for defects in construction which was completed prior 
  to it undertaking repairs to several units.Â  While the lender monitored the 
  construction, this did not create a duty to prevent defects.Â  Id. at 
  422, 321 S.E.2d at 50.Â  Conversely, Roundtree Villas permitted liability 
  against the lender when â€œit undertook to repair defects â€¦ [and] took over the 
  project and undertook to market the units through a corporation it had created.â€Â  
  Id. at 423, 321 S.E.2d at 51.
A lender, however, may be held liable 
  under the theory of an implied warranty of habitability when its functions as 
  a lender are secondary to its function as a developer.Â  See Lane, 
  267 S.C. at 503-04, 229 S.E.2d at 730. In Lane, the developer of a subdivision 
  sold an undeveloped lot to a builder.Â  The developer took a second mortgage 
  on the house built on the lot.Â  The builder deeded the house to the developer 
  in satisfaction of its mortgage.Â  The developer paid off the first mortgage 
  on the house, and then sold it to Lane.Â  Lane experienced problems with the 
  septic system, and the developer was found liable under caveat venditor and 
  the implied warranty of habitability.Â  In that case, the court found:Â  â€œTrenholm 
  purported to be selling a new house and certainly Lane's objective in purchasing 
  the house was to provide a home for his family. The sale contemplated the use 
  of the house as the dwelling; an implied warranty does no more than fulfill 
  the reasonable expectations of the parties.â€Â  Id. at 503, 229 S.E.2d 
  at 730.Â Â Â Â Â  
In Kennedy, the court further 
  addressed the issue and found a lender might be liable under implied warranty 
  of habitability in certain situations:

A lender will also incur liability for the performance of 
  express representations made to a buyer. A lender should be held responsible 
  if it is aware of defects but conceals them from an unwitting buyer. Liability 
  may also attach when the lender becomes highly involved with construction in 
  a manner that is not normal commercial practice for a lender. In such a situation, 
  the lender might be said to be a joint venturer. The lender may be liable if 
  it is so amalgamated with the developer or builder so as to blur its legal distinction. 
  A lender may also be liable where it forecloses on a developer in the midst 
  of construction, takes title, has substantial involvement in completing the 
  construction and sells homes.

Kennedy, 299 S.C. at 340-41, 384 S.E.2d at 
  734 (internal citations omitted).
Here, we find the public policy reasons 
  advanced in Lane do not apply because the Kirkmans will not be â€œorphanedâ€ 
  if they are unable to proceed against First Union.Â  The Kirkmans know who built 
  the house, who produced the stucco siding, and who installed the stucco siding.Â  
  Their lawsuit has named all involved in the stucco siding, in addition to First 
  Union.Â  Significantly, the Kirkmans entered into the contract for sale with 
  the original builder, Miller Housing.Â  They knew Miller Housing was in foreclosure 
  and that First Union was involved only as a lender.Â  The Kirkmans approached 
  First Union about completing the house when Miller failed to do so.Â  In view 
  of these facts, we find none of the policy considerations discussed in Lane 
  justifying imposing liability under an implied warranty of habitability are 
  present in this case.Â  
Moreover, none of the situations discussed in Kennedy 
  favoring lender liability are present in this case.Â  The Kirkmans argue that 
  First Unionâ€™s expenditure of $40,000 to $50,000, standing alone, compels a finding 
  of First Unionâ€™s â€œsubstantial involvementâ€ in completing construction.Â  However, 
  we do not believe the supreme court in Kennedy intended the issue of 
  â€œsubstantial involvementâ€ to be determined solely by a mathematical approach.Â  
  Instead, we believe the degree of a lenderâ€™s involvement, in terms of completing 
  construction and otherwise, must be qualitatively and quantitatively determined 
  from the totality of the circumstances.Â  Here, according to the first contract 
  entered into by the Kirkmans, First Union was not to foreclose on the property 
  and the Kirkmans were to purchase it outright from the builder.Â  In order to 
  clear title for the Kirkmans, however, the contract was later modified to allow 
  foreclosure by First Union. At the time, First Union was owed over $200,000 
  on the property.Â  First Union was then required to complete construction, at 
  a cost of $40,000 to $50,000.Â  This expenditure of funds by First Union did 
  not alter its status as a lender because First Union had a right to expeditiously 
  mitigate its losses resulting from the builderâ€™s financial troubles.Â Â Â Â Â  
We find the public policy reasons articulated 
  in Kennedy compel a result rejecting an imposition of lender liability 
  on First Union.Â  First Union was not the only party known to the Kirkmans, so 
  they are not â€œorphanedâ€ as in Lane.Â  First Union would not be liable, 
  as recognized in Roundtree Villas, for the stucco siding because it was 
  not involved in the installation of the stucco siding.Â  As found in Kennedy, 
  it would be â€œunduly punitive to impose potential warranty liability on a lender 
  that is searching for some way to recover the losses it has suffered due to 
  the default of the debtor.â€Â  Kennedy, 299 S.C. at 340, 384 S.E.2d at 
  734.Â  Finally, since we find First Union was a mere lender and its completion 
  of construction was, at most, of secondary importance to its role as a lender, 
  we conclude that no valid, recognized policy would be served by imposing lender 
  liability on First Union.
 Accordingly, the decision of the circuit 
  court is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and HOWARD, JJ., concur.

 
   
     
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  For simplification we collectively refer to South Carolina 
    Federal and its successor, First Union, as â€œFirst Union.â€

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Rudolph Barnes, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Doris Ann 
        Barnes,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Cohen Dry Wall, Inc., and Aelina Martin, as Personal Representative of 
        the Estate of Orin Tilman Feagin,       
Defendants,
Of Whom Cohen Dry Wall, Inc. is the       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3710
Heard October 8, 2003 â€“ Filed December 
  8, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
N. Heyward Clarkson, III, Charles F. Turner, and Elizabeth 
  J. Smith, all of Greenville, for Appellant.
George J. Kefalos, of Charleston and Steve Christopher Davis, 
  of Moncks Corner, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.: Â  Rudolph Barnes, as personal 
  representative of the Estate of Doris Barnes, filed a negligence action against 
  Cohen Dry Wall and Orin Feagin.Â  The jury returned a verdict for Barnes in the 
  amount of $750,000.Â  Cohen appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On December 12, 1998, Cohen held its annual 
  Christmas party for its employees and their families.Â  As alcoholic beverages 
  were to be served at the party, Cohen Gaskins, the president of Cohen, hired 
  a professional bartender to verify guestsâ€™ identification before serving alcohol.Â  
  During the party, Gaskins announced to the party guests that there were 
  police officers outside and that, if anyone had too much to drink, a ride home 
  would be provided.
The day before the party, a supervisor informed 
  Orin Feagin, a nineteen-year-old Cohen employee, that he would not be served 
  alcohol at the party.Â  Feagin stated he would bring his own bottle of 
  alcohol.Â  Although several Cohen employees observed Feagin with a bottle 
  of gin at the party, no one saw him drink from the bottle.Â  Only one 
  person testified he saw Feagin drink alcohol from the bar.Â  
Several guests testified Feagin was loud and disruptive 
  at the party; however, others testified he behaved normally and did not act 
  as if he had been drinking.Â  Though Feagin left the party with a designated 
  driver, he drove out of the parking lot in his own vehicle.Â  After leaving 
  the party, Feagin visited his girlfriend at her place of employment, drove to 
  her motherâ€™s house, and then revisited his girlfriend.Â  Both the girlfriend 
  and her mother testified Feagin did not appear to be intoxicated.Â  A 
  short time later that evening, Feagin was involved in a two-car accident that 
  killed both him and the passenger in the other vehicle, Doris Barnes.Â  
Barnes sued both Cohen and Feaginâ€™s estate, alleging, 
  among other things, that Cohen was negligent in serving alcoholic beverages 
  to Feagin at the party.Â  Feaginâ€™s estate asserted a cross-claim against 
  Cohen for negligence per se and gross negligence. 
At the close of the evidence, Cohen unsuccessfully 
  moved for a directed verdict.Â  The jury returned a verdict against Cohen 
  and Feaginâ€™s estate for $750,000 in actual damages. 
  [1] Â  Cohen then moved for judgment notwithstanding the verdict, 
  new trial absolute, new trial nisi remittitur, new trial pursuant to the thirteenth-juror 
  doctrine, and alteration of the judgment to reflect a setoff of the amounts 
  paid by any or all of the insurance policies.Â  The trial court granted 
  only the last motion, holding â€œCohen Dry Wall is entitled to modify the judgment 
  to the extent of any liability insurance paid by the Defendant Feagin.â€
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.
Cohen argues that, under South Carolina law, â€œa 
  social host does not incur any liability to third parties when he serves alcohol 
  to his guestsâ€ and the trial court should therefore have granted its 
  directed verdict motion.Â  We disagree. 
  [2] 
In support of this argument, Cohen relies on Garren 
  v. Cummings & McCrady, Inc. [3] Â  This reliance is misplaced.Â  In Garren, 
  this court held that South Carolina did not recognize a third-party action against 
  a social host for serving alcohol to an adult guest.Â  This holding was based 
  on two determinations:Â  (1) South Carolina is â€œin accord with the general common 
  law view . . . that a social host incurs no liability to third parties when 
  he serves alcohol to his adult guestsâ€ [4]  and (2) no such liability was imposed by statute. 
  [5] Â  Neither of these circumstances applies to the present case.Â  
Here, Barnes sought relief for losses allegedly resulting 
  from Cohenâ€™s allowing the consumption of alcohol by a minorâ€”rather than an adult 
  guest.Â  Even more important, however, is the fact that the South Carolina General 
  Assembly has enacted several statutes making it unlawful for â€œany person,â€ not 
  just commercial establishments, to provide alcohol to persons under the legal 
  drinking age. [6] Â  Moreover, although these statutes 
  specifically exempt certain situations, they do not exclude social hosts from 
  the prohibition, [7]  and as our supreme court has stated in Whitlaw v. Kroger, 
  such statutes â€œare designed to prevent harm to the minor who purchased the alcohol 
  and to members of the public harmed by the minorâ€™s consumption of that alcohol.â€ 
  [8] 
Although Whitlaw concerned the unauthorized sale of 
  alcohol to a minor by a commercial entity, we hold the supreme courtâ€™s statement 
  regarding the purpose of such statutory prohibitions is just as applicable to 
  the provision of alcohol by a social host to a guest who is under the legal 
  drinking age.Â  In so holding, we follow other jurisdictions that have recognized 
  civil causes of action against social hosts for serving alcohol to underage 
  individuals when such an act was in violation of a statute. 
  [9] 
II.
A.
Cohen Dry Wall contends the trial court erred in allowing 
  Barnes to read excerpts of a deposition at trial, arguing Barnes did not meet 
  the burden of showing the witness was unavailable.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Counsel for Barnes informed the trial court that he intended 
  to read excerpts of a deposition at trial.Â  Counsel argued this was permitted 
  under Rule 32 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure because he could 
  not procure the witness by subpoena.Â  In support of this claim, counsel 
  submitted an affidavit of attempted service.Â  During the course of this 
  colloquy, the parties also discussed their belief that the deponent was incarcerated 
  in Columbia, which, according to Cohenâ€™s attorney, was less than 100 miles from 
  where the case was being tried.Â  Cohen now contends the trial court erred 
  in allowing the deposition testimony because it was not sufficiently established 
  that the deponent was either incarcerated or over 100 miles away.Â  
Although the trial court did not make specific findings regarding 
  the deponentâ€™s whereabouts, such findings were unnecessary.Â  Barnes submitted 
  an affidavit of failed service of the subpoena on the deponent.Â  This was sufficient 
  under Rule 32(a)(3)(D) to allow the deposition to be read into evidence at trial. 
  [10] 
B.
Cohen further argues Barnes failed to 
  give the required notice of his intent to use the deposition in lieu of having 
  the witness testify.Â  In addition, Cohen contends that, even if the allowance 
  of the deposition had been proper, the trial court should have also allowed 
  the jury to be informed that the deponent was incarcerated when the case came 
  to trial.Â  
These arguments, however, were not set forth in 
  the Statement of Issues on Appeal in Cohenâ€™s brief; therefore, we decline to 
  address them. [11] Â  We further note that, with 
  regard to the trial courtâ€™s refusal to inform the jury that the deponent was 
  incarcerated, Cohen presented no argument on appeal either challenging the trial 
  courtâ€™s finding that the information was hearsay or supporting its admissibility 
  as a hearsay exception.
III.
Finally, Cohen argues the trial court 
  erred in including in the jury charge language from South Carolina Code section 
  56-5-6110, known as the aiding and abetting statute.Â  Specifically, Cohen contends 
  that the reason the charge was error was that section 56-5-6110 is â€œnot relevant 
  to the issues raised by Barnesâ€™ allegations that Cohen Dry Wall provided and/or 
  served alcohol to a person under the age of twenty-oneâ€ because section 56-5-6110 
  concerns aiding and abetting only those offenses within the same title and chapter, 
  whereas the offenses of providing alcohol to persons under the legal drinking 
  age are found in different parts of the code.Â  We find no reversible error.Â  

At trial, when Barnes proffered the instruction, 
  Cohen argued the charge was improper because it would â€œ[supersede] the social 
  host immunityâ€ in that it would apply to serving visibly intoxicated adults 
  as well as minors. Â After the trial court charged the jury, Cohen made 
  only a general objection to the aiding and abetting charge, â€œjust to preserve 
  our position on the record.â€ 
We have reviewed the record before us and do not 
  see a ruling by the trial court on the question of whether section 56-5-6110 
  can be applied to the statutory prohibitions in Title 61 concerning serving 
  alcohol to a minor. Â Because the trial court did not have the opportunity 
  to rule on this particular issue, we likewise decline to address it on appeal. [12] 
AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  The jury also awarded punitive damages to Barnes against Feaginâ€™s 
    estate in the amount of $1,400,000, and no appeal was taken from this award.Â  
    As to the claim of Feaginâ€™s estate against Cohen, the jury found Cohen was 
    20 per cent responsible for Feaginâ€™s death and Feagin was 80 per cent responsible.

 
   
    [2] Â  Barnes argued in his brief that Cohen failed to preserve this argument 
    for appeal.Â  After examining the record in its entirety, however, we hold 
    Cohen sufficiently raised the issue before the trial court in order for us 
    to address it on appeal.Â  See State v. Dunbar, Op. No. 25732 
    (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Oct. 13, 2003) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 37 at 31, 34) 
    (â€œA party need not use the exact name of a legal doctrine in order to preserve 
    it, but it must be clear that the argument has been presented on that ground.â€).

 
   
    [3] Â  289 S.C. 348, 345 S.E.2d 508 (Ct. App. 1986).

 
   [4] Â  Id. at 350, 345 S.E.2d at 510 (emphasis 
    added).

 
   [5] Â  Id. at 351, 345 S.E.2d at 510.

 
   
    [6]  Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 61-4-90 (Supp. 2002) (â€œIt is unlawful 
    for a person to transfer or give to a person under the age of twenty-one years 
    for the purpose of consumption beer or wine at any place in the State.â€) and 
    id. Â§ 61-6-4070 (â€œIt is unlawful for a person to transfer or give to 
    a person under the age of twenty-one years for the purpose of consumption 
    alcoholic liquors at any place in the State.â€).

 
   
    [7] Â  Sections 61-4-90 and 61-6-4070 both state their respective provisions 
    do not apply to situations in which alcohol is provided (1) to a spouse or 
    child within the family home, (2) in conjunction with a religious ceremony, 
    and (3) within certain instructional settings.

 
    [8] Â  306 S.C. 51, 54-55, 
    410 S.E.2d 251, 253 (1991) (emphasis added); cf. Tobias v. Sports 
    Club, Inc., 332 S.C. 90, 93, 504 S.E.2d 318, 320 (1998) (â€œWe hold today 
    that our alcohol control statutes do not create a first party cause of action 
    for an intoxicated adult patron, but that they do permit a third party 
    action.â€) (emphasis added).

 
   
    [9] Â  See, e.g., Macleary v. Hines, 817 F.2d 1081 (3d Cir. 
    1987) (holding that, â€œunder Pennsylvania law a defendant who knowingly and 
    intentionally allows premises over which she has control to be used for the 
    purpose of consumption of alcohol by minors . . . may be liable for injuries 
    resulting therefromâ€ if the use of the premises is found to be â€œa substantial 
    factor in bringing about the intoxication of the minor guestâ€); Ely v. 
    Murphy, 540 A.2d 54, 58 (Conn. 1988) (recognizing the â€œlegislative determination 
    that minors are incompetent to assimilate responsibly the effects of alcohol 
    and lack the legal capacity to do soâ€ and holding that a minorâ€™s consumption 
    of alcohol therefore does not as a matter of law â€œinsulate one who provides 
    alcohol to minors from liability for ensuing injuryâ€); Thaut v. Finley, 
    213 N.W.2d 820, 822 (Mich. Ct. App. 1973) (holding the violation of a criminal 
    statute against furnishing intoxicants to a minor without a doctorâ€™s prescription 
    created a third-party cause of action against a social host who violated the 
    provision, notwithstanding the absence of any reference in the statute to 
    civil liability); Cole v. Oâ€™Tooles of Utica, Inc., 643 N.Y.S.2d 283, 
    286 (N.Y. App. Div. 1996) (holding a complaint sufficiently stated a â€œdramshopâ€ 
    cause of action against social hosts who unlawfully procured alcoholic beverages 
    for consumption by a minor who became intoxicated and then drove his car in 
    a negligent and reckless manner, causing the death of his passenger).

 
   
    [10]  Rule 32(a)(3) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provides 
    as follows:
  The deposition of a witness, 
    whether or not a party, may be used by any party for any purpose if 
    the court finds:
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (A) that the witness 
    is dead;Â  or
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (B) that the witness 
    is at a greater distance than 100 miles from the place of trial or hearing, 
    or is out of the State, unless it appears that the absence of the witness 
    was procured by the party offering the deposition;Â  or
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (C) that the witness 
    is unable to attend or testify because of age, illness, infirmity, or imprisonment;Â  
    or
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (D) that the party 
    offering the deposition has been unable to procure the attendance of the witness 
    by subpoena;Â  or
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (E) upon application 
    and notice, that such exceptional circumstances exist as to make it desirable, 
    in the interest of justice and with due regard to the importance of presenting 
    the testimony of witnesses orally in open court, to allow the deposition to 
    be used.
  (Emphasis added.)Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

 
   [11] Â  See State v. Dunbar, Op. No. 
    25732 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed October 13, 2003)Â  (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 37 at 
    34-35) (â€œNo point will be considered which is not set forth in the statement 
    of issues on appeal.â€) (citing Rule 208(b)(1), SCACR).

 
   
    [12] Â  See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 
    122, 124 (1991) (ruling an issue was not preserved for appellate review because 
    the trial court did not explicitly rule on it at trial and the appellant made 
    no Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment on that ground); Gurganious 
    v. City of Beaufort, 317 S.C. 481, 488, 454 S.E.2d 912, 916 (Ct. App. 
    1995) (â€œIt is well settled that one cannot present and try his case on one 
    theory and then change his theory on appeal.â€) (citing McClary v. Witherspoon, 
    251 S.C. 523, 164 S.E.2d 220 (1968)).

title: G & P Trucking v. Parks Auto Sales, Service, & Salvage
description: In this action for contribution arising from several prior related negligence claims, the defendant, Parks Auto Sales, Service & Salvage appeals the award of damages to the plaintiff, G&P Trucking, in the amount of Park Auto's pro rata share of the common liability in the underlying claims.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
G & P Trucking,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Parks Auto Sales Service & Salvage, Inc.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Daniel  F.Â  Pieper, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3711
Heard November 4, 2003 â€“ Filed December 
  8, 2003

REVERSED


  
    
      
Robert A. McKenzie and Gary H. Johnson, II, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Stephen E. Darling, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  In this action for contribution 
  arising from a prior negligence claim, the trial court awarded damages to G&P 
  Trucking against Parks Auto Sales, Service, & Salvage, Inc., in the amount 
  of Parks Autoâ€™s pro rata share of the common liability.Â  Parks Auto appeals.Â  
  We reverse.
FACTS
On January 12, 1999, Donald Finkey, a G&P employee, while 
  operating a tractor-trailer at the salvage yard of Parks Auto, struck a guy 
  wire connected to a radio communications tower and caused the tower to fall. 

After the accident, G&P entered into 
  settlements with four separate entities in connection with the collapse of the 
  tower.Â  Payments by G&P pursuant to the settlements were as follows:Â  
  (1) to Radio Communications of Charleston (RCC), the owner of the tower, G&P 
  paid drafts totaling $200,000.00 on January 12, 1999, and March 29, 1999; 
  (2) to The Hartford, which insured RCC and had a right to subrogation for 
  payments made directly to RCC, G&P paid $72,295.13 on September 1, 1999; 
  (3) to Wicks Broadcasting, which had equipment destroyed in the accident, 
  G&P paid $94,181.17 on February 15, 2000; and (4) to Parks Auto itself, 
  G&P paid $36,000.00 on November 10, 2000.Â  The total amount paid 
  by G&P was $402,476.30.
The record on appeal indicates that, in 
  connection with the four settlements, G&P obtained signed releases from 
  only RCC and Parks Auto.Â  The release from RCC states in pertinent part 
  that, in consideration of the sum paid by G&P, RCC â€œremise[s], release[s] 
  and forever discharge[s] the said Zurich Insurance [G&Pâ€™s insurer], G&P 
  Trucking Company and Donald Finkey, their agents, servants, employees, executors, 
  adjusters, insurance companies, subsidiaries, affiliated companies, administrators, 
  successors, employees, and assigns.â€Â  The release executed by Parks Auto, 
  after acknowledging G&P, Zurich, and Finkey as â€œPayers,â€ states that Parks 
  Auto â€œand its heirs, executors, administrators, and assigns, release and forever 
  discharge said Payers, their executives, administrators, assigns, and all other 
  persons, firms, and corporations, both known and unknown.â€ 
Before all the agreed-upon amounts were 
  paid in full, G&P brought this claim against Parks Auto for contribution 
  under the South Carolina Contribution Among Tortfeasors Act (the Act).Â  In 
  its complaint, dated January 31, 2000, G&P alleged Parks Auto was negligent 
  in failing to warn of the guy wire and in maintaining its premises in an unreasonable 
  condition.Â  Parks Autoâ€™s answer, dated March 22, 2000, denied any and 
  all claims asserted by G&P.Â  As of January 12, 2002, when the statute 
  of limitations had run on any claim arising from the underlying accident, the 
  case was still pending and no hearing had taken place. 
A hearing on the matter took place February 
  5 and 6, 2002.Â  The trial court, with the consent of counsel for both 
  sides, bifurcated the trial, allowing the jury to determine whether or not Parks 
  Auto was negligent, but reserving to itself the determination of whether Parks 
  Auto would be liable for contribution under the Act in the event the jury found 
  negligence.
The jury found Parks Auto negligently 
  and proximately caused damage or injury to G&P.Â  Parks Auto immediately 
  moved for judgment notwithstanding the verdict or, in the alternative, a new 
  trial on several grounds, namely, that (1) Parks Autoâ€™s liability was 
  not extinguished by the settlements, (2) Parks Auto had no duty to warn 
  of an open and obvious condition, and (3) Finkeyâ€™s intervening negligence 
  was the sole proximate cause of the accident.Â  The trial court denied 
  the motion and directed counsel to provide proposed orders on the nonjury issues, 
  with leave to reply to the other sideâ€™s order within five days thereafter.
The trial court found that â€œ[n]one of the settlements 
  fully compensated the parties for their loss.â€Â  Nevertheless, on June 
  14, 2002, the trial court issued an order granting G&P judgment against 
  Parks Auto in the amount of $201,238.15.Â  This award was equal to half 
  the amount that G&P had paid in connection with the accident. 
DISCUSSION
1.Â  Parks Auto argues that, because G&P has 
  not met the extinguishment requirement in the Act, 
  [1]  it has no legal right to contribution.Â  We agree with this argument 
  insofar as it concerns the payments to RCC, The Hartford, and Wicks Broadcasting.
â€œThe common law rule against contribution 
  was abrogated in 1988 when our General Assembly enacted the South Carolina Uniform 
  Contribution Among Tortfeasors Act . . . .â€ 
  [2] Â  Because the Act is in derogation of the common law, it must be strictly 
  construed. [3] Â  Moreover, â€œ[i]n a suit in which 
  contribution is sought from a joint tortfeasor, the claimant obviously must 
  prove facts sufficient under the statutes and the common law of his own state 
  to establish a right to contribution between wrongdoers.â€ [4] 
Section 15-38-20(D) of the Act provides as follows:

A tortfeasor who enters into a settlement with a claimant 
  is not entitled to recover contribution from another tortfeasor whose liability 
  for the injury or wrongful death is not extinguished by the settlement 
  nor in respect to any amount paid in a settlement which is in excess of what 
  was reasonable. [5] 

The trial court held that section 15-38-20 is ambiguous 
  about whether a tortfeasor who has reached a settlement with the injured party 
  on the underlying tort could bring a contribution action after the statute of 
  limitations has run on the injured partyâ€™s claim against the joint tortfeasor 
  even if the settlement did not cover the injured partyâ€™s damages.Â  In reaching 
  this conclusion, the trial court noted that the terms â€œextinguishâ€ and â€œdischargeâ€ 
  are not defined within the statute for purposes of the Act.Â  The trial court 
  then found G&P was entitled to contribution from Parks Auto based on Castillo 
  v. Roger Construction Co., [6]  in which the third circuit court of appeals 
  interpreted analogous sections of the Pennsylvania Contribution Among Tortfeasors 
  Act and gave the term â€œextinguishâ€ a liberal construction.
We, however, decline to follow Castillo 
  and note that later state cases in Pennsylvania have not adhered to this decision. 
  [7] Â  In addition, our review of case law from other jurisdictions indicates 
  the trial court incorrectly determined that section 15-38-20(D) is ambiguous. [8] Â  
The plain language of section 15-38-20(D) yields only one 
  interpretation, namely that extinguishment of the defending joint tortfeasorâ€™s 
  liability must have resulted directly from the settlement itself. [9] Â  We have found nothing in section 
  15-38-20, or, for that matter, any other part of the Act, that would suggest 
  that the running of the statute of limitations on an action arising from the 
  underlying tort would â€œextinguishâ€ a joint tortfeasorâ€™s liability so as to entitle 
  a settling tortfeasor to contribution. [10] Â  
Moreover, we agree with Parks Autoâ€™s argument that the running 
  of the statute of limitations in and of itself cannot operate to â€œextinguishâ€ 
  a tortfeasorâ€™s liability. [11] Â  Although, as G&P argues, a statute of limitations can 
  foreclose the right of a claimant to file suit, unlike a statute of repose, 
  it is subject to certain counter-assertions, such as waiver, tolling, and estoppel. [12] 
In the present case, there was no evidence of a release 
  that would discharge any liability of Parks Auto for claims asserted by The 
  Hartford or Wicks Broadcasting.Â  With regard to the agreement executed in connection 
  with G&Pâ€™s payment to RCC, that document purported to release only G&P 
  and any related entities.Â  None of these three claimants, then, agreed that 
  the payments received from G&P relieved Parks Auto of liability in the underlying 
  tort. [13] Â  
Given both the absence of a release as to Parks Auto and 
  the unappealed finding by the trial court that none of the payments by G&P 
  fully compensated any of the injured parties for their losses, we hold that, 
  as a matter of law, G&P has failed to establish entitlement to contribution 
  from Parks Auto under the South Carolina Uniform Contribution Among Tortfeasors 
  Act.
2.Â  Although the agreement executed by Parks Auto in 
  connection with the payment it received from G&P released â€œall other persons, 
  firms, and corporations, both known and unknown,â€ we agree with Parks Auto that 
  G&P cannot obtain contribution under the Act for this particular claim because 
  Parks Auto, the only alleged tortfeasor other than G&P, was also the injured 
  party and, as such, could not have been a tortfeasor as to its own injury, let 
  alone a joint tortfeasor. [14]  Because Parks Auto was not 
  a joint tortfeasor in this particular instance, there was no â€œcommon liability.â€Â Â Â  

Furthermore, we reject G&Pâ€™s argument that, notwithstanding 
  Parks Autoâ€™s status as the injured party, the award should be upheld because 
  G&P had a contractual right under the agreement to â€œseek and pursue indemnity 
  and/or contribution rights for all monies paid herein or otherwise.â€Â  Without 
  question, G&P had this right and exercised it.Â  With respect to all four 
  payments, including that made to Parks Auto, however, G&P requested only 
  contributionâ€”and not indemnity.Â  Because there was no common liability on which 
  to base a claim for contribution for payment of Parks Autoâ€™s own damages, G&P 
  was not entitled to this relief for this particular claim. 
  [15]  Â We therefore hold that, with respect to G&Pâ€™s payment of compensation 
  to Parks Auto, the trial court was incorrect in granting G&Pâ€™s request for 
  contribution.Â Â Â Â Â  
3.Â  Because our holding on G&Pâ€™s right to contribution 
  is dispositive of this appeal, we do not address Parks Autoâ€™s argument that 
  it was entitled to a directed verdict on the issue of negligence.
REVERSED.
CONNOR and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-38-10 through â€“70 (Supp. 2002).

 
   
    [2] Â  Vermeer v. Wood/Chuck Chipper, 336 S.C. 53, 68, 518 S.E.2d 
    301, 309 (Ct. App. 1999). 

 
   
    [3] Â  See Watson v. Sellers, 299 S.C. 426, 433, 385 S.E.2d 
    369, 373 (Ct. App. 1989) (noting that a particular act, being in derogation 
    of the common law, must be strictly construed).Â  

 
   
     
    [4] Â  18 Am. Jur. 2d Contribution Â§ 126, at 129 (1985).

 
   
    [5] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-38-20(D) (Supp. 2002) (emphasis added).

 
   [6] Â  560 F. 2d 1146 (3d Cir. 1977).

 
   
    [7] Â  See, e.g., Walton v. Avco, 610 A.2d 454, 461 (Pa. 
    1992) (â€œIf, . . . a settling defendant acts only to remove himself from the 
    uncertainties of litigation, he may not then ask the non-settling defendant 
    to â€˜cover his lossesâ€™ if, upon judgment, it turns out that he has made a bad 
    business decision.â€); Schuman v. Vitale, 602 A.2d 390, 392 (Pa. 1992) 
    (holding the Pennsylvania Legislature intended that â€œwhere there are two or 
    more joint tort-feasors and one of them settles with the injured person, such 
    settling joint tort-feasor may not recover contribution from the other non-settling 
    joint tort-feasors unless the settlement by the settling joint tort-feasor 
    extinguishes the liability of the non-settling joint tort-feasor to the injured 
    personâ€) (emphasis added).

 
   
    [8] Â  See, e.g., Pearson Bros. Co. v. VCV Engâ€™g & Supply, 
    Inc., 476 N.E.2d 73 (Ill. App. Ct. 1985).Â  In Pearson, the Appellate 
    Court of Illinois, in considering the application of an extinguishment requirement 
    that is analogous to that in section 15-38-20(D), stated as follows:
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  An obvious purpose of the [legislation concerning contribution 
    among joint tortfeasors] is to reduce the amount of litigation.Â  A limitation 
    on the right to obtain contribution ought to reduce the amount of litigation.Â  
    The situation where a statute of limitations runs on a joint tortfeasor . 
    . . is a rare occasion.Â  We do not choose to torture the language of 
    [the extinguishment requirement] to permit the seeking of contribution 
    here even though it might seem fair to do so.
  Id. 
    at 75 (emphasis added).

 
   
    [9] Â  See Vermeer, 336 S.C. at 69, 518 S.E.2d at 309 (noting 
    that because the joint tortfeasor had been dismissed by the injured party 
    with prejudice, the tortfeasor seeking contribution did not â€œextinguishâ€ the 
    joint tortfeasorâ€™s liability because â€œno liability . . . existed to be extinguishedâ€).

 
   
    [10] Â  To the contrary, the Act limits a tortfeasorâ€™s right to seek contribution 
    in such a way that is consistent with the requirement in section 15-38-20(D) 
    that the liability of the joint tortfeasor from whom contribution is sought 
    must have been â€œextinguished by the settlement.â€Â  See S.C. Code Ann. 
    Â§ 15-38-40(D) (Supp. 2002) (providing in pertinent part that, if there has 
    been no judgment against the tortfeasor seeking contribution arising from 
    the underlying tort, the tortfeasorâ€™s right of contribution is barred unless 
    the tortfeasor has â€œdischarged by payment the common liability within the 
    statute of limitations period applicable to claimantâ€™s right of action against 
    himâ€) (emphasis added).

 
   
    [11] Â  See Langley v. Pierce, 313 S.C. 401, 403-04, 438 
    S.E.2d 242, 243 (1993) (â€œâ€˜A statute of limitations is a procedural device 
    that operates as a defense to limit the remedy available from an existing 
    cause of action.Â  A statute of repose creates a substantive right in those 
    protected to be free from liability after a legislatively-determined period 
    of time.â€™â€) (citations omitted) (quoting Goad v. Celotex Corp., 831 
    F.2d 508, 511 (4th Cir. 1987).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

 
   
    [12] Â  Cf. Florence County Sch. Dist. # 2 v. Interkal, Inc., 
    348 S.C. 446, 453, 559 S.E.2d 866, 869 (Ct. App. 2002) (noting in passing 
    â€œthe proposition that the running of a statute of limitations against one 
    tortfeasor does not affect another tortfeasorâ€™s ability to sustain a contribution 
    actionâ€ and holding that â€œ[t]he Statute of Repose bars actions for contribution 
    under the Uniform Contribution Among Tortfeasors Act brought more than thirteen 
    years after the completion of an improvement to real propertyâ€).

 
   
    [13] Â  Thomas S. Nolan, the adjuster who resolved the various claims, 
    testified the payments represented a full and reasonable settlement of the 
    potential claims; however, he also admitted on cross-examination that 
    the respective claimants could potentially try to make additional claims.

 
   
    [14] Â  See Shipes v. Piggly Wiggly St. Andrews, 269 S.C. 
    479, 483, 238 S.E.2d 167, 168 (1977) (defining â€œdutyâ€ in a negligence case 
    as â€œthe obligation to conform to a particular standard of conduct toward anotherâ€) 
    (emphasis added).

 
   
    [15] Â  See First Gen. Servs. of Charleston v. Miller, 314 
    S.C. 439, 443-44, 445 S.E.2d 446, 449 (1994) (noting the requirement in section 
    15-38-10 that a tortfeasor must pay more than his or her pro rata share of 
    the â€œcommon liabilityâ€ to recover contribution).Â Â

title: USAA v. Litchfield
description: United Services Automobile Association ("USAA") brought this declaratory judgment action against Lesli Litchfield and Vernon Litchfield seeking a declaration that no basis exists for reforming Lesli Litchfield's automobile insurance policy to include underinsured motorist ("UIM") coverage.  The trial court granted USAA's motion for summary judgment.  The Litchfields appeal, contending USAA failed to make a meaningful offer of UIM coverage.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
United Services Automobile Association,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Lesli Litchfield and Vernon Litchfield,       
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
A.   Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3712
Heard November 6, 2003 â€“ Filed December 
  15, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Carl H. Jacobson, of Charleston, for Appellants.
William O. Sweeny, III and William R. Calhoun, Jr., both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  United Services Automobile 
  Association (â€œUSAAâ€) brought this declaratory judgment action against Lesli 
  Litchfield and Vernon Litchfield seeking a declaration that no basis exists 
  for reforming Lesli Litchfieldâ€™s automobile insurance policy to include underinsured 
  motorist (â€œUIMâ€) coverage.Â  The trial court granted USAAâ€™s motion for summary 
  judgment. The Litchfields appeal, contending USAA failed to make a meaningful 
  offer of UIM coverage.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
USAA sent Lesli Litchfield (then Lesli Tillman) 
  an automobile insurance policy on July 9, 1997.Â  USAA included an offer of UIM, 
  using form 333SC(10), a form prescribed by the Chief Insurance Commissioner 
  of South Carolina.Â  This form listed each and every limit of UIM coverage that 
  USAA had filed with and had been approved to sell by the South Carolina Department 
  of Insurance, instructed Litchfield how to select UIM coverage if she wished 
  it, and told her how she could later increase or decrease the limits of such 
  coverage.Â  The coversheet of the policy contained the following notice: â€œImportant 
  Notice!Â  SC law requires us to add . . . UIM to your policy in the same limits 
  as your liability unless you sign the attached offer of optional . . . UIM Form 
  333SC and return it to us within 30 days.â€
When Litchfield failed to respond, USAA issued her 
  a policy on August 19, 1997, that included UIM coverage in the amount of her 
  liability coverage.Â  Six months later, Litchfield telephoned USAA and asked 
  that it drop the UIM coverage from her policy.
USAA sent her a form annotated with the words â€œRejection 
  of UIM per phone conversationâ€ written across the bottom and asked her to sign, 
  date, and return it by mail.Â  Litchfield did so, returning the form on February 
  2, 1998.Â  USAA then prepared and sent to Litchfield an amended declaration that 
  reflected the deletion of the UIM coverage and the prorated, decreased premium 
  for the remainder of the policy period.
On October 5, 1999, while driving a rented automobile 
  in Hawaii, Litchfieldâ€™s husband was injured in a motor vehicle collision.Â  Litchfieldâ€™s 
  husband then presented a claim for UIM benefits against her USAA policy because 
  the damages he sustained allegedly exceed the $100,000.00 liability coverage 
  of the at-fault driver.
USAA instituted this declaratory judgment action 
  against the Litchfields, asserting Litchfield had effectively cancelled her 
  UIM coverage.Â  The latter counterclaimed, seeking to have the policy reformed 
  to include the UIM that Litchfield, almost two years previously, had specifically 
  asked be deleted from her policy.
The trial court granted USAA summary judgment, 
  finding the sole reason that Litchfieldâ€™s policy did not contain UIM coverage 
  at the time of the accident was because she had voluntarily elected to drop 
  it.Â  The Litchfields do not challenge this finding on appeal.Â  The Litchfields 
  claim that USAA did not make a valid offer of optional UIM coverage when she 
  purchased her coverage. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
We do not view this as an â€œoffer of UIM coverageâ€ 
  case. [1] Â  We are beyond the point of having to decide 
  whether USAA made a valid offer of UIM coverage to Litchfield.Â  This is because 
  Litchfield did in fact enjoy such coverage and in an amount up to the limits 
  of her liability coverage; however, she later, on her own initiative, voluntarily 
  decided to drop it.Â  Because Litchfield once had UIM coverage and later changed 
  the policy by dropping the UIM coverage from her policy, USAA was under no obligation 
  to make another offer of UIM coverage. 
  [2] Â  Moreover, we agree with the trial court that â€œ[i]t would make no sense 
  . . . for an insurer to be required to â€˜offerâ€™ a given coverage to an insured 
  who had contacted the insurance company for the specific purpose of dropping 
  that coverage.â€
Indeed, if Litchfield were allowed to prevail in 
  this instance, then anyone whose policy currently includes UIM coverage in an 
  amount less than his or her liability coverage would be able to question later 
  the sufficiency of the offer of UIM coverage and seek to have the policy reformed 
  in an attempt to increase the limits thereof.Â  The opportunity for fraud would 
  be enormous.
AFFIRMED.
StILWELL, J., concurs.Â  HUFF, J., dissents 
  in a separate opinion.
HUFF, J. (dissenting) :Â  I respectfully 
  dissent.Â  I disagree with the majorityâ€™s conclusion affirming the trial courtâ€™s 
  decision.Â  The trial court granted USAAâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  The 
  Litchfields appeal.Â  I believe the main issue on appeal concerns whether USAA 
  made a valid offer of UIM coverage.Â  I would hold that USAA did not make a valid 
  offer and reverse the trial courtâ€™s ruling.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In light of the fact that a determination as to 
  the existence of a valid offer is critical to this case I find it necessary 
  to provide a separate factual statement.Â  In July 1997, USAA issued an automobile 
  insurance policy to Lesli Litchfield, then known as Lesli Tillman, effective 
  July 10, 1997 through January 10, 1998.Â  The policy did not include UIM coverage.Â  
  The automobile policy packet sent to Litchfield did, however, include an offer 
  of UIM coverage.Â  The offer provided, in pertinent part:

Your automobile insurance policy 
  does not provide any underinsured motorists coverage.Â  You have, however, a 
  right to buy underinsured motorists coverage in limits up to the limits of liability 
  coverage you carry under your automobile insurance policy.Â  Limits of underinsured 
  motorists coverage, together with the additional premiums you will be charged 
  are shown upon this Form. 

The policy coversheet and the UIM offer both indicated 
  that, if the offer form was not completed and returned within thirty days, UIM 
  coverage would automatically be added to the policy at the same limits as Litchfieldâ€™s 
  liability limits, as required by law.Â  
The offer form gave the option of purchasing or 
  rejecting UIM coverage, and listed ten levels of bodily injury limits ranging 
  from $15,000/$30,000 to $1,000,000/$1,000,000 and seven levels of property damage 
  limits ranging from $5,000 to $500,000.Â  To select the desired levels of coverage 
  the applicant had to check the boxes next to the appropriate limits.Â  The parties 
  do not dispute that USAAâ€™s offer form listed every limit of UIM coverage USAA 
  is authorized by the South Carolina Department of Insurance to sell.Â  
Litchfield did not respond to 
  the initial offer of UIM coverage, so on August 19, 1997 USAA automatically 
  added the coverage to her policy, effective July 10, 1997.Â  On January 26, 1998, 
  Litchfield telephoned USAA and asked that the UIM coverage be dropped from her 
  policy.Â  USAA informed Litchfield that, to properly document her request, it 
  needed to have a statement in writing.Â  USAA sent Litchfield a standard form 
  offer of underinsured motorist coverage with the handwritten annotation â€œRejection 
  of UIM per phone conversation.â€Â  Litchfield promptly executed the form declining 
  coverage and mailed it back to USAA.Â  Shortly thereafter, USAA prepared and 
  sent Litchfield an Amended Declaration, reflecting the deletion of the UIM coverage.Â  

On October 5, 1999, Litchfieldâ€™s husband, Vernon 
  Litchfield, was seriously injured in an automobile collision in Hawaii.Â  The 
  liability carrier for the at-fault vehicle tendered its limits of liability 
  coverage.Â  Mr. Litchfield subsequently presented a claim for UIM benefits against 
  his wifeâ€™s USAA policy, asserting the policy should be reformed to include $50,000 
  in UIM coverage because USAA failed to make a meaningful offer of UIM coverage.Â  

USAA denied there was any UIM coverage, asserting 
  that Lesli Litchfield had changed her policy to delete UIM coverage and USAA 
  was not required to make any further UIM offers following the change.Â  The Litchfields 
  sought reformation of the policy to include UIM coverage on the grounds that 
  USAA failed to make a meaningful offer of UIM coverage.Â  
The trial court granted summary judgment to USAA 
  finding that the sole reason the policy did not provide UIM coverage at the 
  time of the accident was that Litchfield voluntarily elected to drop it, and 
  USAA was not required to offer Litchfield that same coverage when she telephoned 
  them requesting that UIM coverage be deleted.Â  The court further found that 
  the form offering UIM coverage sent to Litchfield in July 1997, when her policy 
  was initially issued, complied with South Carolina law such that the offer was 
  meaningful and effective.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Litchfields assert that USAAâ€™s offer of UIM 
  coverage was not a meaningful offer under South Carolina law, and because no 
  meaningful offer was made to Mrs. Litchfield, it is irrelevant that she rejected 
  the UIM coverage. [3] Â  I agree.
In finding USAA was not required to offer Mrs. 
  Litchfield UIM coverage after she elected to drop the coverage, the trial court 
  relied on Â§ 38-77-350(C) of the South Carolina Code, governing the offer of 
  optional coverages.Â  This section provides, â€œAn automobile insurer is not required 
  to make a new offer of coverage on any automobile insurance policy which renews, 
  extends, changes, supercedes, or replaces an existing policy.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 38-77-350 (C) (2002).Â  It is clear, however, that this subsection envisions 
  that an effective past offer has already been made.Â  See Antley v. 
  Nobel Ins. Co., 350 S.C. 621, 635, 567 S.E.2d 872, 879-80 (Ct. App. 2002) 
  (while an insurer is not required to make a new offer of optional coverage where 
  the policy renews an existing policy, the insurer still bears the burden of 
  demonstrating a meaningful offer of the optional coverage was made at some point 
  in the past);Â  McDonald v. S.C. Farm Bureau Ins. Co., 336 S.C. 120, 125, 
  518 S.E.2d 624, 626 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œWhere Section 38-77-350(C) states the 
  insured is not required to make a â€˜newâ€™ offer, it clearly envisions the circumstances 
  where the insurer has already made an â€˜oldâ€™ offer.â€);Â  Ackerman v. Travelers 
  Indem. Co., 318 S.C. 137, 142, 456 S.E.2d 408, 411 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œ[T]he 
  only reasonable way to interpret the language in Â§ 38-77-350(C) is to recognize 
  that the insurer may rely on the effective past offers it has given to 
  its insureds when these insureds continue coverage with the same insurer.â€) 
  (emphasis added).Â Â Â  
We thus turn to the question of whether USAA made 
  a meaningful offer to Litchfield in the past.Â  The Litchfields argue USAAâ€™s 
  offer did not comply with the requirements of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 (2002) 
  and pertinent South Carolina case law.Â  We agree.
Section 38-77-160 requires automobile insurance 
  carriers to offer, at the option of the insured, UIM coverage â€œup to the limits 
  of the insured liability coverage to provide coverage in the event that damages 
  are sustained in excess of the liability limits carried by an at-fault insured 
  or underinsured motorist.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 (2002).Â  This statute 
  has been construed to mandate that the insured â€œbe provided with adequate information, 
  and in such a manner, as to allow the insured to make an intelligent decision 
  of whether to accept or reject the coverage.â€Â  Burch v. S.C. Farm Bureau 
  Mut. Ins. Co., 351 S.C. 342, 345, 569 S.E.2d 400, 402 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting 
  State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Wannamaker, 291 S.C. 518, 521, 354 
  S.E.2d 555, 556 (1987)).Â  Specifically, our courts have interpreted this section 
  as requiring insurers to offer UIM coverage to the insured in any amount 
  up to the insuredâ€™s liability coverage.Â  Id. at 345, 569 S.E.2d at 402.
To determine whether an insurer has complied with 
  its duty to offer optional coverages and thus make a meaningful offer of UIM 
  coverage, the court must consider the following factors: (1) the insurerâ€™s notification 
  process must be commercially reasonable, whether oral or in writing; (2) the 
  insurer must specify the limits of optional coverage and not merely offer additional 
  coverage in general terms; (3) the insurer must intelligibly advise the insured 
  of the nature of the optional coverage; and (4) the insured must be told that 
  optional coverages are available for an additional premium. Wannamaker, 
  291 S.C. at 521, 354 S.E.2d at 556.
The insurer bears the burden of establishing it 
  presented a meaningful offer of UIM coverage.Â  Butler v. Unisun Ins. Co., 
  323 S.C. 402, 405, 475 S.E.2d 758, 759 (1996).Â  If the insurer fails to make 
  a meaningful offer of UIM coverage, the court will reform the insuredâ€™s policy 
  to include UIM coverage up to the limits of the insuredâ€™s liability coverage.Â  
  Dewart v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 296 S.C. 150, 153, 370 S.E.2d 
  915, 916 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  A noncomplying offer has the legal effect of no offer 
  at all.Â  Hanover Ins. Co. v. Horace Mann Ins. Co., 301 S.C. 55, 57, 389 
  S.E.2d 657, 659 (1990).
USAA claims its offer of UIM coverage satisfied 
  the requirements for a meaningful offer because its form listed every level 
  of coverage the company was authorized by the South Carolina Department of Insurance 
  to sell.Â  I disagree.
In Bower v. National General Insurance Co., 
  our supreme court ruled that an offer of UIM coverage must inform the insured 
  â€œthat any limits up to the liability limits could be purchased.â€ 351 
  S.C. 112, 119, 569 S.E.2d 313, 316 (2002) (emphasis in original).Â  In that case, 
  the insurerâ€™s offer form stated, in language virtually identical to the language 
  in USAAâ€™s form, that the insured had the â€œright to buy underinsured motorist 
  coverage in limits up to the limits of liability coverage you will carry under 
  your automobile insurance policy.â€Â  The form further provided, â€œThe limits of 
  underinsured motorist coverage, together with the additional premiums you will 
  be charged, are shown upon this Form.â€ Id. at 114-15, 569 S.E.2d at 314.Â  
  The form listed four bodily injury limits and fourÂ  property damage limits with 
  the applicable premiums.Â  Id. at 115, 569 S.E.2d at 314.Â  The form then 
  included blank spaces to fill in requested UIM bodily injury limits and UIM 
  property damage limits.Â  Id.Â  The supreme court concluded, because the 
  language of National Generalâ€™s form failed to inform the insured that UIM coverage 
  in any amount up to the insuredâ€™s liability coverage could be purchased, 
  the offer could not be considered meaningful. Id. at 119, 569 S.E.2d 
  at 316.Â  Though the form did not explicitly state that â€œallâ€ of the available 
  limits of UIM coverage were listed, the court found that a reasonable person 
  would conclude that the options listed were the only ones available. Id. 
  at 118, 569 S.E.2d at 316.
As in Bower, the offer of UIM coverage in 
  the instant case did not inform Litchfield of her right to purchase the coverage 
  in any amount up to the limits of her liability coverage.Â  The supreme 
  court in Bower clearly held that the offer must â€œinform an insured that 
  â€˜underinsured motorist coverage in any amount up to the insuredâ€™s liability 
  coverageâ€™ is what is actually being offered.â€Â  Id. at 119, 569 S.E.2d 
  at 316 (emphasis in original).Â  USAAâ€™s form failed to provide this explicit 
  information to the insured, listing only the fixed levels of coverage it had 
  obtained authorization from the Department of Insurance to sell.
USAA argues Bower is distinguishable because, 
  unlike USAAâ€™s offer, the UIM coverage offer at issue in Bower only listed 
  examples of the levels of coverage, not all of the limits the insurer was authorized 
  to sell.Â  We find a careful reading of Bower shows no distinction between 
  the two cases, asÂ  Bower specifically relied on this courtâ€™s decision 
  in Wilkes v. Freeman, 334 S.C. 206, 512 S.E.2d 530 (Ct. App. 1999). In 
  Wilkes, this courtÂ  found a meaningful offer of UIM coverage was not 
  made where, as in the present case, the offer form listed all of the 
  limits the insurer was authorized to sell.Â  The offer of UIM coverage in Wilkes 
  stated that â€œ[a]ll of the limits of underinsured motor vehicle coverage 
  we sell, together with the additional premiums you will be charged, are shown 
  on this form.â€Â  Id. at 210, 512 S.E.2d at 532 (emphasis in original).Â  
  Although the insurerâ€™s offer form listed all the limits of UIM coverage the 
  insurer sold, the court found that the form failed â€œto provide any indication 
  that applicants may request other coverage amounts.â€ Id.Â  Because the 
  insurer failed to provide the insured an opportunity to request UIM coverage 
  at alternate coverage amounts, the insurer failed to â€œoffer UIM coverage â€˜up 
  toâ€™ the limits of [the insuredâ€™s] liability coverage.â€Â  Id. at 212, 512 
  S.E.2d at 533.  [4] 
I am mindful that, by explicitly listing each level 
  of UIM coverage it was authorized to sell, USAA was likely attempting to make 
  the insuredâ€™s choice of UIM coverage limits easier rather than more difficult 
  to understand.Â  I am constrained, however, by recent precedent which requires 
  that an offer of UIM coverage clearly inform the insured that UIM coverage may 
  be purchased in any amount up to the limits of liability coverage.Â  No 
  exception has been carved out for cases such as the present, in which the offer 
  lists every limit of UIM coverage the insurer is legally authorized to sell.Â  
  As noted above, our courts declined to provide for such an exception when those 
  circumstances arose in the Wilkes case.Â  
Based on the standing case law, I would hold USAAâ€™s 
  offer of UIM coverage did not sufficiently inform Mrs. Litchfield of her right 
  to purchase UIM coverage in any amount, and I am thus compelled to rule the 
  offer was not meaningful.Â  I would reverse the trial courtâ€™s order granting 
  summary judgment and remand the case with the instruction that Mrs. Litchfieldâ€™s 
  USAA policy be reformed to include UIM coverage at the appropriate limits.

 
   [1]  Because we do not consider this 
    an â€œofferâ€ case, we do not reach the issue of whether the offer made by USAA 
    to Litchfield was valid to begin with.Â  Cf., however, Norwood v. 
    Allstate Ins. Co., 327 S.C. 503, 506-507, 489 S.E.2d 661, 663 (Ct. App. 
    1997) (holding an automobile insurer made a valid offer of UIM coverage under 
    a policy with liability limits of 25/50/25 where insured offered UIM coverage 
    of 15/30/5, 15/30/10, and 25/50/10, and offer form indicated insured could 
    purchase UIM coverage â€œup toâ€ her liability limits and instructed her how 
    to increase or decrease her limits of UIM coverage); cf. also 
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-73-470 (Supp. 2002) (â€œThere is no requirement for an insurer 
    or an agent to offer underinsured motorist coverage at limits less than the 
    statutorily required bodily injury or property damage limits.â€).

 
   
    [2]  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-350(c) (2002) (â€œAn automobile insurer 
    is not required to make a new offer of coverage on any automobile insurance 
    policy which renews, extends, changes, supersedes, or replaces an existing 
    policy.â€).

 
   
    [3] USAA asserts the Litchfields failed to address the trial courtâ€™s finding 
    â€œthat the sole reason that [Mrs. Litchfieldâ€™s] policy did not provide coverage 
    at the time of the accident was that she had voluntarily elected to drop it.â€Â  
    It therefore contends the Litchfields have abandoned this issue.Â  However, 
    after review of the Litchfieldsâ€™ brief, I find they have sufficiently challenged 
    this ruling by maintaining that Mrs. Litchfieldâ€™s rejection or deletion of 
    the UIM coverage is irrelevant because there was no meaningful offer made 
    by USAA in the first instance. Â 

 
   
    [4] It should further be noted that, unlike the form in this case, the 
    form in Bower included a blank space for the insured to specify the 
    exact limits the insured desired.Â  The Bower dissent partially relied 
    upon this distinction in maintaining that a meaningful offer of UIM coverage 
    was made.Â  Bower, 351 S.C. at 121, 569 S.E.2d at 317.Â Â
