THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Roy McDowell,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Travelers Property & Casualty Company, and Travelers Indemnity Company 
        of Illinois,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Donald W. Beatty, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3718
Heard October 7, 2003 â€“ Filed December 
  22, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James C. Spears, Jr., of Spartanburg, 
  for Appellant.
Robert D. Moseley, 
  Jr., of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  


 HOWARD, J.:Â  Roy McDowell was 
  injured in a motor vehicle collision while driving a tractor-trailer owned by 
  his employer, Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company (â€œGoodyearâ€) and insured by 
  Travelers Property & Casualty Company and Travelers Indemnity Company of 
  Illinois (collectively â€œTravelersâ€).Â  McDowell brought this declaratory judgment 
  action against Travelers seeking to reform the insurance contract, alleging 
  Travelers failed to make a meaningful offer of underinsured motorist (â€œUIMâ€) 
  coverage to Goodyear.Â  The circuit court granted summary judgment to Travelers, 
  concluding, under any view of the evidence, a meaningful offer of UIM coverage 
  was made to and knowingly rejected by Goodyear.Â  McDowell appeals, arguing the 
  circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to Travelers.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
McDowellâ€™s suit arises from a traffic accident 
  in which he received injuries rendering him totally and permanently disabled.Â  
  At the time of the accident, McDowell was operating a tractor-trailer owned 
  by Goodyear.Â  
The insurance company for the at-fault 
  driver paid McDowell $49,000.Â  Because McDowell alleged damages exceeding this 
  amount, McDowell sought to recover UIM coverage under Goodyearâ€™s policy with 
  Travelers.Â  Travelers denied the claim, alleging Goodyear had rejected UIM coverage.Â  
  McDowell then brought this declaratory judgment action, alleging Travelers failed 
  to make a meaningful offer of UIM coverage to its insured, and thus, the policy 
  should be reformed to provide UIM coverage in the amount of the liability limits 
  of the policy.Â  
Travelers moved for summary judgment, arguing it 
  made a meaningful offer of UIM coverage pursuant to both South Carolina Code 
  Annotated section 38-77-350 (A) (Supp. 2002) and State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. 
  Co. v. Wannamaker, 291 S.C. 518, 521, 354 S.E.2d 555, 556 (1987).Â  Â Â Â Â 
In granting summary judgment to Travelers, the 
  circuit court held Travelers made a meaningful offer of UIM coverage which Goodyear 
  rejected.Â  McDowell appeals. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œSummary judgment is proper when there is no genuine 
  issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to a judgment 
  as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; South Carolina Prop. and Cas. Guar. 
  Assoc. v. Yensen, 345 S.C. 512, 518, 548 S.E.2d 880, 883 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
  To determine whether any material fact exists, â€œthe evidence and all inferences 
  which can be reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable 
  to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Yensen, 345 S.C. at 518, 548 S.E.2d at 883.Â  
  â€œSummary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of 
  the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œAn 
  appellate court reviews the granting of summary judgment under the same standard 
  applied by the trial court.â€Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
McDowell argues the circuit court erred 
  by holding Travelers made a meaningful offer of UIM coverage as required by 
  South Carolina Code Annotated section 38-77-160 (Supp. 2002).Â  McDowell contends 
  Travelersâ€™ failure to list the range of premiums for the available limits on 
  its form offering UIM coverage to Goodyear, as is required in section 38-77-350(A), 
  required reformation of the policy to include UIM coverage in the amount of 
  the liability limits.Â  Although we agree Travelers did not meet the requirements 
  of section 38-77-350(A), we disagree with McDowellâ€™s assertion that this alone 
  denotes failure to make a meaningful offer warranting reformation of the policy.Â  
  Furthermore, viewing the evidence in a light most favorable to McDowell, we 
  find the circuit court correctly held Travelers made a meaningful offer of UIM 
  coverage to Goodyear, which Goodyear rejected.
South Carolina law requires automobile insurance 
  carriers to offer â€œat the option of the insured, underinsured motorist coverage 
  up to the limits of the insured liability coverage to provide coverage in the 
  event that damages are sustained in excess of the liability limits carried by 
  an at-fault insured or underinsured motorist.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 (Supp. 
  2002).Â  â€œIf the insurer fails to comply with its statutory duty to make a meaningful 
  offer to the insured, the policy will be reformed, by operation of law, to include 
  UIM coverage up to the limits of liability insurance carried by the insured.â€Â  
  Butler v. Unisun, 323 S.C. 402, 405, 475 S.E.2d 758, 760 (1996).Â  When 
  an insurer fails to make a meaningful offer, the insured is entitled to reform 
  the policy to reflect coverage in an amount equal to the liability limits on 
  the insuredâ€™s policy.Â  Todd v. Federated Mut. Ins. Co., 305 S.C. 395, 
  399, 409 S.E.2d 361, 364 (1991).Â  
All insurers must complete a form approved 
  by the insurance commissioner when making the required offer of optional coverage 
  to applicants for automobile insurance policies.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-350(A) 
  (Supp. 2002).Â  The form must include:

(1)Â Â  a brief and concise explanation of the coverage,
(2)Â  a list of available limits and the range of 
  premiums for the limits,
(3)Â  a space for the insured to mark whether the insured 
  chooses to accept or reject the coverage and a space for the insured to select 
  the limits of coverage he desires,
(4) a space for the insured to sign the form which 
  acknowledges that he has been offered the optional coverages,
(5) the mailing address and telephone number of the 
  Insurance Department which the applicant may contact if the applicant has any 
  questions that the insurance agent is unable to answer.

Id. Â (emphasis added).Â  The statute 
  further provides:

If this form is properly completed and executed by the named 
  insured it is conclusively presumed that there was an informed, knowing selection 
  of coverage and neither the insurance company nor any insurance agent has any 
  liability to the named insured or any other insured under the policy for the 
  insuredâ€™s failure to purchase any optional coverage or higher limits.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-350(B) (Supp. 2002).Â  Therefore, 
  an insurer who uses a properly executed offer form that complies with section 
  38-77-350(A) enjoys a conclusive presumption a meaningful offer was made.Â  Id.; 
  Antley v. Nobel Ins. Co., 350 S.C. 621, 632, 567 S.E.2d 872, 878 (Ct. 
  App. 2002).Â  However, the insurer may not benefit from the protections of section 
  38-77-350(B) if the form does not comply with the statute.Â  Osborne v. Allstate 
  Ins. Co., 319 S.C. 479, 486, 462 S.E.2d 291, 295 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

To avoid the necessity of having to comply 
  with the array of self-insurance requirements from state to state, Goodyear 
  entered into a contract with Travelers whereby Travelers issued certificates 
  of insurance allowing Goodyear to comply with the insurance regulations of the 
  various states in which it operated while remaining ultimately liable for one-hundred 
  percent of the claims paid.Â  Under this contract, Goodyear pays Travelers an 
  administrative fee and reimburses Travelers one-hundred percent of the amount 
  paid in adjusting its claims during the policy period.Â  In essence, the contract 
  serves as a pass-through accounting mechanism to assist Goodyear in its claims 
  management process. [1] Â Â Â Â  
When Travelers and Goodyear signed this contract, 
  Travelers provided a form offering UIM coverage to Goodyear.Â  The form included 
  an explanation of UIM insurance, ranges of limits, and instructions for seeking 
  limits not shown.Â  The form had blanks for listing premium amounts for the various 
  limits.Â  Travelers did not fill in these blanks as required by subsection (A)(2).Â  
  Thus, the form did not comply with the statute and Travelers does not enjoy 
  the statutory presumption that it made a meaningful offer of UIM. See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-350(B); Antley, 350 S.C. at 632, 567 S.E.2d at 
  878.Â  However, failing to comply with the statute does not necessarily require 
  reformation of the policy.Â  Rather, the insurer bears the burden of establishing 
  it made a meaningful offer of UIM pursuant to section 38-77-160 and Wannamaker.Â  
  See Butler, 323 S.C. at 405, 475 S.E.2d at 760 (holding the insurer 
  has the initial burden of proving that a meaningful offer of optional coverage 
  had been made to the insured.); Antley, 350 S.C. at 632, 567 S.E.2d at 
  878 (â€œThe burden of proving a meaningful offer of optional coverage was made 
  rests with the insurer.â€). 
 Our Supreme Court has adopted a four-part 
  test to determine whether an insurerâ€™s offer of optional UIM coverage is sufficiently 
  meaningful to satisfy the requirements of section 38-77-160.Â  To constitute 
  a meaningful offer of UIM coverage, â€œ(1) the insurerâ€™s notification process 
  must be commercially reasonable, whether oral or in writing;Â  (2) the insurer 
  must specify the limits of optional coverage and not merely offer additional 
  coverage in general terms;Â  (3) the insurer must intelligibly advise the insured 
  of the nature of the optional coverage; and (4) the insured must be told that 
  optional coverages are available for an additional premium.â€ Â Wannamaker, 
  291 S.C. at 521, 354 S.E.2d at 556.Â  
McDowellâ€™s only contention under the 
  Wannamaker analysis is that Travelers failed to provide the premium amounts 
  for the optional UIM coverage.Â  Although the offer form contained no premium 
  amounts in the blanks provided, the contractual agreement between Goodyear and 
  Travelers includes a detailed formula for calculating the premium for UIM coverage.Â  
  Both Goodyear and Travelers contend under this mathematical formula the premiums 
  were readily ascertainable because the amount paid by Goodyear would have been 
  equal to the amount of the claims Travelers paid for underinsured motorist benefits 
  on Goodyearâ€™s behalf, together with an administrative fee.Â  
Eldrich Carr, Goodyearâ€™s Global Risk 
  Manager responsible for ensuring Goodyearâ€™s company vehicles comply with state 
  insurance requirements, averred he is experienced in matters dealing with liability, 
  UIM coverage, and other types of vehicle insurance, and is fully aware of the 
  nature and purpose of UIM coverage.Â  In his affidavit, Carr acknowledged that 
  any premium for UIM coverage quoted on the UIM offer form would necessarily 
  be zero because the premium is equivalent to one-hundred percent of the claims 
  paid during the period of the contract.Â  Therefore, Carr stated Goodyear was 
  fully aware of the costs of the coverage and the available amounts, and thus, 
  â€œGoodyear made a knowing and informed decision in rejecting underinsured motorist 
  coverage.â€Â  Carr further explained Goodyear elected not to obtain UIM coverage 
  in South Carolina because Goodyear provides workersâ€™ compensation and other 
  benefits for employees injured on the job.Â  Essentially, Goodyear viewed UIM 
  coverage as an additional employee benefit it did not want to provide.Â  
The arrangement between Goodyear 
  and Travelers clearly demonstrates Goodyear understood the limits of optional 
  coverage and the costs associated therewith, as required by Wannamaker.Â  
  Therefore, the circuit court did not err by granting summary judgment.Â  
CONCLUSION
Although Travelersâ€™ offer failed 
  to meet the requirements of section 38-77-350(A) and Travelers is not entitled 
  to the statutory presumption that a meaningful offer was made, Carrâ€™s uncontroverted 
  affidavit on behalf of Goodyear affirming a meaningful offer was made and acknowledging 
  Goodyear made a knowing and informed decision to reject UIM coverage conclusively 
  satisfies Travelersâ€™ burden of proof. 
Â Therefore, the decision of the circuit court isÂ  

AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  This arrangement allowed Goodyear to meet these various state insurance 
    requirements without qualifying as self-insured in each state by reporting 
    Travelers as its insurer.Â  However, in rendering summary judgment, the circuit 
    court concluded the contractual arrangement between Travelers and Goodyear 
    did not constitute an insurance policy because there was no transfer of risk 
    to Travelers.Â  On appeal, McDowell contends the circuit court erred by reaching 
    this conclusion.Â  Because we hold a meaningful offer was made in any event, 
    we need not address this issue.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Wayne Schmidt and Terri J. Schmidt,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Michael C. Courtney and Kemper Sports of Crowfield, Inc. d/b/a Crowfield 
  Golf & Country Club and Westvaco Development Corporations, 
Of Whom Kemper Sports of Crowfield, Inc. d/b/a Crowfield Golf & Country 
  Club, is,        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3719
Heard December 9, 2003 â€“ Filed December 
  22, 2003

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
Joseph F. Kent, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellants.
Stephen E. Darling and C. Bowen Horger, II, of Charleston, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â  Wayne Schmidt (Schmidt) and Terri J. Schmidt initiated 
  a negligence action against Michael Courtney for injuries Schmidt sustained 
  when he was struck in the head by a golf ball while roofing a house located 
  adjacent to a golf course.Â  Kemper Sports of Crowfield, Inc. (Kemper Sports) 
  was later joined on claims of negligent design, operation, and maintenance of 
  the golf course.Â  The circuit court judge granted Kemper Sportsâ€™ motion for 
  summary judgment.Â  Schmidt appeals.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On August 27, 1998, [1]  Schmidt 
  was roofing a house located at 113 Waveney Circle in the Hamlets section of 
  the Crowfield Development in Goose Creek, South Carolina.Â  The home is adjacent 
  to the Crowfield Golf and Country Club, which is owned and operated by Kemper 
  Sports.Â  Several oak trees stand between the house and golf course.
While Schmidt was roofing, Courtney was playing golf at the 
  Crowfield Golf and Country Club.Â  When Courtney made his tee shot on the Number 
  11 fairway, he hooked his ball, causing it to fly out of the boundaries of the 
  course and over to the house where Schmidt was working.Â  The golf ball struck 
  Schmidt in the back of his head and knocked him unconscious.Â  A fellow worker 
  caught Schmidt and prevented him from falling off the roof.Â  Schmidt suffered 
  permanent brain damage from the injury and has been unable to work since the 
  accident.
Schmidt initially filed a negligence suit against Courtney.Â  
  Schmidt later joined Kemper Sports in the action, alleging negligent design, 
  construction, operation, and maintenance of the golf course.Â  After filing its 
  answer, Kemper Sports then moved for summary judgment. 
At the summary judgment hearing, Schmidtâ€™s counsel, Joseph F. Kent, presented 
  information regarding an expert witness he located on May 7, 2002, just a few 
  weeks after Kent received notice of the motion for summary judgment.Â  The expert 
  witness, Gerald W. Pirkl, specializes in golf course safety, design, and maintenance.Â  
  Kent professed: â€œWe were very long in finding this gentleman, Your Honor.Â  
  I believe that before the case is over that it is going to turn out that Mr. 
  Pirkl is the most experienced person by way of expert witnesses in this area.â€Â  
  Kent requested the court consider his affidavit which identified Pirkl and 
  set forth what Pirkl would likely state during testimony.Â  In his affidavit, 
  Kent declared:

I, Joseph F. Kent, counsel for the Plaintiffs in this action, having been duly 
  sworn do depose and state as a proffer of evidence in this case, as follows:
1.Â  Full and complete diagnosis of the closed head brain 
  injuries sustained by Wayne Schmidt while working at the residence known as 
  113 Waveney was not accomplished until about the first of December 1999.
2.Â  Counsel knows of no cases in this jurisdiction concerning 
  the liability for negligent golf course design, maintenance or operation.
3.Â  Counsel has found relatively few cases arising in the 
  country from claims of negligent golf course design, maintenance or operation 
  resulting in personal injuries to innocent parties outside of the bounds and 
  property of golf courses.
4.Â  Counsel has testimony of experienced golfers and an 
  expert in the design of golf courses that foreseeable fields of play for tee 
  shots often extend beyond the bounds of certain fairway boundaries and that 
  such an extended field of play was foreseeable for the fairway and tee boxes 
  in this case.
5.Â  Counsel has retained an expert in golf course design, 
  Gerald W. Pirkl, of Dana Point, California who counsel believes will testify 
  that the design of the fairway and tee boxes in this case bring the house at 
  113 Waveney Circle into a foreseeable area of play as counsel understands that 
  area to be defined by the United States Golf Association.
6.Â  Counsel believes that the constructed contour and topography 
  of the fairway in this case eliminates or substantially reduces the opportunity 
  to play a first shot on the subject hole on the design centerline of the fairway.
7.Â  Counsel believes that the said expert will further testify 
  that tee shots from the most distant tee box position at the fairway in question 
  reduces the available shot angle for fairway center line both as that line was 
  designed and perceived by golfers in the tee boxes.
8.Â  Counsel believes that the evidence in this case will 
  be that together with the house location of the house in the predictable field 
  of play for this fairway, that the golf course operator failed to provide adequate 
  screening or fairway map information to reasonably guard and protect against 
  innocent parties outside of the golf course coming within the predictable flight 
  of tee shots from the fairway in this case.
9.Â  Counsel has already begun to shoot aerial photographs 
  of the subject fairway and tee boxes necessary for a written opinion with specifications 
  concerning the deficiencies of the design, maintenance and operation of the 
  Defendant Kemper in this case.
10.Â  Counsel anticipates a first written report from his 
  expert landscape architect within about two weeks and supplemental discovery 
  responses of aerial photography on May 13, 2002.

Kent explained that he expected a final report from Pirkl â€œbefore the end of 
  th[e] month.â€Â  The judge determined the issue of the expert witness was not

  whether negligence on the part of Kemper Sports was the proximate cause of Schmidtâ€™s

  is needed to determine these issues, the trial court erred in granting Kemper 
  Sportsâ€™ motion for summary judgment.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial 
  judge is
REVERSED and REMANDED.
 GOOLSBY, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   [1]  
    The order of the circuit judge, as well as the first and second amended complaints, 
    reference August 27, 1998, as the date Schmidt was hit by the errant golf 
    ball.Â  However, the Appellantsâ€™ brief and the Respondentâ€™s brief provide that 
    August 28, 1998, was the date Schmidt was injured.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Keith P. Quigley and Donna Quigley, individually 
        and Donna Quigley, the duly appointed Guardian ad Litem for Kealy Quigley, 
        a minor under the age of fourteen years,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
John A. Rider, M.D. and Medical Park Pediatricians, 
        P.A.,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3720
Heard October 9, 2003 â€“ Filed December 
  22, 2003

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
James Edward Bell, III, of Sumter; for Appellants.
Hugh W. Buyck, Robert H. Hood, Roy P. Maybank, Deborah H. 
  Sheffield, all of Charleston; for Respondents.
      
    
  


HOWARD, J.:   
Keith P. 
  Quigley, individually, and Donna Quigley, individually and on behalf of her 
  minor child, Kealy Quigley (â€œKealyâ€), brought this medical malpractice suit 
  against John A. Rider, M.D. and Medical Park Pediatricians, P.A. (collectively 
  â€œRiderâ€), alleging Rider committed malpractice by negligently administering 
  a second and third diptheria-pertussis-tetanus (â€œDPTâ€) shot to Kealy after she 
  displayed an adverse reaction to the first shot. 
  [1] Â  The circuit court dismissed the suit, holding the court did not have 
  subject matter jurisdiction because Kealyâ€™s injuries were vaccine-related and 
  were thus barred by the National Childhood Vaccine Injury Compensation Act, 
  42 U.S.C.A. Â§ 300aa-1 to 300aa-34 (1988 as amended) (â€œthe Actâ€). Donna Quigley 
  appeals on behalf of Kealy (â€œQuigleyâ€), arguing Kealyâ€™s injuries were not vaccine-related 
  and Rider is equitably estopped from asserting the Act as a bar to the litigation.Â  
  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Rider gave Kealy her first DPT shot in 
  December 1988.Â  Shortly thereafter, Kealy had adverse reactions to the shot.Â  
  Quigley alleges that Rider knew of these adverse reactions but administered 
  a second and third DPT shot to Kealy, both of which manifested corresponding 
  adverse reactions.Â  Subsequently, Kealy was diagnosed with severe mental and 
  physical retardation, which Quigley attributes to the DPT shots.Â  
Quigley filed this 
  action, alleging Rider was negligent by administering the second and third DPT 
  shots.Â  Additionally, the complaint alleged Rider negligently failed to: 1) 
  notify the Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services (â€œthe Secretaryâ€) 
  regarding Kealyâ€™s reactions to the shots pursuant to 42 U.S.C.A. Â§Â§ 300aa-25(a) 
  & (b); [2]  and 2) inform 
  Quigley of the dangers of the vaccine pursuant to 42 U.C.S.A. Â§Â§ 300aa-26(c) 
  & (d). [3] Â  
Rider moved for dismissal, arguing the 
  circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction over the claim.Â  The court 
  granted the motion, ruling the Act required Quigley to file a petition with 
  the Federal Claims Court prior to seeking state court remedies.Â  Quigley appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.                  
  General Overview of the Act
Congress created the Act in 1986 for the purpose of establishing 
  an efficient scheme of recovery for injuries and deaths traceable to vaccines, 
  while providing protection for manufacturers and administrators of the vaccines.Â  
  See H.R. Rep. No. 99-908, at 4 (1986), reprinted in, 1986 U.S.C.C.A.N. 
  6344, 6345 (â€œWhile most of the Nationâ€™s children enjoy greater benefit from 
  immunization programs, a small but significant number have been gravely injured. 
  These children are often without a source of payment or compensation for their 
  medical and rehabilitative needs, and they and their families have resorted 
  in greater numbers to the tort system for some form of financial relief.â€); 
  Shalala v. Whitecotton, 514 U.S. 268, 269-70 (1995) (citing H.R. Rep. 
  No. 99-908, at 3-7 (1986)) (â€œFor injuries and deaths traceable to vaccinations, 
  the Act establishes a scheme of recovery designed to work faster and with greater 
  ease than the civil tort system.â€); Schafer v. American Cyanamid Co., 
  20 F.3d 1, 4 (1st Cir. 1994) (â€œThe Act seeks to achieve its cost-reducing purpose, 
  not by denying compensation to victims . . . but by reducing the litigation 
  and insurance costs related to lengthy, complex tort procedures and random large 
  tort awards. The Act therefore imposes substantive and procedural limitations 
  upon tort actions.â€); see also H.R. Rep. No. 99- 908, at 6-7 (1986), 
  reprinted in, 1986 U.S.C.C.A.N. 6344, 6348-49 (stating one of the primary 
  purposes of the Act is to protect the vaccine market against the instability 
  and uncertainty of tort litigation).
To meet the clearly stated goals of Congress, 
  the Act provides a remedial scheme whereby a person who sustains vaccine-related 
  injuries after the effective date of the Act must apply to the Federal Claims 
  Court for compensation pursuant to the Act prior to seeking traditional tort 
  remedies through state and federal courts.Â  Â§Â§ 300aa-11(a)(2)(A)(i) and (ii); 
  see Shalala, 514 U.S. at 270 (citing Â§ 300aa-11) (â€œA claimant 
  alleging that more than $1,000 in damages resulted from a vaccination after 
  the Actâ€™s effective date in 1988 must exhaust the Actâ€™s procedures and refuse 
  to accept the resulting judgment before filing any de novo civil action 
  in state or federal court.â€) (emphasis as in original).Â  However, once an injured 
  person has appropriately applied to the Federal Claims Court under the Act and 
  received a judgment, the person may choose to accept the judgment or pursue 
  traditional tort remedies in state and federal court.Â  See Â§ 300aa-21(a).Â  

II.Â Â Â Â Â  Vaccine-Related 
  Injury
Quigley argues the circuit court erred 
  by dismissing Kealyâ€™s claims because Kealyâ€™s injuries are not â€œvaccine-related 
  injuriesâ€ within the scope of the Act.Â Â  Quigley contends although Kealyâ€™s injuries 
  from the first DPT shot were â€œvaccine-related injuries,â€ Kealyâ€™s injuries from 
  the second and third DPT shots were not because Riderâ€™s administrations of the 
  second and third DPT shots were intervening and superseding factors, breaking 
  the causal chain between the DPT shots and Kealyâ€™s injuries.Â  We disagree.
When the terms of a statute are clear 
  and unambiguous, our inquiry ends, and we are required to enforce the terms 
  of the statute as Congress drafted it. See United States v. Ron 
  Pair Enters., Inc., 489 U.S. 235, 241-42 (1989).
Section 300aa-11(a)(2)(A) states the Act only applies 
  to a vaccine-related injury.Â  The Act defines â€œvaccine-related injuryâ€ as â€œan 
  illness, injury, condition, or death associated with one or more of the 
  vaccines set forth in the Vaccine Injury Table . . .â€ Â§ 300aa-33(5) (emphasis 
  added).
DPT is a vaccine listed within the Vaccine Injury 
  Table.Â  Â§ 300aa-14.Â  Furthermore, even under Quigleyâ€™s arguments, Kealyâ€™s injuries 
  are â€œassociated withâ€ the DPT shots. 
  [4] Â  Thus, under any view of the negligence alleged, Kealyâ€™s injuries are 
  â€œvaccine-related injuriesâ€ within the scope of the Act.Â  See Amendola 
  v. Secretary, Depâ€™t of Health and Human Servs., 989 F.2d 1180, 1186-87 (Fed. 
  Cir. 1993) (holding injuries arising from allegations of medical malpractice 
  stemming from multiple administrations of a vaccine within the Act are vaccine-related 
  injuries subject to the Act).Â  Therefore, we reject Quigleyâ€™s assertion the 
  claim against Rider is not vaccine-related.
III.Â Â Â  Subject Matter 
  Jurisdiction
Quigley argues the circuit court erred 
  by ruling the Act deprives state courts of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Quigley 
  contends the statute merely creates a remedial process that must ordinarily 
  be exhausted prior to a vaccine-related injury being brought in state court, 
  and because Rider failed to comply with Â§Â§ 300aa â€“25(d) and â€“26(c) & (d), 
  he is equitably estopped from asserting the statute as a defense.Â Â Â  We disagree.
Where a state statute conflicts with or frustrates 
  federal law, the former must give way.Â  Maryland v. Louisiana, 451 U.S. 
  725, 746 (1981).Â  In the interest of avoiding unintended encroachment on the 
  authority of the states, however, a court interpreting a federal statute pertaining 
  to a subject traditionally governed by state law will be reluctant to find preemption. 
  Thus, preemption will not lie unless it is the clear and manifest purpose of 
  Congress.Â  Rice v. Santa Fe Elevator Corp., 331 U.S. 218, 230 (1947).Â Â  
  Evidence of preemptive purpose is sought in the text and structure of the statute 
  at issue.Â  Shaw v. Delta Air Lines, Inc., 463 U.S. 85, 95 (1983).
Federal law may preempt state law in three ways:Â  
  first, Congress may expressly define the extent to which it preempts state law; 
  second, Congress may occupy a field of regulation, impliedly preempting state 
  law; and third, a state law may be preempted to the extent it conflicts with 
  federal law.Â  Michigan Canners & Freezers Assâ€™n, Inc. v. Agricultural 
  Mktg. & Bargaining Bd., 467 U.S. 461, 469 (1984).
The Act provides:

(2)(A) No person may bring a civil action for damages in an 
  amount greater than $1,000 or in an unspecified amount against a vaccine administrator 
  . . . in a State . . . court for damages arising from a vaccine-relatedÂ Â Â Â  
  injury . . . associated with the administration of a vaccine after October 1, 
  1988 . . . unless a petition has been filed, in accordance with section 300aa-16 
  of this title . . . (B) If a civil action which is barred under subparagraph 
  (A) is filed in a State or Federal court, the court shall dismiss the action.Â  


Â§ 300aa-11(a). (emphasis added).Â  
We believe the statute states a clear and manifest 
  purpose of Congress to occupy and regulate the field of vaccination litigation 
  unless and until a plaintiff files suit in the Federal Claims Court and receives 
  a judgment.Â Â  Thus, it is unnecessary to determine if the statute removes subject 
  matter jurisdiction from state courts or merely requires an exhaustion of remedies.Â  
  Rather, regardless of the characterization, the clear, unambiguous language 
  of the statute requires state courts to dismiss an action within the scope of 
  the Act unless the action has first been brought before the Federal Claims Court.Â  
  See Shalala, 514 U.S. at 270 (â€œA claimant alleging that more than 
  $1,000 in damages resulted from a vaccination after the Actâ€™s effective date 
  in 1988 must exhaust the Actâ€™s procedures and refuse to accept the resulting 
  judgment before filing any de novo civil action in state or federal court.â€)Â  
  (citing Â§ 300aa-11); Strauss v. American Home Prod. Corp., 208 F. Supp. 
  2d 711, 714 (2002) (â€œSimply put, individuals who qualify as Program claimants 
  must file petitions in the Vaccine Court in order to pursue any vaccine-related 
  claims at all.â€) (emphasis as in original).Â  
In the present case, it is uncontested Rider is 
  a vaccine administrator within the meaning of the Act.Â  Furthermore, it is uncontested 
  Quigley is attempting to bring a civil action for damages in excess of $1,000 
  in state court, without having filed a petition pursuant to section 300aa-16, 
  for injuries sustained by Kealy after the effective date of the Act.Â  Consequently, 
  the Act required the circuit court to dismiss Quigleyâ€™s claims.Â  Because the 
  circuit court complied with the Act, we hold the circuit court did not err.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the circuit court, dismissing 
  Quigleyâ€™s claims is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and HUFF, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Keith and Donna Quigley sued Rider in their individual capacities.Â  
    The circuit court dismissed their claims for failure to comply with the applicable 
    statute of limitations.Â  Neither Keith nor Donna Quigley filed an appeal from 
    the dismissal of their claims.Â  Thus, although Keith and Donna Quigley are 
    listed as Appellants in their individual capacity, only Kealyâ€™s negligence 
    claims are the subject of this appeal.Â  Therefore, Keith and Donna Quigleyâ€™s 
    individual negligence claims against Rider are not addressed.Â  See 
    Bell v. Bennett, 307 S.C. 286, 294, 414 S.E.2d 786, 791 (Ct. App. 1992) 
    (holding an issue which is not argued in the brief is deemed abandoned on 
    appeal); Rule 208(b)(1)(B), SCACR (â€œOrdinarily, no point will be considered 
    which is not set forth in the statement of the issues on appeal.â€).Â  

 
   
    [2]  Pursuant to the Act, vaccine administrators are required to make 
    a permanent record of the vaccination.Â  Â§ 300aa-25(a).Â  Additionally, they 
    are required to report to the Secretary â€œthe occurrence of any event set forth 
    in the Vaccine Injury Table . . . the occurrence of any contraindicating reaction 
    to a vaccine which is specified in the manufacturerâ€™s package insert . . . 
    and such other matters as the Secretary may by regulation require.â€Â  Â§ 300aa-25(b).Â  
  

 
    [3] The Act requires vaccine 
    administrators to provide information to the legal guardians of any child 
    receiving a DPT shot.Â  The information must include the benefits of the vaccine, 
    the risks associated with the vaccine, and the availability of the Act.Â  Â§Â§ 
    300aa-26(c) & (d).

 
   
    [4]  During oral arguments, Quigley acknowledged Kealyâ€™s injuries are 
    associated with the DPT shots but argued Riderâ€™s negligence was the paramount 
    cause of Kealyâ€™s injuries.Â
